webTitle: Pop.com fails before it even has the chance to launch

fields.headline: Pop goes the website
fields.standfirst:
As feathers fly at the Dreamworks' internet film venture, Edward Helmore says the fault lies not only with management, but with a technology not fully fledged
Net news
fields.trailText: The failure of Pop.com, the much-heralded site from Dreamworks and Ron Howard's Imagination Entertainment, may just be to Hollywood what Boo.com was to the fashion industry.
fields.body:
The failure of Pop.com, the much-heralded site from Dreamworks and Ron Howard's Imagination Entertainment, may just be to Hollywood what Boo.com was to the fashion industry.

After the 11-month old firm was gutted of employees last week, details began to emerge of mismanagement and overambitious designs to rival that of its fashion counterpart. Pop did not burn through quite as much money (most supplied by Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen) as Boo, but it suffered the indignity of never actually launching at all.

The idea behind the company - to broadcast a mix of animated and live-action short films on the internet - was greeted with much excitement last October, before the dot.com shake-out took hold. Founders Howard, Steven Spielberg and Jeffrey Katzenberg trumpeted their new venture as one of the firms that would revolutionise the way films were made and distributed. As soon as the technology allowed, they believed, Pop.com would transform from showcase for talented young film makers into fully fledged production and distribution company.

Announcing the new company, Katzenberg said: 'Just as MTV introduced a new entertainment forum for music videos, we think this new enterprise will offer a new form of entertainment for the rapidly growing population of internet users. Pop.com has the capability not only to offer a variety of entertainment options, but to tap into an as yet undiscovered talent pool that is as global as the internet itself.'

Pop was supposed to act as a platform for experienced movie makers to experiment with the emerging medium and, when it was launched last autumn, its founders spoke of using the web as a seed bed for new projects for film and television. However, despite agreements with Mike Myers, Will Smith, Julia Roberts, Eddie Murphy, Steve Martin and others to create programming, nothing ever appeared on Pop.com besides press releases. Instead, it became a place for DreamWorks to store its talent when the studio had nothing else for staff to work on.

Then, on 1 August, the Los Angeles Times ran a story questioning the site's finances, the commitment of its backers and its prospects for success. Rumours circulated that Allen had grown tired of funding it: the daily frustrations stemmed 'from too many egos in the kitchen', according to one employee.

Insiders pointed to Pop CEO Ken Wong's lack of experience either as a manager or in the internet world: 'We needed someone with film or dotcom experience, not someone with neither.' Before Pop, Wong was in semi-retirement, and before that he was president of Disney's Imagineering division. Moreover, observers said that of all online entertainment sites, Pop was the most bureaucratic and disorganised.

'It was put together in the days when people thought if you put enough big names and big money together, things will work themselves out,' says Sanjay Malhorta of BandWidth Capital. 'As the market caught up with the expectations of business plans and good management, those weaknesses became glaringly evident.'

None of Pop's high-profile principals were present at last week's meeting to all but shut the company. When asked why neither Katzenberg, Spielberg nor Howard had attended, Wong had no real answer: 'We believe this space is not yet a business. We're not clairvoyants or geniuses, but we think it's going to take years.'

Pop's first major acquisition, last autumn, was an acclaimed short film called The Dancing Cow. It sat on the shelves waiting for the site's launch. Excerpts from DreamWorks' Chicken Run were also scheduled to be released but never materialised. 'It's sad that all these filmmakers got tied up for so long with nothing to show for it,' said Randy Greenberg, vice president of independent film company Always.

But the closure of the firm is more than just the failure of yet another web company without a viable business model. It has shown how hard it is for even the biggest names in entertainment to make sense of the web at a time when the medium itself is rocking the industry's foundations. Not only is the music business fighting for what may turn out to be a Pyrrhic victory against copyright troublemakers such as Napster and Gnutella; there are also signs that mass piracy is about to afflict the movie industry as well.

Since the demise of the Digital Entertainment Network last spring, problems with the internet have scared away investors. The decision to fold Pop was related to failed merger talks with iFilm, which were terminated 10 days ago. Sources say iFilm had balked at Pop's valuation, which is said to have been $200 million.

Others have suffered, too. 'Digital entertainment universe' Scour.com has laid off 56 of 62 employees, saying it ran out of money. A dozen employees were laid off at Shockwave.com, the entertainment site from Flash technology maker Macromedia in San Francisco. That site carries between 700 and 1,000 pieces of content and relies on banner advertising for income. Shockwave is believed to have made expensive deals with the likes of South Park creators Matt Stone and Trey Parker and director David Lynch, but the shows have failed to materialise. The company's planned IPO for late this year now looks doubtful.

Efforts by Microsoft and America Online, among others, to translate TV-style shows to the internet foundered a couple of years ago. Neither have multi-media websites devoted to women fared well. The much trumpeted Oxygen site has experienced an exodus of key editors and staff; and shares in iVillage have plummeted from $95.88 to around $7. Several executives have left during this year, and in late July Candace Carpenter stepped down as CEO.

Despite all this gloom, webcasters are planning to roll out dozens of new online entertainment programs as the new television season starts this autumn.

The subject matter, aimed largely at university students with access to high-speed campus internet connections, pushes the limits of taste. The offerings still have to overcome technical limitations and the fact that the audience for online entertainment is still tiny. Romp.com is launching a new game called 'Avoid Commitment', where players have to hurl a martini at a temptress and then seduce her; another, called 'Panty Raid,' involves retrieving underwear from a girl's dormitory.

'This is like the 1940s in television,' David Wertheimer, chairman of WireBreak Networks, a firm that creates and syndicates web programmes for other sites, told the Wall Street Journal . 'There's no standard for what works and doesn't work.'

And viewers are growing. Despite its problems, Shockwave.com drew 5.7 million users in July, up from 207,000 a year ago, while AtomFilms had 749,000, up from 247,000 a year ago.

But the technical limitations of broadcasting over the web remain the biggest problem for most users. 'People don't think of the internet yet as entertaining them the way television or a movie does,' says Kristen Harmeling of Yankelovich Partners, a US marketing research firm.

Whatever the future of internet broadcasting, Pop.com is unlikely to play a part. Howard said setting up Pop had been a 'tricky, sometimes frustrating' process and although the partners still had 'a lot of enthusiasm for the future of the medium' they wished to wait for the technology that would make entertainment on the web a more rewarding experience. Pop would wind up 'back where we started', he added.

Insiders pointed to Pop CEO Ken Wong's lack of experience either as a manager or in the internet world: 'We needed someone with film or dotcom experience, not someone with neither.' Before Pop, Wong was in semi-retirement, and before that he was president of Disney's Imagineering division. Moreover, observers said that of all online entertainment sites, Pop was the most bureaucratic and disorganised. 'It was put together in the days when people thought if you put enough big names and big money together, things will work themselves out,' says Sanjay Malhorta of BandWidth Capital. 'As the market caught up with the expectations of business plans and good management, those weaknesses became glaringly evident.' None of Pop's high-profile principals were present at last week's meeting to all but shut the company. When asked why neither Katzenberg, Spielberg nor Howard had attended, Wong had no real answer: 'We believe this space is not yet a business. We're not clairvoyants or geniuses, but we think it's going to take years.' Pop's first major acquisition, last autumn, was an acclaimed short film called The Dancing Cow. It sat on the shelves waiting for the site's launch. Excerpts from DreamWorks' Chicken Run were also scheduled to be released but never materialised. 'It's sad that all these filmmakers got tied up for so long with nothing to show for it,' said Randy Greenberg, vice president of independent film company Always. But the closure of the firm is more than just the failure of yet another web company without a viable business model. It has shown how hard it is for even the biggest names in entertainment to make sense of the web at a time when the medium itself is rocking the industry's foundations. Not only is the music business fighting for what may turn out to be a Pyrrhic victory against copyright troublemakers such as Napster and Gnutella; there are also signs that mass piracy is about to afflict the movie industry as well. Since the demise of the Digital Entertainment Network last spring, problems with the internet have scared away investors. The decision to fold Pop was related to failed merger talks with iFilm, which were terminated 10 days ago. Sources say iFilm had balked at Pop's valuation, which is said to have been $200 million. Others have suffered, too. 'Digital entertainment universe' Scour.com has laid off 56 of 62 employees, saying it ran out of money. A dozen employees were laid off at Shockwave.com, the entertainment site from Flash technology maker Macromedia in San Francisco. That site carries between 700 and 1,000 pieces of content and relies on banner advertising for income. Shockwave is believed to have made expensive deals with the likes of South Park creators Matt Stone and Trey Parker and director David Lynch, but the shows have failed to materialise. The company's planned IPO for late this year now looks doubtful. Efforts by Microsoft and America Online, among others, to translate TV-style shows to the internet foundered a couple of years ago. Neither have multi-media websites devoted to women fared well. The much trumpeted Oxygen site has experienced an exodus of key editors and staff; and shares in iVillage have plummeted from $95.88 to around $7. Several executives have left during this year, and in late July Candace Carpenter stepped down as CEO. Despite all this gloom, webcasters are planning to roll out dozens of new online entertainment programs as the new television season starts this autumn. The subject matter, aimed largely at university students with access to high-speed campus internet connections, pushes the limits of taste. The offerings still have to overcome technical limitations and the fact that the audience for online entertainment is still tiny. Romp.com is launching a new game called 'Avoid Commitment', where players have to hurl a martini at a temptress and then seduce her; another, called 'Panty Raid,' involves retrieving underwear from a girl's dormitory. 'This is like the 1940s in television,' David Wertheimer, chairman of WireBreak Networks, a firm that creates and syndicates web programmes for other sites, told the Wall Street Journal . 'There's no standard for what works and doesn't work.' And viewers are growing. Despite its problems, Shockwave.com drew 5.7 million users in July, up from 207,000 a year ago, while AtomFilms had 749,000, up from 247,000 a year ago. But the technical limitations of broadcasting over the web remain the biggest problem for most users. 'People don't think of the internet yet as entertaining them the way television or a movie does,' says Kristen Harmeling of Yankelovich Partners, a US marketing research firm. Whatever the future of internet broadcasting, Pop.com is unlikely to play a part. Howard said setting up Pop had been a 'tricky, sometimes frustrating' process and although the partners still had 'a lot of enthusiasm for the future of the medium' they wished to wait for the technology that would make entertainment on the web a more rewarding experience. Pop would wind up 'back where we started', he added.

fields.headline: @large
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Ennui sets in as text type goes off message
fields.body:
Ennui sets in as text type goes off message

An incredible 6 million text messages were sent on A-level results day last month, says Vodafone. However, @large is worried about phones which speed up message writing by guessing which word you are trying to type. If you type in the word 'footie' on some phones it spits out 'ennui'. Is Nokia trying to tell us something about the beautiful game?

What's in a hyphen?

A punch-up over punctuation is emerging between the Beeb and wannabe media mogul Jon Danzig of Look Hear, a multimedia movie-making business (look-hear.com), who has been embroiled in a custody battle over lookhear.com, registered by Oscar Music & Media.

Last month, Danzig explained his plight on the Stephen Rhodes consumer show on BBC Three Counties radio. Rhodes queried Danzig's view that the hyphen was irrelevant and the names were equivalent for trademark purposes.

Given the stance, Danzig proposed that the BBC would not mind if he registered the BBC-Three-Counties-Radio website with the appropriate hyphens. A letter from the BBC legal department suggested that, on the contrary, the move would invite the attention of the BBC brand enforcement unit.

It's a jungle out there

We were sorry to hear about the failure of jungle.com to reach the dizzy heights of billion pound flotation and was instead swallowed whole by Argos.

At Jungle's launch at London's Tiger Tiger bar, @large did its best to persuade Steve Bennett not to use The Lion Sleeps Tonight as its signature tune, because it was too cheesy. Instead we suggested M-beat's seminal jungle music classic, Incredible. It features the famous chorus chant: 'Wicket. Wicket. Jungle Is Massive.' It truly could have been.

webTitle: William Keegan: Oil fuels the fear of inflation

fields.headline: Oil fuels the fear of inflation
fields.standfirst:
French haulier's association
Eurotunnel
fields.trailText: We were lucky. We managed to cross the Channel in the interval between the fishermen's blockade and the disruption caused by the French truck drivers.
fields.body:
We were lucky. We managed to cross the Channel in the interval between the fishermen's blockade and the disruption caused by the French truck drivers. This was in spite of chancing a detour to Colombey Les Deux Eglises, the home of General Charles de Gaulle, where one was reminded that even the great man himself had problems with the French when they took to the streets.

Our only traffic problem in France was at the Italian border, where we spent an hour waiting to pay the toll at Ventimiglia. It makes you wonder about the wisdom of the road-pricing system. On the other hand, despite a grim warning at Ventimiglia that we faced a suspiciously precise 127 kilometres of French traffic jams ahead, the jams simply vanished on one of the busiest Saturdays of the year. Perhaps the French had all stopped for dinner.

Notwithstanding France's little local difficulties over the price of petrol (and such difficulties are no longer confined to France) I am reminded whenever I travel to the Continent that, in the end, I am on the European side of the great debate. While I was standing with a European official next to a French war memorial, he paused, pointed and said: 'Brussels bureaucracy has to be better than this.'

But one cannot disregard the serious economic difficulties involved for Britain.

The big question for those of us with such concerns is: what happens if it comes to a question of either in - or out altogether? It is admiration for European standards of social protection that drives TUC general secretary John Monks's support for the euro, as Robert Taylor makes clear in his interesting new book on the unions, The TUC - from the General Strike to New Unionism (published by Palgrave). And it is interesting that many former members of the Left now see social salvation in Europe.

While we are on the subject of the Left, an analyst of European affairs observed recently: 'Perhaps New Labour would not be quite so unpopular if Tony Blair had to look over both shoulders, as most continental leaders do.'

The brilliance of Sir Edward Heath's leadership was in taking Britain into 'Europe' without a referendum. De Gaulle had said 'no' to Britain after answering his country's call to return from Colombey Les Deux Eglises; Heath got on well with President Pompidou, as is clear from his memoirs, and from the publication last week of a fascinating historical document Britain's Entry into the European Community - Report on the Negotiations of 1970-1972 by Sir Con O'Neill' (Frank Cass).

When reminiscing at the Foreign Office launch of the book last week, Heath lamented the fact that the 'momentum' of our relationship with Europe was adversely affected by the 1973-74 oil crisis. That crisis not only hit all the major industrial economies badly, it also affected the fate of their political leaders. Heath himself was brought down by a miners' challenge to his authority that would probably not have occurred if the rise in the price of oil had not tempted domestic producers of energy to flex their muscles.

There are some uncanny parallels between today's concerns about the price of oil and the crisis of the mid-1970s. It is fashionable to argue that things have moved on, that we are less dependent on energy thanks to the conservation efforts induced by previous oil crises. It is also true that there are still massive reserves of oil around the world. Nevertheless, when I hear world leaders pleading with the Organisation of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) to be 'more responsible', I tend to think like Gielgud's character in Harold Pinter's play No Man's Land : 'I've known this before.'

Perhaps the most interesting parallel is between all the 'New Economy' rubbish we have been subjected to over the past year, and the feeling, in the early 1970s before the oil crisis, that the prospect was one of indefinite, healthy, synchronised economic growth throughout the world.

I recall the OECD economist John Llewellyn (now with Lehman Brothers) telling me during the earlier oil crisis: 'We have tended to take energy for granted, but energy is different from other economic inputs.'

For much of the recent US boom, the economy was doing no more than matching earlier historic economic performances. Certainly the lat ter phase of the boom had a lot to do with investment in new technology; but it also received an enormous boost from the collapse of oil prices.

An important reason why the macro-economic picture around the world has been so good recently is that policymakers have been able to run the economy with little or no inflationary threat. What is happening in the oil market is a serious warning that there could be trouble in store. The cheapness of 'gasoline' in the US is quite amazing, largely because energy taxes are negligible by European standards.

The market works - but in matters of oil exploration and development the market works slowly. A US economic adviser once said that an economist's time lag is a politician's lost election. An oil price of $10 was absurdly low, but one in the $30 to $40 range and possibly rising is a serious challenge to the view that the good times are here for ever.

Behind all the technical arguments about oil stocks, and the political wrangling, lies the simple fact that, as in the 1970s, demand has for the time being outstripped available supply.

webTitle: Island sells web address to buy UN membership

fields.headline: Island sells web address to buy UN membership
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: A tiny Pacific island state has exploited a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity provided by the world wide web to fund its newly acquired membership of the United Nations. Tuvalu has sold an American firm the rights to use its internet domain address.
fields.body:
A tiny Pacific island state has exploited a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity provided by the world wide web to fund its newly acquired membership of the United Nations. Tuvalu has sold an American firm the rights to use its internet domain address.

Last week Tuvalu was admitted to the UN in advance of the world leaders' Millennium summit.

The former British colony of the Ellice Islands is a string of coral atolls with a population of 10,000, situated about half-way between Hawaii and Australia. Fish and coconut butter were its only exports until a $50m deal earlier this year which sold off 10-year rights to its '.tv' domain name.

The deal with a US firm called DotTV effectively trebled Tuvalu's national income. Part of these receipts will be used to pay annual UN subscriptions, a move that would place the country ahead of the US, which is massively in arrears. The government has spent some of the $18m downpayment on infrastructure, internet connections and scholarships.

Names such as 'zee.tv' and 'soccer.tv' are being sold on by DotTV to companies setting up internet television stations. China.tv and net.tv recently sold for $100,000 a year. This is in anticipation of high-speed connections that will soon allow broadcast-quality television channels over the internet.

'The agreement with DotTV has given our nation a sense of economic independence. Our membership of the United Nations signals to the world that Tuvalu has joined the international community,' said Prime Minister Ionatana Ionatana.

'Rarely does the internet have such a direct economic impact on developing nations,' said Lou Kerner, chief executive of DotTV.

Tuvalu became the 189th member of the UN during last week's 55th General Assembly, and its prime minister featured in the world leaders' photocall. Only four countries have applied and been admitted to the UN in the past six years; Tuvalu is the only admission this year. The country was also recently admitted to the Commonwealth to reflect its growing involvement in world affairs.

In his maiden UN speech, Ionatana raised fears about the effect of globalisation on culture, and rising sea levels, which threaten parts of his country.

fields.trailText: Arsenal are quietly confident of joining European super-spenders Lazio in the second phase thanks to a kind draw. The Italians, Champions for the first time since 1974, should win the group after an extravagant summer splash brought Argentine forwards Crespo and Lopez, plus goalkeeper Peruzzi (right), to an already fearsome squad. Sparta Prague are beatable, although they take heart from drawing in Porto and putting the frighteners on Barcelona in last year's competition. As for Champions League debutants Shaktar Donetsk , a trip to the hostile Strahov Stadium in deepest, iciest Ukraine is not to be relished even if the team is bereft of household stars. Tuesday:

webTitle: Those television moments that made us all squirm

fields.headline: Those television moments that made us all squirm
fields.standfirst: Viewers vote with glee for the worst 100, reports  Vanessa Thorpe
fields.trailText: Viewers vote with glee for the worst 100, reports  Vanessa Thorpe.
fields.body:
It was the antidote to all the recent backslapping in the television business. Instead of plaudits and nostalgia, the industry last night shone the spotlight on its biggest failures.

The 100 Greatest TV Moments From Hell on Channel 4 provided a countdown of all the most dire and upsetting miscalculations the networks have made in the name of broadcast entertainment.

Just five days after BBC2's masterly sitcom, Fawlty Towers, was named the best television programme of all time, Judy Finnegan and Richard Madeley, the married daytime presenting team on ITV's This Morning , were alone held responsible for five of the most embarrassing sequences ever screened.

The number one spot was awarded to the moment when Madeley appeared in front of the This Morning crew dressed as Ali G, the spoof rapping star, equipped with gold chains, yellow tracksuit and Tommy Hilfiger hat.

'It was actually brilliant,' said a Channel 4 spokeswoman. 'These clips of programmes were really selected because they were unexpected incidents in television history, although some of them may well have been nightmares for the presenter involved.'

The second most popular unpopular moment was the appearance of the hit group Dexy's Midnight Runners playing their song 'Jackie Wilson Said' on Top Of The Pops in front of a large photograph of the darts player Jocky Wilson, due to a misunderstanding.

The 100 chosen excerpts were picked by a panel of authors, television executives and journalists and then voted for by visitors to the Channel 4 website.

Also cited on the roll of television dishonour was the humiliating evening in 1989 when Samantha Fox was teamed with rock star Mick Fleetwood to present the pop industry's Brit Awards.

Other dismal moments included the appearance of the worst University Challenge team. The four young women from New Hall, Cambridge University, achieved a record low score of 35 points and were defeated by Nottingham University's 335 points in 1997. They answered only nine questions correctly in the half-hour programme and found that even getting off the mark was a problem - wrong answers put the ill-starred undergraduates on minus 15 for the first half of the show.

The late Harold Wilson's unfortunate post-premiership attempt to host BBC2's Friday Night, Saturday Morning chat show was given its due as a moment of TV hell, too. The only other politician to be featured in the Channel 4 selection of turkeys was the former Conservative Minister John Redwood. The then Welsh Secretary was famously caught by the cameras as he made a grim hash of pretending he knew the words to the Welsh national anthem.

But it was the failings of daytime television that became the recurrent theme during the evening's countdown of disasters. The makers of the lunchtime quiz show Going For Gold, hosted by Henry Kelly, were called to account for having allowed foreigners to compete against native English speakers.

The saddest and baddest moment in the television canon was considered to be the revelation that the garden of the BBC's Blue Peter had been vandalised in 1983.

Finally, two television shows that, arguably, should never have been made at all received a sound drubbing. They were the soap opera about the female inmates of an Australian penitentiary called Prisoner: Cellblock H and L!ve TV for inventing the News Bunny and topless darts.

Ten of the worst

1. Richard Madeley impersonates Ali G on This Morning

2. Dexy's Midnight Runners play Jackie Wilson Said on Top of The Pops in front of a photograph of darts player Jocky Wilson

3. Streaker Mark Roberts surprises This Morning 's weatherman

4. L!ve TV - News Bunny, topless darts and bouncing dwarves

5. Welsh Secretary John Redwood fluffs the Welsh national anthem.

6. Arthur Mullard and Hylda Baker perform a Grease hit on TOTP

7. Shakin' Stevens attacks Madeley for comparing him to Elvis

8. Late-night 'yoof' show The Word and its disgusting 'Hopefuls'

9. Yippies take over The Frost Report

10. The Brits presented by Mick Fleetwood and Samantha Fox

webTitle: Panic as petrol supplies run dry

fields.headline: Panic as petrol supplies run dry
fields.standfirst: The issues explained: Petrol
fields.trailText: Dozens of petrol stations across Britain ran out of unleaded fuel yesterday as fears rose that protesters against high prices could cause a nationwide fuel crisis.
fields.body:
Dozens of petrol stations across Britain ran out of unleaded fuel yesterday as fears rose that protesters against high prices could cause a nationwide fuel crisis.

Panic-buying was reported in Merseyside as motorists filled up their tanks as news of a shortage spread. 'Demand has gone through the roof,' said one major petrol retailer.

Shell reported that 30 of its petrol stations in the North-west were expected to be out of unleaded fuel by late last night and BP said five of its stations had already run dry. Supplies in the region have been disrupted by a blockade of Stanlow oil refinery, in Cheshire, by farmers and lorry drivers demanding a cut in fuel taxes. A demonstrator was arrested yesterday after scuffles broke out. The protest has trapped tankers on which 400 Shell and BP petrol stations rely.

European finance ministers meeting in France yesterday called on the Opec oil-producing countries to raise production in order to reduce the price of oil.

Eurotunnel

webTitle: Scientists 'closer to' Holy Grail of physics

fields.headline: Scientists 'closer to' Holy Grail of physics
fields.trailText: Scientists believe they may have caught a tantalising glimpse of the universe's most mysterious component, the Higgs particle, triggering a furious row among particle physicists.
fields.body:
Scientists believe they may have caught a tantalising glimpse of the universe's most mysterious component, the Higgs particle, triggering a furious row among particle physicists.

The Higgs particle - considered the Holy Grail of physics - is believed to give all other objects their mass. Nothing can have weight without them, it is thought.

But the particle has eluded scientists since its existence was first proposed by Edinburgh researcher Peter Higgs. Three decades of searching uncovered no sightings - until last week.

A few days ago, at the Cern particle physics laboratory in Switzerland, researchers observed a series of anomalous results on their giant Large Electron Positron (Lep) accelerator, a 16-mile underground atom smasher drilled underneath Geneva. These observations 'are consistent with the production of the Higgs', Cern's research director Roger Cashmore told the journal Nature .

But physicists still cannot be sure, and the uncertainty has provoked heated debate at Cern where researchers are demanding four months' more research to confirm or refute these claims.

However, the laboratory's massive Lep accelerator is scheduled for closure this month, so it can be dismantled and replaced by an even more powerful £2 billion accelerator in 2005.

'This place is in uproar,' one Cern physicist told The Observer . 'We are now tantalisingly close to finding the most sought-after prize in physics. The Higgs is vital to all our theories. Without it we would have to tear up all the laws of logic and start again. Yet we may have to give up the hunt just as we are clos ing in on it, allowing our American rivals at the Fermilab in Chicago to steal the prize. They are due to start running experiments next week on their accelerator after four years' renovation.

'We therefore have a choice: delay closure and keep looking even if there is no guarantee of success. These observations could just be anomalies, after all. We would therefore delay the opening of our new machine for no good reason.

'Alternatively, if we do give up, we could go down as being the greatest wusses in the history of science - for giving up when we could have won the prize.'

A Cern official said the issue would be resolved on Thursday when its research council finally meets to discuss formally a proposal to delay the closure of Lep. 'There will be no going back after that,' he said.

webTitle: Hostages freed after $4m ransom convoy ambush

fields.headline: Hostages freed after $4m ransom convoy ambush
fields.trailText: Amid jubilant scenes the final four Western holidaymakers held hostage in the southern Philippines since Easter Sunday were released yesterday. But their release was marked by high drama as emissaries carrying the $4 million (£2.7m) ransom, provided by Libya, were ambushed en route to the exchange and three members of their party killed in the ensuing shoot-out.
fields.body:
Amid jubilant scenes the final four Western holidaymakers held hostage in the southern Philippines since Easter Sunday were released yesterday. But their release was marked by high drama as emissaries carrying the $4 million (£2.7m) ransom, provided by Libya, were ambushed en route to the exchange and three members of their party killed in the ensuing shoot-out.

The release of the last of the group of 10 holidaymakers, seized from a diving resort, has still not closed the kidnap saga. Fearing an attack from the Philippines military, the Abu Sayyaf Muslim separatist captors yesterday reneged on their promise to free all the remaining prisoners held at their base on Jolo island.

Abu Sayyaf are keeping a Filipino seized at the same time as the Westerners, two French journalists who were captured while covering the crisis and 12 Christian evangelists who were kidnapped when they went into the Jolo jungle to pray for the hostages. It is unclear when they will be freed.

A splinter group of the main Abu Sayyaf is also holding an American man for whom it is demanding $10m (£6.9m). Jeffrey Schilling, 24, a Muslim from California was seized on 28 August when he visited a rebel camp with his Filipino Muslim wife, Ivi Osani. The Libyans, who hope their largesse will improve their international standing, have not indicated whether they are willing to help secure his release.

Grinning broadly through bushy beards the hostages could not hide their joy at being free. 'It's great,' said German Marc Wallert, whose parents had been released earlier. The other three men released were Finns Seppo Juhani Franti and Risto Vahanen, and Frenchman Stephane Loisy.

The group feared for their freedom after rival guerillas ambushed the intermediaries' convoy in an attempt to seize the sackloads of ransom in Philippines pesos that were being carried. One of the intermediaries' bodyguards and two other men were killed and at least 20 others injured in the attack.

webTitle: Petrol queues, pumps run dry - welcome back to the 1970s

fields.headline: Petrol queues, pumps run dry - welcome back to the 1970s
fields.standfirst:
Truckers' blockades begin to bite as garages across Britain are forced to turn away drivers

The issues explained: Petrol
fields.trailText: When Neil Anders arrived for work at the Formby filling station near Liverpool yesterday morning, he found that the unthinkable had happened. The station had run out of petrol. By midday, Anders, the assistant manager, had turned away hundreds of customers. The forecourt was deserted.
fields.body:
When Neil Anders arrived for work at the Formby filling station near Liverpool yesterday morning, he found that the unthinkable had happened. The station had run out of petrol. By midday, Anders, the assistant manager, had turned away hundreds of customers. The forecourt was deserted.

'I never thought anything like this would happen,' he said. 'Since people thought we might run out it's been chocka. And now we have. It's amazing.'

It was a scene repeated at dozens of other service stations across northern England yesterday morning. The tankers bringing fuel for the weekend had simply failed to arrive. The pumps were dry.

Twenty miles away from Formby, in a yard outside Stanlow Refinery, next to Ellesmere Port, 60 bright yellow and red tankers were lined up ready to go. But they were not going anywhere. Shell had decided that it was too dangerous for their drivers to take to the road.

Outside the refinery's gates a crowd of protesters, mainly truckers and farmers, milled around drinking tea and eating pork pies. Though they looked less than threatening, during the night police had been forced to intervene after a tanker's windscreen was smashed in scuffles and one protestor was arrested. Earlier in the week a tanker driver was arrested when he mounted the pavement in an attempt to drive round demonstrators.

Shell admitted yesterday that 20 to 30 stations in the North-west were running out of petrol and that, unless supplies were brought in from elsewhere, the number would rise. Five BP stations, also supplied by the Stanlow refinery, had run out too. A BP spokeswoman said that their staff had been reporting panic-buying of petrol in Liverpool. 'We have made contingency plans to obtain fuel from other depots. But if the blockade continues, it is inevitable [that] will have an effect,' she said.

And yesterday evening it looked as if the 'battle of the refineries' would intensify, raising the possibility of more widespread fuel shortages this week. The protestors outside Stanlow said they were planning to deploy a steam-roller that police could not tow away.

'We'll stay here indefinitely,' said Brynle Williams, the farmer who is organising the Stanlow blockade. 'For as long as it takes.'

If the protestors succeed in halting distribution from the 15 main refineries in the UK that supply 80 per cent of our petrol and diesel fuel, then stations everywhere could start running out of fuel. There are signs already that the crisis is deepening. In west Wales yesterday, lorry drivers blocked the main entrance to the Texaco refinery in Milford Haven and sent trucks to cut off a nearby Elf Aquitaine installation. Two important depots at Bristol's Avonmouth docks - one used by Texaco and Total Fina, the other by Esso - were also picketed.

Supermarket fuel outlets have also been hit. Sainsbury's said that three outlets in Scotland had been forced to shut and that 15 of its stations in the rest of the country were 'running out'of fuel. Asda warned that its petrol stations in Bristol would be affected within days if protests continue.

Truckers say that high fuel prices are forcing them out of business. The cost of British petrol jumped more than 40 per cent from January 1999 to June 2000 and is currently the highest in Europe. Tax and duties make up about 75 per cent of the price of a litre of premium unleaded petrol, currently about 85p, but recent crude oil price rises have put even more pressure on drivers.

Filling up their car costs the average family more than £1,000 a year, experts calculate, but fuel taxes put more than £23billion a year into government coffers. The price rise, if sustained, will add at least two billion to the total. Gordon Brown, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, has frequently ruled out fuel tax cuts, saying the money is needed for health and education.

The forecourt cost rise is largely due to a surge in crude, unrefined oil prices over the last 18 months. A barrel of crude now costs more than $33, a ten-year high. Oil companies have fed this rise through to their customers. Prices have also been driven up by speculation that restricted supply combined with the booming world economy's growing demand for oil-based products would trigger a severe shortage. Some analysts have predicted a peak of $50 per barrel.

There is still plenty of feverish buying by oil traders, in the same spirit as the people of Merseyside this weekend, driving up the cost of fuel. The widespread protests in France, and now Britain, are also helping to keep the price high.

Opec (the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries) is meeting later today in Vienna.

It has been under heavy pressure from President Clinton and other Western leaders to increase in oil production to ease the market squeeze and get prices down to around $28 a barrel. European finance ministers met in Versailles yesterday to plan their strategy. However, any production increase will take at least several weeks to feed through to the market.

Yesterday, French road hauliers and farmers reluctantly began lifting their own blockade of oil refineries and fuel depots. Their six-day fuel price protest had brought much of France to a standstill, with some four-fifths of the country's petrol stations empty, regional airports closed and school buses and postal deliveries suspended. Thousands of British holidaymakers were also stranded as they tried to return to the UK after summer breaks.

'Carrying on would have risked turning the whole thing sour,' said Christian Rose, national secretary of the French hauliers' federation. 'We cannot ignore what the government has offered ... This was a dignified protest and it was important to show that the road haulage companies did not do it for nothing.'

The French Interior Ministry said that some 95 blockades of refineries and depots were still in place yesterday, 65 fewer than at the end of last week. A further 50 barricades and go-slow operations were still severely disrupting traffic around the country, but a ministry spokesman said 'a clear retreat' had begun. It is now unlikely that troops and police will be sent in to forcibly clear blockades as previously feared.

French agricultural unions have also urged their members - albeit 'with a heavy heart' in the case of one - to end their part in the demonstrations. Their retreat is good news to the Prime Minister, Lionel Jospin and his British counterpart.

Whether an improvement in the situation will come as a relief to Anders and his colleagues remains to be seen. 'All the cashiers just want to go to the pub,' he said.

Additional reporting by Nick Paton Walsh and Jon Henley in Paris


French haulier's association
Eurotunnel

webTitle: 'Humble' leader who hiked the price of oil

fields.headline: 'Humble' leader who hiked the price of oil
fields.standfirst:
Venezuela's Hugo Chavez is behind Opec's new found confidence, report Phil Gunson and Faisal Islam

The issues explained: Petrol
fields.trailText: Few motorists cursing rising petrol prices will have heard of Hugo Chavez, but the paratrooper-turned-president of Venezuela is at the heart of the re-emergence of the Opec cartel.
fields.body:
Few motorists cursing rising petrol prices will have heard of Hugo Chavez, but the paratrooper-turned-president of Venezuela is at the heart of the re-emergence of the Opec cartel.

Over the past 18 months Chavez has rekindled Opec unity, reinvigorating the cartel as a force on the world stage. The fruits of his labour are apparent in a quadrupling of the oil price since his arrival in power in 1998.

Last month Chavez toured all 10 of Venezuela's fellow Opec members. He became the first foreign head of state since the Gulf war to visit Saddam Hussein and he got on famously with Libya's Colonel Gadaffi. He revels in his role as an international champion of the impoverished masses.

Today, his Oil Minister, Ali Rodriguez, will be beating a drum for only a token increase in oil production at the Opec meeting in Vienna. The West is hoping for an increase of at least 700,000 barrels a day. Any thing less is likely to see the oil price shoot up, and stock markets dive.

But Chavez's real moment will come at the end of the month when he hosts the first Opec heads of state meeting for 25 years in Caracas.

It is a remarkable coup considering Venezuela is a relatively minor producer of oil and pre-Chavez was barely engaged in Opec's affairs.

When he came to office, the price of a barrel was in the region of $8 and Venezuela was heading for a devastating recession. Around 70 per cent of exports and 60 per cent of tax income is generated by oil, and the price is now $33.

But before Chavez's presidency, Venezuela had consistently sabotaged Opec's attempts to raise prices, by deliberately producing more than its official quota.

Chavez was determined to change that. He joined forces with the world's biggest producer - Saudi Arabia - and non-Opec Mexico in agreeing production cuts that helped turn the tide.

Arguing for a 'multi polar' world, and against the scourge of 'savage neoliberalism', Chavez is not the first Venezuelan leader to seek to parlay oil wealth into influence on the world stage.

At last week's UN world leader's summit he offered to supply oil 'on favourable terms' to cash-strapped Central American nations.

Lt. Col. Hugo Chavez first came to the world's attention in February of 1992, when he tried - and failed - to overthrow the elected government of Venezuela in a military coup. Arrested and brought before the TV cameras, Chavez turned defeat into a kind of victory with the briefest political speech of his life.

'Chavez's appearance on television lasted for just over a minute,' notes Richard Gott, author of a recent book on the Venezuelan president. 'Its unexpected result was to turn him from a wholly unknown colonel into a national figure.'

A tough-talking, leftist populist, Chavez comes from humble origins in the rural hinterland. He looks and talks like ordinary Venezuelans.

He brought the military back into politics, lambasted the media, the church hierarchy and the 'oligarchs'. And he tackled the issue of the low oil price. He considers any return to such low prices as 'passing a death sentence' on Opec countries.

But even as Chavez was addressing the UN summit, a local newspaper headline summed up the challenge: 'Oil rises to $35 a barrel,' it read, 'and poverty reaches 81 per cent.'


French haulier's association
Eurotunnel

fields.headline: Whatever 'quidditch' is, we love it
fields.standfirst: Harry Potter's game, expletives and 'God' head the field, as a search for our favourite word draws to close. Oh, and Spike Milligan chose 'fish'
fields.trailText: Harry Potter's game, expletives and 'God' head the field, as a search for our favourite word draws to close. Oh, and Spike Milligan chose 'fish'
fields.body:
The 10 favourites in alphabetical order:
Bollocks Elephant Hope Jesus Joy Puddle Quidditch Rainbow Serendipity Sex

'Strange' - that's the word that sprang to mind when Sir Bob Geldof launched the Search for the Nation's Favourite Word in May. In a year full of millennial polls and lists, this quest stood out as either the most original, or the silliest, of the lot.

But, with the winning word due to be announced next week, The Observer can reveal that 'strange' has not made it into the top 10.

In fact, 'Quidditch', the name of the school game played in the Harry Potter series of children's books, and 'serendipity', the knack of making happy discoveries by chance, are now running neck and neck in the race for the finishing line.

Shortly behind them is 'bollocks', a crude reflection, perhaps, of the fact that Geldof launched his appeal for public votes with the admission that his own favourite word was 'fuck'.

Expletives have scored well so far. 'Crap' has made many appearances, but the long succession of pious religious vocabulary nominated has helped to balance out the profanities. 'God' has been selected by a fair proportion of voters and 'Jesus' has made it high up the top 10. Organisers are unsure whether to ban or to handicap this word, however, because they believe that British members of an American evangelical church were all instructed to vote for it.

Positive and uplifting ideas such as 'hope' and 'joy' have made the top 10 and so does one of the most basic of all emotive words: 'sex'.

Over the past three months, more than 13,000 people have voted. The poll was mounted to promote the London Festival of Literature, known as The Word, which starts on 22 September at The Globe Theatre in London. Geldof is a trustee of the festival and he has called on the public to help put together a 'cultural and linguistic Domesday Book for the beginning of the new millennium' to be published this autumn.

All the proceeds from the book will support the educational programme of the festival's nominated charity, the British Dyslexia Association.

James, Beryl Bainbridge and Robert Harris are contributing. webTitle: Love your enemy - he may be your best friend

fields.headline: Love your enemy - he may be your best friend
fields.standfirst: Hate figures who do us the power of good
fields.trailText: Worried that you have too many enemies? Well, stop fretting, get out the voodoo dolls and stick a few more needles in them. You may hate others, and they may hate you, but it can be good for you - if only in the short term. If you haven't got enemies your life may not be complete.
fields.body:
Worried that you have too many enemies? Well, stop fretting, get out the voodoo dolls and stick a few more needles in them. You may hate others, and they may hate you, but it can be good for you - if only in the short term. If you haven't got enemies your life may not be complete.

According to a new book by the celebrated psychologist Dorothy Rowe, we don't just need friends, we also need enemies. She counted 24 different benefits brought by having enemies, including making you feel more important, making you feel more virtuous, and simply making life more exciting.

'Having an enemy could be an advantage,' she concluded after research for Friends and Enemies which took her to Bosnia, Northern Ireland, South Africa and Lebanon. It's only in the long term that the drawbacks become clear.

The national hysteria over Big Brother's Nasty Nick shows not just how much we all love to have a hate-figure, but how effective it can be in bringing a country closer together. 'If a group has an enemy, that enemy brings the group together - we saw that in this country in World War II' said Rowe. 'You see it in business organisations - if the boss is seen as an enemy, the workers get very close.'

'First, get a common enemy' could be the opening of any leader's rulebook. 'Rulers have always invented an enemy to keep people together. Rulers who want to stay in power always have a war,' said Rowe (think of General Galtieri's decision to invade the Falklands) and it even applies to democracies (think of Thatcher's electoral triumph after defending the Falklands).

It even explains much of geo-politics. 'The US is a very diverse group of people, and the way the government held the country together was by having an enemy. But when the Berlin wall came down, the US no longer had an enemy,' explained Rowe. 'So President Bush immediately announced a war on drugs.' The Colombian drug barons, such as Pablo Escobar, have done their bit to keep the US united. Hatred towards Islamic fundamentalists - and public enemy number one Osama Bin Laden - also keeps Americans appreciative of their president.

Having enemies can also help combat boredom. Rowe was puzzled by one family where all the members were constantly at war with each other until she realised they actually enjoyed it. 'It made their otherwise dull lives more exciting,' she said.

Enemies also have the advantage of being more exciting than friends. 'The enemy is always doing something, or you can always imagine them doing something.' Enemies can also make people feel that they matter. Rowe worked in a psychiatric hospital, where old people knew no one was thinking of them, and found that frightening. They would get enemies, so at least they knew someone was thinking of them. 'Imagine being so insignificant that no one could be bothered to hate you.'

Having a hate-figure can also make us feel better about ourselves. People give their enemies all the characteristics that they have trouble with themselves - whether it's being sadistic, aggressive or manipulative. For example, if you're feeling guilty about having some malicious thoughts, it's comforting to believe Saddam Hussein is the embodiment of pure evil and that we are less cunning than Peter Mandelson.

A good enemy can also help people cope with their failings in life, by simply taking the blame for everything. At work, people often blame the boss.

'You don't have to take responsibility, and it means you can avoid the really complex questions.' This can also dominate a political culture, such as Hitler blaming the Jews for much of Weimar Germany's problems, or unemployed people blaming immigrants. But Rowe thinks that some of the hatred that many people feel for migrants may be even more primitive. 'When our species first appeared on the planet, there were very few of us and we lived in little bands, and the concept of stranger was the same as the concept of enemy,' she said 'Echoes of that are still with us.'

Ultimately, like almost everything in psychology, it seems, it all goes back to childhood. 'The need for enemies is very directly linked to the amount of punishment you had as a child. Most chil dren are hit, or they're made to stay in their room, or spoken to in horrible ways. You need enemies to put your hatred onto,' said Rowe.

Enemies allow adults to simply act out the frustrations of childhood. 'If, as a child, we had a bad relationship with our father, you project your idea of father onto any authority figures, and behave towards them as you would have towards your father, but wouldn't dare.'

But before we all rush out to get an enemy, or upset a few people to acquire a few more, Rowe warns that all the advantages are simply short term. 'If you devote a lot of your energy to hating some one, you don't have the energy to enlarge your life.' When you scapegoat and blame others, you fail to get to grips with the real causes of your problems.

Rowe now sees getting rid of the need for enemies as essential for the future of humanity: 'Having enemies is now a luxury our species can no longer afford. It's led to the degradation of the planet, with industries competing to death. We need to learn to live without enemies to ensure the survival of the planet.'

Friends and Enemies is published tomorrow by HarperCollins, price £19.99

fields.headline: Number of jailed mothers soars
fields.trailText: The number of mothers in the British prison system has reached an all-time high, more than doubling in the past 10 years, an investigation by  The Observer  has revealed.
fields.body:
The number of mothers in the British prison system has reached an all-time high, more than doubling in the past 10 years, an investigation by The Observer has revealed.

The record numbers reflect the growing prison population but also increasing willingness among judges to jail women who are pregnant or have young children. Of 3,524 women being held at the end of last month, two-thirds were mothers and more than 1,000 were pregnant or had children under the age of five. Current estimates suggest 5,500 children have mothers in prison.

According to Frances Crook of the Howard League for Penal Reform, the true figure may be higher because a large number of women hide the fact they are parents from the authorities, fearing their children may be taken away while they serve sentences.

At present there are just 72 places in four prison mother-and-baby units nationwide, and these are restricted to children under 18 months - deemed the age by which they are more aware of their surroundings and thus likely to be psychologically damaged by the prison environment. Two new units are being built and more should follow.

The problem is particularly acute for mothers from the South and West - the nearest unit for mothers from Cornwall is in Cheshire.

Lawyers have suggested that the current practice of splitting jailed mothers from their babies could be challenged from October when the Human Rights Act, which guarantees a right to family life, comes into force.

Earlier this month Martin Narey, director-general of the Prison Service, stunned reformers by announcing that he was considering increasing the total amount of time children could spend with their mothers to four years.

As the majority of mothers in jail are the primary carers of their children, they often emerge homeless, poor and unable to maintain family life. By contrast, male prisoners usually have a partner to keepthe home going. At any one time, some 95,000 children have fathers behind bars.

Nick Flynn of the Prison Reform Trust warned: 'In trying to do the right thing, the prison service is in danger of making things worse. Prison is not a place for children.'

webTitle: Man's ills threaten apes with oblivion

fields.headline: Man's ills threaten apes with oblivion
fields.trailText: In the misty highlands of Rwanda, scientists noted a disturbing outbreak of illness among mountain gorillas. First the animals began coughing and sneezing. Then the animals became sluggish. Finally they wandered into the forest to die.
fields.body:
In the misty highlands of Rwanda, scientists noted a disturbing outbreak of illness among mountain gorillas. First the animals began coughing and sneezing. Then the animals became sluggish. Finally they wandered into the forest to die.

The cause of this epidemic was a mystery until one researcher collected blood and tissue samples and studied them.

His discovery was startling: Rwanda's gorillas appeared to be succumbing to measles, a disease previously only found in humans. Either researchers, or - more probably - tourists, who spend thousands of dollars on trips to pose beside gorillas, were infecting the animals.

By the time this diagnosis was made, six gorillas were dead and 27 dangerously ill.

The scientists faced a crisis. Rwanda is home to the world's last 400 mountain gorillas. Disease could finally drive these creatures to extinction. So the researchers decided to intervene and began administer ing oral vaccines. The epidemic stopped immediately.

The outbreak was assumed to be isolated until a series of recent reports forced researchers to re-appraise the disease danger that humans pose to primates. Many now believe that our ailments are a far more common threat to gorillas, chimps and other apes than previously realised.

Having been persecuted to near extinction by man, our closest biological cousins could soon receive a final blow, not from hunters or farmers, but from bacteria and viruses that cause colds, flu, measles and other human illnesses.

The timing of this discovery, outlined in the current issue of Science , is particularly ironic. On Monday scientists are scheduled to gather in London for a major international conference to debate the exact mechanism by which Aids - currently affecting more than 40 million people - first spread to humans from chimpanzees. Very little has been said about the dangers of diseases that flow in the opposite direction.

'There is no doubt that Aids is a devastating illness that has already killed millions,' said primatologist Professor Robin Dunbar of Liverpool University. 'However, it does not threaten Homo sapiens with extinction. By contrast, illnesses like flu, pneumonia and measles, which we pass on to chimps, gorillas and other apes, threaten to tip some populations into oblivion.

'The problem is that they are so genetically similar to us. We share 98 per cent of their DNA. We should scarcely be surprised that they are vulnerable to our diseases.'

The extent of the problem was outlined in a report in International Journal of Pri matology in which US primatologists Janette Wallis and Rick Lee describe more than a dozen outbreaks of suspected human diseases in wild gorillas, chimpanzees, baboons and monkeys.

Among the ailments they recorded were measles, polio and scabies. Many proved to be fatal and most were confined to already threatened groups of primates.

One outbreak occurred at Tanzania's Gombe Park, where Jane Goodall set up her field centre for studying wild chimpanzees 40 years ago. In 1996 eight animals, including a mother and her infant twin children, died of a respiratory infection, probably pneumonia. Since then there have been several other fatal outbreaks, added former Gombe researcher, Professor Anne Pusey, of Minnesota University. 'The last one was in February when two more chimps died of the same respiratory illness.'

Gombe chimps have also suffered a scabies outbreak which killed three infant apes, while a catastrophic outbreak of polio led to the deaths of several others.

'The trouble is we don't really know how common such microbes are among other chimps and gorillas,' said Pusey. 'The only way we can find out is to study them, and as soon as we do that we run the risk of infecting them ourselves. At present we are restricted to collecting samples of their faeces and the chewed up remains of their food.'

Even if scientists do prove that chimps and gorillas are being infected with human diseases, it is not clear what action could be taken. 'We can't walk away from the few protected areas we have created for chimps and gorillas,' said Dunbar. 'If it wasn't for guarded zones like Gombe there would be virtually no chimps left alive today.'

The alternative - administering vaccines - is equally controversial. Such interventions represent a slippery slope, say many scientists, for they will leave apes increasingly dependent on humans for protection. They will, in effect, no longer be wild animals.

'In any case, it is hard enough to give an ape an oral vaccine,' said Pusey. 'And it would much worse to inject them with one. These are very fierce, wild animals that are every bit as dangerous as lions. They wouldn't take kindly to such actions at all.'

webTitle: Rise in children suffering mental illness

fields.headline: Rise in children suffering mental illness
fields.standfirst: Health services under strain as number of disturbed toddlers rockets,  Jason Burke reports
fields.trailText: Britain has been hit by a huge rise in the number of very young children and adolescents seeking treatment from psychiatrists for serious mental health problems, new research has revealed.
fields.body:
Britain has been hit by a huge rise in the number of very young children and adolescents seeking treatment from psychiatrists for serious mental health problems, new research has revealed.

Of particular concern is a surge in the number of very young children with suspected mental health problems being referred to psychiatrists. They include hundreds less than two years old.

One psychiatrist told The Observer that his clinic was now seeing more than four times as many under-fives than in 1997. Another spoke of six-year-olds who attempted to harm themselves, seven-year-olds with compulsive behaviour problems, and nine-year-olds with suicidal tendencies.

Many psychiatrists have had dozens of toddlers aged one, two and three referred to them for treatment.

The figures, compiled by Young Minds, a leading children's mental health charity, show that in some instances psychiatrists' adolescent caseloads have nearly doubled in the past year alone. The increase has accelerated over the past three years.

Young people are coming to psychiatrists with a huge range of serious mental health problems. They include schizophrenia, anorexia nervosa, attention deficit disorder (ADD) and dozens of other behavioural problems. Many are caused by drug or alcohol abuse.

The research raises fears that Britain's stretched mental health care services will not be able to cope with the huge new demands placed upon them.

'We are reaping the legacy of decades of underfunding of provision for mental healthcare,' said Peter Wilson, director of Young Minds. 'It is a very serious situation and we need radical action quickly.'

Child and adolescent psychiatrists say they feel 'inundated' and 'overwhelmed'.

Dr Kedar Dwivedi, working in Northampton, said that when he started his career 20 years ago he had 200 referrals annually. Now the total was around 1,200.

He said that in 1997 only 13 children aged five or less had been referred to him. Since then the total had gone up 10 times . In the past year, he has seen more than 130 under-fives, including 27 aged three, six two-year-olds and four one-year-olds.

Another psychiatrist in the South-west said that the number of children visiting clinic had gone up by nearly three times in the past five years.

Dr Jonathan Dare, a consultant child and adolescent psychiatrist and director of south London's Maudsley NHS Trust, said he treated four-, five- or six-year-olds who often showed signs of severe emotional deprivation.

Dare said his clinic had treated a nine-year-old boy last year who had threatened to throw himself from a window on several occasions and a six-year-old who had stuck a needle into himself.

Obsessive disorders were commonly seen in seven- or eight-year-olds, Dare said. One nine-year-old changed clothes as often as seven times a day for fear of being dirty.

All the 80 people questioned in the survey, including consultant psychiatrists, paediatricians and social services directors, reported significant increases in their caseloads during the past year.

The sample included nearly a tenth of practising child and adolescent psychologists in England and Wales.

Many point out that the crisis is likely to worsen if radical action is not taken.

'Child mental health problems have an impact on health later as mature adults and thus, as parents, on future generations,' said Dwivedi.

The Young Minds report also highlights a significant lack of staff trained in working with children and adolescents and a lack of facilities to deal with the more serious cases. Far too often, the report says, young people are placed in adult or paediatric wards.

The huge number of referrals, combined with staff shortages, has also led to long waiting lists, the Young Minds report discloses.

Of 24 clinics examined by Young Minds, only 10 were able to meet the government target of three months. In addition, sometimes clinics took up to three weeks to respond to 'life-threatening emergencies' because of the weight of work.

'We should not underestimate the sheer intensity, emotional or otherwise, of dealing with these very complex and distressing cases,' Wilson said. 'The cumulative impact on people working in the field is very severe.'

There is controversy over the exact size of the increase and the reasons for it. Some say that more awareness of children's problems has boosted the figures. There is also fierce debate over whether attention deficit disorder is as widespread as thought. Other factors - such as the closure of some social services facilities - are also thought to have contributed. A larger number of referrals of young people by health visitors would be one more reason for the increased figures for children.

However, a government report last year said that around one in 10 young people suffer from a mental disorder, more than previously thought.

Experts say that a number of initiatives could improve the current situation. Many depend on broad multi-agency approaches involving teachers, community workers and other professionals working together within the community.

A Department of Health spokeswoman said that it recognised there was strong and increasing pressure on children and adolescent mental health services. She said that around £30million was being invested this year in a range of projects designed to tackle the problem.

webTitle: One in four Britons now works nights

fields.headline: One in four Britons now works nights
fields.standfirst: Children being 'passed like batons' between parents forced to work shifts to service the 24-hour society
fields.trailText: Almost a quarter of the British workforce is now forced to work at some point between 6pm and 6am. The price being paid for an American inspired 24-7 society.
fields.body:
Almost a quarter of the British workforce is now forced to work at some point between 6pm and 6am. The price being paid for an American inspired 24-7 society - open 24 hours a day seven days a week - is turning out for millions to be antisocial working hours at little or no extra pay. Fifteen per cent are working all night.

The number of workers on duty during the hours of darkness will be confirmed in a report this week highlighting the potential dangers to children of being 'passed like batons' in a relay race between shift-working parents.

Sixty-one percent of working families now have parents away from home during early mornings, evenings, nights and weekends; 34 per cent have a parent who works at weekends. The numbers are expected to double by 2007.

'It's clear that employers are expecting staff to work whatever hours are needed without seeing these as exceptional circumstances,' said Megan Pacey of the Daycare Trust, which will publish 'Shift Parents' this week. 'There has also been an erosion of premium payments for working outside the old nine-to-five hours so people often receive no extra money for this either.'

Staff are now required to work antisocial hours in a swath of industries far beyond the traditional fields of restaurants and hotels. The decline in 24-hour working expected with the contraction of manufacturing industry has been replaced instead by an explosion in the number of call centres, shops and new-technology businesses operating around the clock.

Tom Ingham, from Dorking in Surrey, who works as an information processor for an accounting firm, said: 'I'm now required to work one week in four through the night. We receive extra pay for doing it but it's highly disruptive to family life.

'My partner is tied down every evening with the kids and I feel shattered. It's difficult enough sleeping in the day anyway, but I am almost always disturbed as well by the children in the house. I also end up drinking a huge amount of coffee which keeps me on edge for hours.'

He added: 'Working these shifts is virtually non-negotiable. Everyone in our department has to do it. You simply wouldn't expect to get promoted or pay reviewed if you didn't.'

The biggest increase in late working in the past five years has come from the retail sector. Thirty-six stores in the 437-strong Sainsbury's chain already open all night on at least one evening a week. In December the number will be increased to 63.

Staff are paid a premium for working on Sundays or if their shift covers the hours between midnight and 2am. However, they receive no extra pay if obliged to work until midnight or to start in the early hours.

'We are now a 24-hour business even if a store is not actually open,' said a spokeswoman for the chain. 'There is rarely a time when there isn't a skeleton staff on duty at the very least.'

Professor Sue Yeandle of Sheffield Hallam University, a leading labour-market expert, said: 'The clear trend towards people working into the evening and overnight will continue. It's certainly true that with a small number of exceptions people are not getting paid a premium.

'Even without overnight working, the development of the entire service sector in late afternoons and into the evening is very disruptive to family life. People in these sectors on relatively modest incomes are simply not able to buy proper childcare to cover these hours on their pay. There are clear risks to children.'

But middle-class families are suffering from 'long hours syndrome' too. Judy Mella, a surgical registrar in Dorset, is a single mother with four children. She is expected to be on call, usually on site, at least one night a week.

'It's part of the job. It means I have to have someone to come in and spend the night at home. It has meant employing an au pair who absorbs a third of my take-home pay.'

ben.summerskill@observer.co.uk

How parents can help

Ages 5-7

Do: Use junk mail to get your children interested in reading.

Play ball games with your children and get them to think about 'the reason a ball moves at different speeds'.

Help your children's maths by getting them to count loose change.

See which bath toys sink and which float, ask the child to think about why.

<st

ges 7-11

Do: Ask your child to add up till receipts after shopping.

Make a polite 'rules poster' about who can and can't go into their bedroom

Ask them them to order a take away, giving them a set budget first.

At the fairground see if your child can identify motors, axles, pulleys, gears and spind

ong>/p>

Teenagers

Do: Help your children with homework and get them to set a timetable.

Take them on trips to historic houses.

Get videos out that relate to school projects.

Don't: Sit your children in front of the TV while you do something else.

Do their homework for them.

Cost of lost sleep

 Not getting enough sleep can lead to you becoming 'borderline retarded'. Falling an hour short of the necessary eight hours can temporarily knock a point of your IQ. Fifteen points can easily be lost in a week if you miss two hours a night.

 The average night's sleep in Britain is now down to seven hours, from nearly nine in the early part of the last century. Many people survive on less than six hours a night.

 Ten per cent of us have fallen asleep while driving - causing a quarter of all fatal road accidents. In a survey, 70 per cent of train drivers admitted having nodded off at the controls.

 In 1963 American schoolboy Randy Gardner stayed awake for 264 hours - a full 11 days - and had periods of lucidity until the end. He still holds the world record for staying awake.

webTitle: DNA set to break the silence of towns shielding killers

fields.headline: DNA set to break the silence of towns shielding killers
fields.standfirst: It's five years since Robert Higgins was murdered. Now his family hope hi-tech tests will end their nightmare and bring his killer to justice
fields.trailText: It's five years since Robert Higgins was murdered. Now his family hope hi-tech tests will end their nightmare and bring his killer to justice
fields.body:
The bottle of champagne has been tucked away in Brenda Walker's cupboard for too long, a sad, dusty symbol of celebration suspended. Walker does not even like champagne, but for five years she has dreamt of the day she gets to pop the cork. That will be when her brother's killers are caught, and she finally learns why the shy, gentle factory worker's life ended violently.

The special occasion may be long overdue, but now there is fresh hope that the champagne will not lie undisturbed forever. Detectives reviewing the stabbing of Robert Higgins are investigating new clues which they believe could lead to those responsible for one of Scotland's most baffling murders.

The body of Higgins, 35, was dumped in an abandoned quarry on 1 May 1995 near the home he shared with his elderly mother in Dalmeny, West Lothian. Police believed his killers were local, and would be unable to hide for long among the small, tightly knit communities near the Forth road and rail bridges.

But the residents of Dalmeny, Queensferry and Kirkliston, horrified though they were by the crime, offered up few clues. Despite thousands of hours of investigation by scores of detectives, police have been unable to uncover even a motive for the killing.

The spot where the body was found is so secluded it is unlikely that an outsider would have known of it. Although Higgins had not been home for three nights, people who saw him over that weekend say he looked relaxed and tidy. Yet nobody has revealed where he spent those nights. He was last seen with a couple. Yet nobody has identified them.

'Somebody here must know who did this to Robert, even if they weren't directly involved,' Walker, 38, told The Observer. 'But for five years they have kept quiet.'

Now, however, detectives are convinced they are close to unravelling the mystery. Tests using new DNA technology to re-examine old evidence should soon identify the killers, officers believe.

The tests have already established that tiny traces of blood found at the scene came not from Higgins but from a woman. He was last seen with the couple in South Queensferry about 11am on the day before the body was found. One of the two stab wounds on his body had less force behind it than the other, suggesting that the blow was delivered by a woman.

A saliva sample taken from a cigarette butt found at the scene is being analysed, and detectives hope that results of both tests will match a criminal already on the national DNA database. Officers will also be able to compare the results against samples taken from suspects.

There are other clues which police now believe point to male and female assailants. One of the many strange aspects of the case was the arrangement of Higgins' clothes at the scene. While some garments had been tossed into bushes and trees, others had been folded neatly and placed on the ground. A report by criminal psychologists prepared as part of the review says this, too, points to the involvement of both a man and a woman.

One theory is that one of the killers coerced the other, who kept quiet out of fear. If the relationship has changed, one of them may now be willing to speak. The psychologists, Gerry Rooney and Suzanne O'Rourke, of Carstairs Secure State Hospital near Lanark, told the police that a new relationship with a woman might account for a dramatic change in Higgins' behaviour on the weekend of his murder. Until then, his habits were unchanging. During the week he worked in a chicken factory. At weekends, he would take his wages out of the bank and drink in the same pubs until his money ran out. He would then return to his mother's home. Only rarely did he stay away overnight, and he always let her know.

But that weekend Higgins abandoned his routine.

He took only £80 from his bank for the weekend - a fraction of the amount he usually spent on drink - and did not appear in his usual pubs. Nor did he contact his family to tell them what he was doing or where he was staying.

There were sporadic sightings of him over the weekend, and all the witnesses say he showed no signs of being in trouble. Instead, his clothes appeared to have been washed and his face was clean shaven.

Rooney and O'Rourke suggested that Higgins may have changed his behaviour because he had met a woman.

'As a starting point, we operate on the premise that everybody's behaviour is predictable, and if that behaviour changes it is because something has happened to make it unpredictable,' the psychologists wrote.

'Sex, or the possibility of sex, can be a very powerful motivator.'

The landlord of one of Higgins' regular drinking dens has told the victim's family that on the Thursday night before his death, Higgins told him that he was going to bring his girlfriend in the following week.

The family are convinced that if he had been going to meet a woman, the shy Robert would not have told anybody for fear of ridicule.

The victim's other sister, Catherine Pearson, said: 'He was such a gentle man. He couldn't fight even if he wanted to. So I know he would have been terrified that night. He would have been curled up screaming for his life.'

Police are now hoping that their fresh pressure will force the communities to yield up their secret at last.

'Whoever did this is probably thinking they have got away with it,' said Detective Chief Superintendent Ian Cowden, who is overseeing the case review. 'We have not gone away and we are not going to go away until we have caught the killers. If you keep shaking the tree, something will eventually fall out.'
