webTitle: Schröder and Blair team up in transfer fees row

fields.headline: Schröder and Blair team up in transfer fees row
fields.trailText: Their countries are sworn enemies on the football pitch, they both aspire to be 'the leader of Europe' and they argue about the benefits of the euro.
fields.body:
Their countries are sworn enemies on the football pitch, they both aspire to be 'the leader of Europe' and they argue about the benefits of the euro. But Tony Blair and his German counterpart, Gerhard Schröder, yesterday agreed on one thing: that scrapping multi-million pound transfer fees for big-name footballers would be disastrous for the people's game.

In a joint offensive against the European Commission's controversial plan to abolish transfer fees for players switching clubs, the British and German Prime Ministers warned that the scheme could severely damage the game.

The two leaders acknowledged that the current system 'is not perfect', but added: 'We fear, however, that a radical reform could have a negative impact on the structures of football in Europe. We share concerns that many smaller professional clubs would struggle to survive.'

The EC has declared that the existing transfer system, under which stars have switch clubs for as much as £37 million, is illegal because it breaks European law on freedom of movement. It has given football until the end of October to come up with an alternative way of handling players' movements.

Football has condemned the EC's move as disastrous. It warns that without the 'trickle-down' effect of transfer fees from selling players to big clubs, scores of lower division sides in Britain could disappear.

The Professional Footballers Association has warned that 'clubs will become like Euston station', with players staying only for a few months, that players' wages will spiral as high as £250,000-a-week and that fans will find it harder to identify with their local team.

'Professional football has a proud history in both our countries', said Blair and Schröder in a joint statement released by Downing Street. 'All our clubs are deeply rooted in the life of their towns and cities and provide a rich source of civic pride. Football fans are enthusiastic about their sport and feel a close loyalty to their clubs. We want it to stay this way.'

Blair and Schröder backed football's concern that the plan could discourage clubs from investing in development, saying: 'The clubs must be able to rely on a system that gives them sufficient opportunity to train young players, build up their teams and keep the game healthy at all levels.'

A spokesman for the Cental Council of Physical Recreation, which represents sports such as rugby, cricket and soccer, said: 'This complicated legal and political issue affects other sports, not just football. But without the EC recognising sport as a special case, any agreement with the football authorities could still be open to legal challenge. Sport should not be treated as just a normal business'.

The Football Association said the two leaders' support was 'hugely pleasing'. On Tuesday a new six-man Transfer Task Force of football representatives will meet at Uefa headquarters in Switzerland to start drawing up detailed plans for an alternative to the current system.

The Football Association said the two leaders' support was 'hugely pleasing'. On Tuesday a new six-man Transfer Task Force of football representatives will meet at Uefa headquarters in Switzerland to start drawing up detailed plans for an alternative to the current system. denis.campbell@observer.co.uk

webTitle: It's not junk mail, it's the latest teaching aid

fields.headline: It's not junk mail, it's the latest teaching aid
fields.trailText: Parents are to be told to use junk mail to help their children's reading and tell their offspring to track their favourite football teams or pop groups around the world to improve their grasp of geography.
fields.body:
Parents are to be told to use junk mail to help their children's reading and tell their offspring to track their favourite football teams or pop groups around the world to improve their grasp of geography.

In the first-ever guides to the National Curriculum, the Government is to announce a series of 'top tips' for parents who want to make sure their children get the best education possible.

The 80-page guides, which cover children's education from the age of three until they leave school, will have advice on everything from when to start teaching cooking, which colour pens to use when highlighting passages in books to the types of ball games to play with older pupils to make sure they stay fit. They will also detail ways of stopping children watching too much of the wrong type of television. Parents should switch on current affairs programmes or buy wildlife videos, the guides will say.

Officials said they wanted to clear up confusion over what is taught at school. Parents often do not know how to respond when their child comes home and, when asked what they did at school, answers 'nothing much'.

They are often also at a loss to know how to help their children at home.

It is first time the Government has given parents a guide to what they should expect from school on a precise, year-by-year basis. Stung by accusations that earlier advice on healthy eating which tells people how many vegetables to eat smacks of the nanny state, the parents' guides will make it clear that they are only advisory and are not orders.

The Prime Minister is so keen on the idea that he will front the launch of the guides, along with Education Secretary David Blunkett.

'Most parents want to support their children's education and want to know what teachers are teaching them in school,' an official at the Department for Education said. 'For too long education was a bit of a secret garden from which parents felt excluded.

'They now have better information on performance tables and Ofsted reports [on school standards] but the day to day curriculum still remains a mystery to them. Children often come home and say they did nothing at school. The package we are talking about puts parents better into the picture.'

The tips start from the age of five, when parents are told to get children to 'write your shopping lists or phone messages'.

The guides will say that junk mail can be put to good use. 'Pick out leaflets with large, bright lettering and get your child to find smaller words in the bigger ones. For example they can find the word "live" in "delivery" and "off" in "offer".'

Although Government sources said that they were braced for accusations that they were trying to tell parents what to do, they said that there was a huge demand from parents for more information.

By the age of seven the guides say that parents should use cookbooks to help their children with their English. They also suggest making children set videos manually rather than with an automatic programming system which will help them 'think through their maths'.

'Get your child to do some skim reading to save you time. Cookbooks usually say how long it takes to prepare recipes. Get your child to go through the book and use a green highlighter pen to colour the first line of all recipes that take 45 minutes or under to prepare. Then highlight all the recipes that take 45-75 minutes in orange.'

The guides say that a map of the world can be used to chart the movements of children's favourite groups or football clubs.

By the age of 13, the guides admit that school can seem boring for children. They suggest taking them on trips to historic houses, visits to the theatre to see performances linked with their English work or renting videos connected with school projects.

They also suggest helping children with projects such as 'gluing together a model plane or fixing a shelf'.

By the time children take GCSEs much of the work might be difficult to understand for some parents. Then roles should then be reversed, the guides say, with the parent eagerly becoming the pupil. 'If your child can teach you, they really know and understand it.'

Teaching unions welcomed the plans last night. 'They will make a major contribution to parents' understanding of what is going on in school,' said David Hart of the National Association of Head Teachers.

webTitle: Music but no maestro please, say orchestras

fields.headline: Music but no maestro please, say orchestras
fields.trailText: They are the ones who take the bows, get the applause and wave their arms around. But more and more musicians and cash-strapped orchestras are now asking - what do conductors actually do?
fields.body:
They are the ones who take the bows, get the applause and wave their arms around. But more and more musicians and cash-strapped orchestras are now asking - what do conductors actually do?

One answer is that they eat up budgets. A big-name conductor can demand a retainer of around £600,000 a year to stay with a major orchestra and he - at this level they are all men - may often work with more than one 'band' at a time. Lucrative recording contracts and additional one-off concert deals mean their income is many times higher than those of the hundred or so people who play for them. A musician in one of London's five major orchestras could expect to earn between £25,000 and £30,000 a year.

Now, as Sir Andrew Davis recovers today from conducting his final Last Night of the Proms, a new, rebellious movement is surging through British orchestras.

An acclaimed small London orchestra that plays without a conductor is about to launch a new season of Mozart concerts, while next week the London Philharmonic Orchestra will be introducing a series of 'democratising' elements to its performances.

Audience members will have a hand in choosing the programme of music for some of their concerts and on certain nights a young per son will be invited from the audience to take the conductor's place.

The Audience Request initiative has been developed from a pilot scheme tried last year at the LPO's home, the Royal Festival Hall. Ticket-holders will vote for one of two pieces of music. They will discover the outcome when they take their seats.

The use of an inexperienced substitute conductor for the first of the LPO's regular family, or FUNharmonics, concerts next month has apparently been endorsed by the evening's conductor, David Angus, who will give the newcomer a short tutorial before handing over.

The move to shake up the hierarchy of the concert hall reflects continued concern about the stuffy image of live classical music and the tyranny of the maestro with 'the stick'. Diana Ambache, a pianist who runs the pioneering Ambache orchestra, believes musicians can be creatively stifled by a succession of conductors.

'Many say that while it is a frightening experience, it is much more fulfilling to play without a conductor,' she told The Observer.

The Ambache's oboe player, Jeremy Polmear, is one of several members who welcome conductorless play.

'When there is no conductor, I am forced to listen to everybody in order to participate properly,' he said. 'The effect is that I take a much more holistic view of the music we are playing and the people I am playing with - and it's much more fun.'

The LPO has appointed Kurt Masur as principal conductor. The German maestro, 73, who also works with the New York Philharmonic, has said he approves of being challenged but does not think conductors are dispensable. Their job, he says, is to inject 'meaning' and 'spirituality' into a performance.

LPO web site: www.lpo.org.uk. Kurt Masur will talk live online to launch the LPO's website from 7.30pm on 13 September, www.ambache.co.uk.

webTitle: Captive climbers had to kill to survive

fields.headline: Captive climbers had to kill to survive
fields.trailText: The climbers were faced with a stark choice. Having risked their lives on some of the most challenging mountains in the world, where only their skill and courage had kept them going, the four-strong American group seized by kidnappers during an expedition in a remote part of former Soviet-controlled Asia contemplated the ultimate dilemma: kill their guard or face being killed themselves.
fields.body:
The climbers were faced with a stark choice. Having risked their lives on some of the most challenging mountains in the world, where only their skill and courage had kept them going, the four-strong American group seized by kidnappers during an expedition in a remote part of former Soviet-controlled Asia contemplated the ultimate dilemma: kill their guard or face being killed themselves.

In an epic real-life adventure story that has prompted a frenzied bidding war between Hollywood film studios and New York publishers, the real story of the mountaineers and the guard they pushed off a cliff to certain death is only now beginning to emerge.

The expedition had begun well enough. When Jason 'Singer' Smith, 22, and his friends set off to climb in the Pamir mountains in Kyrgyzstan they thought they knew what they were getting into. The Karavashin region, 10,000ft up in the mountains, has become a Mecca for adventurous mountaineers and the four Americans planned to grab their own share of climbing glory by conquering a number of new climbs.

The drama that engulfed the young team began while Smith and his three companions were bivouacking hundreds of feet up a vertical rock face. After days of climbing, they planned to spend their first night on a cramped platform they had carried up with them, an aluminium-framed 'portaledge' - a campsite hanging in the sky.

Hanging from ropes far above the ground, they slotted together the alloy poles, discussed the next day's route up the unclimbed face and looked forward to a simple dinner and an unnerving night's rest above the black void. With Smith were John Dickey, at 25 the oldest member of the group, and two Californians, Tommy Caldwell, 22, and Beth Rodden, 20, at 5ft and six stone, a tiny but brilliant woman who had quickly become one of world's most famous female climbers.

The expedition had been sold as a big deal in the lucrative world of US outdoor marketing. It had been backed by the leading outdoor designer label The North Face, and Dickey and Smith were there to photograph the two 'stars' of the climb, Caldwell and Rodden, as they inched up the face. Rodden was a recent recruit to The North Face. For all of them, a lot was riding on a successful climb.

What happened next turned their adventure into a nightmare. As they rested on cramped ledges, they were startled by the sound of guns being fired in their direction from the valley below. They were sitting targets in the middle of a blank granite wall high above the ground, and any thought of ignoring the shooting and continuing to the summit disappeared when bullets started hitting the rock around them.

Terrified, the team agreed that one of them should abseil down to negotiate with the gunmen, and it was Dickey who was elected to do the talking. According to friends who spoke to The Observer last week, he abseiled down to the foot of the cliff where he was immediately surrounded by three armed Uzbeks, members of the Islamic Movement of Uzbekistan, which is fighting for the creation of an independent Muslim state where the borders of Kyrgyzstan, Uzbekistan and Tajikistan converge. The group regularly kidnaps westerners and has plunged the area into political chaos.

Confronted by the gunmen, Dickey knew they were in deep trouble. Their base camp was in ruins and the Uzbeks, with barely any English, were in no mood to negotiate. The kidnappers had already destroyed most of their tents and spare equipment and Dickey quickly complied with the gunmen's hand-signalled orders, telling his friends over their radio to descend to the certainty of captivity and the possibility that they would die.

According to friends, the gunmen ordered the four to gather what food they could and go with them. Grabbing a few energy bars, the climbers endured a six-day ordeal, being moved at night by two of the guerrillas and being forced to hide during the day under brush or rocks from the view of Kyrgyz army helicopters. If they did not understand the risks of non-compliance, it was made abundantly clear five hours into their captivity. To their horror, a Kyrgyz soldier whom the guerrillas had kidnapped earlier was taken away and shot.

Smith was forced to sit on the body for 40 minutes before the group continued. Continuously hungry, forced to drink foul water from puddles and in constant fear for their lives, the four stumbled by night under the watchful gaze of their captors and froze during the day, unable to move in their shadowy hideouts. 'I thought about everything,' Caldwell said afterwards, 'I thought about the meaning of life, what these people were after.'

On the sixth day, one of their guards returned to base to collect fresh batteries for the radios taken from the climbers. The hostages found themselves on top of a high granite cliff with one man watching over them. It was then that they hatched their escape plan.

No one knows who acted first and the climbers are not saying - yet. But at a press conference in her hometown of Davis, California, Rodden gave the briefest outline of what happened: 'While moving at night and guarded by only one rebel, we at last saw a chance to escape by pushing our guard off the cliff. It is so hard to think of that now, but we were afraid we would not survive.'

The tight-knit climbing community in the US has speculated that it was the charismatic Smith, a natural leader, who would have had the courage to rush an armed man, but friends of the climbers told The Observer that all four had acted together to push the Uzbek over the edge. After the guard fell to what the climbers assume was certain death, the four immediately started running 'like Forrest Gump', as Smith described it to his mother, covering 18 miles to a Kyrgyz army outpost.

But their ordeal was not yet over. As they approached the post they were shot at again, this time by Kyrgyz troops mistaking them for guerrillas. Caldwell, Dickey and Rodden dived for cover behind rocks but Smith kept running, finding himself surrounded by soldiers. He shouted: 'We're Americans! We're Americans!'

'You'd never believe how good tinned sardines can taste,' Caldwell said of their first meal in almost a week. They were given army fatigues and were met at Batken by the Kyrgyz president, Askar Akayev, who flew the four climbers to Bishkek in his personal jet before they were transferred to the US Embassy.

Since returning to the US at the end of August the four have been besieged by American and foreign media eager to buy up their story. After signing an exclusive contract with Outside magazine, the team have been auctioning a book about their adventure and several studios are bidding for the film rights. Smith is also believed to have given an interview to Playboy magazine.

Not all of the interest has been friendly. Rejecting criticism that the climbers had been foolhardy in going to such a politically unstable area in the first place, Rodden's father told reporters that she was 'doing remarkably well under the circumstances'. He said advice found by the team on the internet suggested that the risk was minimal. The US State Department, however, has been warning Americans to stay away from the region for more than a year.

fields.headline: World in brief
fields.trailText: Haider hits out
fields.body:
Haider hits out

Austrian far-right leader Joerg Haider lashed out at the leaders of France and Germany yesterday after a report by three EU 'wise men' called for sanctions against the Austrian government to be lifted.

Haider said yesterday that the report represented a 'debacle' and a 'Waterloo' for French President Jacques Chirac, one of the far-right Austrian coalition's fiercest critics.

Stambolic 'in jail'

An anonymous caller has told the wife of former Serbian President Ivan Stambolic, who vanished two weeks ago, that he is in Belgrade's central prison, the family's lawyer said yesterday.

Lawyer Nikola Barovic said that police had claimed to know nothing about the whereabouts of Stambolic, a former friend of Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic who had stepped up his criticism of Milosevic before elections later this month.

Airman arrested

A US airman stationed in Japan turned himself in to police yesterday after an early morning hit-and-run incident that killed a 72-year-old Japanese woman.

Police in Tachikawa, a western suburb of Tokyo, identified the airman as Jon M Mills, a 24-year-old enlisted man stationed at Yokota Air Base. Mills was arrested him on charges of professional negligence resulting in death.

Monk's Mercs

The Thai government is to investigate a Buddhist monk to determine whether his collection of 60 Mercedes cars violates his religion's anti-materialist precepts. Phra Khru Viboon Pattanakit, abbot of the Sisakrabua temple in Bangkok, claims he wants to set up a museum featuring the vehicles. Phra Khru Viboon said he received the cars as donations from his followers or bought them with cash given by his devotees.

webTitle: Air crashes blamed on military pulses

fields.headline: Air crashes blamed on military pulses
fields.trailText: Electromagnetic pulses from military craft may have been responsible for several civilian airline disasters in the past four years. If the theory is proved correct, it suggests navy ships and air force planes pose a lethal threat to passenger flights.
fields.body:
Electromagnetic pulses from military craft may have been responsible for several civilian airline disasters in the past four years. If the theory is proved correct, it suggests navy ships and air force planes pose a lethal threat to passenger flights.

Crash investigators have been startled by similarities between several tragedies. In particular, they have uncovered common features in two crashes: Swissair 111, on 2 September 1998, and TWA 800, on 17 July 1996. Both planes took off from the same airport, New York's JFK, on the same day, a Wednesday, at the same minute, 8.19pm. Both followed the same route over Long Island. Both reported trouble in the same region of airspace, and both suffered catastrophic electrical malfunctions. fields.headline: US reels at car giants' 'betrayal'
fields.standfirst: The reputations of Ford and Firestone have been shattered after 88 people died in a series of accidents. As a small-town lawyer takes on the firms, the public is turning against them, writes  Ed Helmore in New York
fields.trailText: This is a story that goes back a century - to the dawn of American motoring and a relationship at the heart of America's first industrial boom. Then a car maker named Henry Ford turned to another Henry, a man named Firestone, to make tyres for   his Model T, laying the foundations for two of America's biggest companies.
fields.body:
This is a story that goes back a century - to the dawn of American motoring and a relationship at the heart of America's first industrial boom. Then a car maker named Henry Ford turned to another Henry, a man named Firestone, to make tyres for his Model T, laying the foundations for two of America's biggest companies.

That historic partnership is now on the rocks, torn apart by one of America's biggest corporate scandals. It has seen Ford's most popular and profitable car in the US, the Explorer, and the oversize Firestone tyres that carry it, implicated in a series of accidents that have killed more than 80 people and injured hundreds more.

To a disbelieving and increasingly angry American public, it is a story of deliberate duplicity in which their lives have been endangered. As the Ford-Firestone fiasco continues to build it has conformed to a classic American myth: the little man - a small-town Texan lawyer - pitted against the arrogance of big business, and winning.

It may, however, be a very long haul and years before the full story of who knew what and when is finally revealed, as all sides deny culpability. For whatever or whoever is ultimately to blame - Firestone's ATX tyres, the design of the Explorer, or a deadly combination of the two - the official number of people who have died after tyres on the sport utility vehicle have shredded, causing the vehicle to roll over, now stands at 88, with injuries at 250. And the numbers may be far higher. More than 6.5 million tyres have been recalled, 47m more are suspect, executives have been hauled before Congress to explain.

The crisis is not limited to the US. On Friday the French government approved the recall of all Firestone ATX tyres, citing concern over the deaths in America and in Venezuela where fatal accidents have been reported.

It is clear that American consumers, and those in 15 other countries, have been misinformed or misled. Moreover, both companies have made serious mistakes in handling the crisis.

Americans by the hundreds of thousands have put themselves on waiting lists for replacement tyres, and garages have had to field countless calls from drivers worried about the tiniest shred on their tread. As the Justice Department mulled over a formal investigation last week it was clear that the crisis would not go away.

The problems only came to light through the efforts of Randy Roberts, a lawyer from East Texas, who took up the case of Jessica LeAnn Taylor, a high school cheerleader who died in a car accident in October 1998. A friend of Taylor's mother was driving when the tread of her Explorer's Firestones allegedly peeled off like a banana skin and the vehicle rolled over. Roberts sued Firestone; the company claimed it knew of only one other similar incident.

In November last year, a judge ordered Firestone to turn over all complaints and lawsuits. According to Roberts, there had been more than 1,100 incidents and 57 lawsuits by February this year.

Last weekend a 10-year-old boy was killed when the driver of a Firestone-equipped Explorer lost control of the vehicle and it flipped off an interstate near Laredo, Texas. Authorities said at least one of the tyres was shredded.

Whatever the cause of the tragedy, Ford and Firestone are guilty as charged in the court of public opinion. 'They've known something was wrong for years,' said Lori Lazarus, a 31-year-old schoolteacher whose Explorer flipped after a Firestone tyre shredded on a Florida highway in 1996. Lazarus survived but still suffers from headaches and balance problems and is suing both companies.

For Ford the issue is doubly disastrous. The Explorer has been the goose that lays the golden egg, providing a quarter of its profits. Ford's chief executive, Jacques Nasser, looking sombre and earnest, appears in ads to reassure customers by pledging to work 'around the clock' to resolve the crisis. For Firestone, the outcome is potentially more dire. Ford accounts for 32 per cent of the company's orders and analysts warn that it will probably fold if future contracts are not awarded, as seems increasingly likely.

At congressional hearings into the controversy last week, the chief executive of Firestone, Masatoshi Ono, said: 'I come before you to apologise to you, the American people - especially the families who have lost loved ones in these terrible rollover accidents.' Nasser testified that the company did not take action because a review of various databases assured the form - wrongly, as it turned out - that there was not a problem.

But evidence is mounting that the companies had known about separating tyre-tread problems for years. Lawsuits against the firms relating to the tyres on the Explorer date back to 1991 and documents show that Firestone began reimbursing consumers for faulty tyres as far back as 1989.

Moreover, it appears that the companies knew about the problems in 1998 when they began replacing the tyres on Explorers in Saudi Arabia, Asia and South America. But it failed to reveal the recall to US regulators until May this year. In Venezuela, where the Ford replaced faulty Firestones a month before the US recall, regulators have accused Ford and Firestone of conspiracy after 46 died in Firestone-equipped Explorers.

Ford maintains its vehicle is sound and only Firestone's tyres are defective. Firestone, a division of Japan's Bridgestone Corp, counters that a factor beyond its control - namely a lower tyre pressure recommended by the auto giant - is to blame. Without admitting liability, both companies now acknowledge they might have appreciated the magnitude of the problem earlier.

Whatever the truth, warning signs that the Explorer-Firestone combination was a danger were easily missed - or obscured.

'Ford and Firestone had at a minimum a moral obligation to make sure that the products they sell are safe,' said Senator Richard C. Shelby. 'And yet they both failed to bring this issue to consumers' and the federal government's attention, at the cost of dozens of lives.'

If Ford and Firestone knew of problems and did nothing, federal regulators could impose up to $925,000 in fines. The companies could also face criminal charges. The biggest potential damage is that the image of the companies will become so tarnished that customers avoid their products.

Both say their August sales showed little effect from the recall but some independent dealers say customers are now avoiding Firestone tyres.

Many safety experts believe that long after tempers have cooled it will be discovered that no single factor is to blame for the crashes. 'You've got a vehicle on the margin of stability and a tyre on the margins,' says accident investigator Dick Baumgardner. 'Put them together and you've got a disaster.'

fields.headline: City Life - Tokyo
fields.trailText: They don't tell "fly in my soup" jokes in Japan. Instead it is the stuff of headlines following a rash of bizarre food scares that have highlighted a national obsession with cleanliness. 'Lizard lurked in tin of baby sweetcorn!' screamed one front page. 'Weird objects swarming out of creepy foodstuffs,' warned another. Even serious broadsheets have carried stories about a fly in a boxed lunch, a bee in a bun and a metal bolt in a tin of spaghetti sauce.
fields.body:
They don't tell "fly in my soup" jokes in Japan. Instead it is the stuff of headlines following a rash of bizarre food scares that have highlighted a national obsession with cleanliness. 'Lizard lurked in tin of baby sweetcorn!' screamed one front page. 'Weird objects swarming out of creepy foodstuffs,' warned another. Even serious broadsheets have carried stories about a fly in a boxed lunch, a bee in a bun and a metal bolt in a tin of spaghetti sauce.

Now deep bows of apology by contrite presidents of food companies have become a regular sight on television news shows. Hundreds of thousands of products, ranging from cheese and crisps to isotonic drinks and caramel puddings, have been recalled because a handful of consumers complained of tasting 'something funny' or discovered an insect, button or hair inside the pack. The total cost of these recalls has yet to be calculated, but it is expected to run into several billion yen.

Such an overreaction seems ridiculous - even to most Japanese - but the sudden appetite for stories about alien sightings in supermarket goods cannot just be dismissed as silly season flimflam.

Very real concerns about corporate hygiene standards emerged in late June when about 15,000 consumers were struck down with vomiting and diarrhoea after drinking milk products made by Japan's leading dairy company, Snow Brand. As well as being the biggest outbreak of food-poisoning in living memory, the public were shocked at the company's ham-fisted and duplicitous response.

When the first few illnesses were reported, a Snow Brand executive dismissed the severity of the problem with the unforgettable explanation that: 'It is well known that 20 per cent of Asians get loose bowels after drinking milk.' It later emerged the jelly belly might have had more to do with the fact that the company reused out-of-date milk, mixed products by hand under the midday sun and failed to recognise the threat posed by loss of power at a refrigeration unit.

'When I was a kid, my father always told me that Snow Brand milk was the safest, so I feel completely betrayed,' said Yoko Yamada, a mother of two living just outside of Tokyo. 'If we can't trust them, then who can we trust?'

Japanese consumers are among the most hygiene and safety-conscious in the world. Perhaps because of a hot and humid summer climate that necessitates an almost constant battle against mould and bacteria, cleanliness is not only next to godliness (purification is a key element in many Buddhist and Shinto rituals), it is also seen as physically attractive (the Japanese use the same word for 'beautiful' and 'clean').

A huge market has sprung up for germ-resistant goods, from cutting boards and cling film to bed linen and steering wheels. Supermarkets also sell a bewildering range of anti-bacterial wipes for everything from toilet seats to train handles.

Snow Brand's crime is, thus, unforgiveable, but it is hard not to feel sorry for the other food companies forced to carry out massive recalls and to run full-page newspaper apologies in deference to public hypersensitivity. The discovery of a single fly was enough to force Kirin Beverage to withdraw 600,000 cans of tomato juice. Two flies in a box lunch forced West Japan Railway Food Service to shut down a factory for a month.

Some commentators welcome this as a sign that the long-suffering Japanese consumer worm has finally turned, but shoppers themselves are beginning to wonder whether things have got out of hand.

webTitle: Millions fear killer dust clouds from dried-up sea

fields.headline: Millions fear killer dust clouds from dried-up sea
fields.standfirst: Aral Sea: Choking dust kills
fields.trailText: The people of Karakalpakstan have come to fear the dust storms that sweep across this region, whipping up grit from the sandy basin of the dried up Aral Sea and depositing it in a fine layer over their homes. For a few moments the day is darkened, the sky turns grey and suddenly the choking dust is everywhere - scratching at at eyes, grazing throats.
fields.body:
The people of Karakalpakstan have come to fear the dust storms that sweep across this region, whipping up grit from the sandy basin of the dried up Aral Sea and depositing it in a fine layer over their homes. For a few moments the day is darkened, the sky turns grey and suddenly the choking dust is everywhere - scratching at at eyes, grazing throats.

Over the past few years these heavy, gusting clouds of grime have become more frequent; scientists recently named the area the dustiest place on earth. But at the root of locals' fears is not the quantity of dust, but the highly poisonous toxins it contains and the sickness and disease it brings.

Most people here believe that the dust is the main cause of the dire health problems: epidemic levels of tuberculosis, debilitating respiratory illnesses, widespread kidney problems, high infant mortality, rampant anaemia and painful intestinal ailments.

It is more than 10 years since the world first began to learn about the crisis in the Aral Sea - described by the United Nations as 'the most staggering disaster of the twentieth century' - but scientists still have no more than a partial understanding of the damage inflicted on the five million people who live near the shrivelled shores of what was once the world's fourth largest lake.

In 1959, keen to boost cotton production in the dry plains of central Asia, bureaucrats in Moscow conceived a brutally ambitious scheme to irrigate huge swathes of desert land and transform them into lush plantations. A network of unlined canals was built, water from the Aral Sea's two tributaries was diverted to the cotton fields and powerful pesticides were pumped liberally into the system. Twenty years later the region was producing nine million tonnes of cotton a year, but locals had noticed with alarm that the sea was shrinking.

With only a trickle of water coming in, the sea retreated rapidly, and what remained of it became saltier and poisonous, killing most of its fish and much of the wildlife on its shores. As the sea shrank to half its former size, a sandy area about as big as the Netherlands was exposed, baking and cracking in the sun.

'When I was a child I used to swim in the sea. Now it isn't there. It's like a fairytale in reverse,' said Almagun Matnazarova, a former schoolteacher from the onetime port town of Muynak, who scratches out a living selling socks and vests at a stall in the bazaar. At the town's outskirts, the deserted beaches where she used to play now edge on to the cracked scrubland that is the former seabed. Rusting trawlers are marooned in the sand. The coast is almost 100 miles away.

After the collapse of the Soviet Union, international aid agencies hurried to the region - now divided between Uzbekistan and Kazakhstan - but almost all of them focused on the environmental fall-out from the catastrophe: the collapse of the eco-system, the damage to local flora and fauna, the effect on the region's environment.

Just as they had been ignored by the Soviet planners of the 1950s, the people were largely forgotten about by environmental workers. It is only now, with concern mounting over the fate of those left stranded by the desiccated seabed, that serious research into the health impact of the worst man-made environmental disaster is beginning.

Joost van der Meyer, a research director with Médecins Sans Fron tières, which is championing the need for a greater focus on the people of the region, said: 'The health and social consequences of the disaster remain a blank spot on everybody's map. It was seen primarily as an environmental issue so no one bothered looking at the people. The impact on the local population is still not well known.'

His researchers have started to study the dust to establish whether it really is one of the causes of the widespread ill-health. Every year, the wind is estimated to whip up some 150,000 tonnes of particles which were shown to contain a variety of organophosphates and organo-chlorines, old-fashioned pesticides long-since discarded on safety grounds. These pesticides have been detected in the milk of breast-feeding women in the area and are believed to slow down children's mental development.

Half of the children who die in the Karalpakstan area of Uzbekistan (the region which surrounds the former coastline) are killed by respiratory diseases - asthma, chronic bronchitis, pneumonia - an extraordinarily high ratio, probably increased by the irritating effect of the dust.

Over the 30 years in her job, Ibadullayeva Sarakdin, head of the children's ward in Muynak hospital, has witnessed the children's increasing breathing problems. 'About 60 per cent of them suffer from some kind of bronchial problem. Often we don't have the medicine to treat them.' Most of the deaths are caused by late hospitalisation. Parents are often reluctant to bring their children in until they are critically ill. 'Although the treatment is free, they have to pay for the food here - many can't afford to,' she said wearily.

Drinking water at least four times saltier than that in the West is also causing an array of complaints from kidney disease to heart problems.

But the gravest threat to health is posed by the total collapse of the economy and the ensuing chronic poverty. Muynak once had a profitable fish canning industry as well as a thriving tourist business. Now it has bankrupt fish processing plants, bankrupt hotels and bankrupt building companies. Even the local cinema has closed.

Unemployment is high and few can afford to feed themselves properly. The explosion of TB cases is caused by this poverty, as is the anaemia which affects more than 70 per cent of women, and around 99 per cent of pregnant women, draining their energy and precipitating complications at birth.

A drought this summer has wiped out almost all of the region's crops and the UN last week warned that famine could follow.

The future for the people of the Aral Sea looks bleak.

A drought this summer has wiped out almost all of the region's crops and the UN last week warned that famine could follow. The future for the people of the Aral Sea looks bleak.

webTitle: Football's importance to  the television industry

fields.headline: Lure of the Euro cups
fields.trailText: Football's importance to the television industry was never better illustrated than by the fact that five different companies will be involved in screening the six European ties featuring English clubs this week.
fields.body:
Football's importance to the television industry was never better illustrated than by the fact that five different companies will be involved in screening the six European ties featuring English clubs this week.

The fact that the BBC, with their revitalised interest in sport under new director general Greg Dyke, aren't one of them merely emphasises just how competitive the market has become. Although the Beeb have the rights to Liverpool's home matches in the Uefa Cup, Channel 5 beat them to signing the away leg of their first-round tie on Thursday against Rapid Bucharest.

The other two Uefa Cup games, Chelsea v St Gallen and Leicester v Red Star Belgrade, will both be on Sky, although the satellite broadcaster will only be the platform in the case of the Leicester match, which will be a pay-per-view production by the increasingly acquisitive u>direct.

Then there are the Champions League matches on Tuesday and Wednesday involving Manchester United, Arsenal and Leeds (and Rangers), which will be split between ITV and ONdigital.

In fact, the Wednesday night games will be divided up within ITV, with Yorkshire TV and ITV2 viewers being shown Leeds's match in Barcelona while the rest of the network are taken to Old Trafford for Manchester United against Anderlecht.

Apart from the general point that the number of companies battling to invest in these European matches is an indication that there is no sign yet of football being damaged by overexposure, perhaps the most interesting aspect of all these deals is that pay-per-view remains on the periphery.

Begging Leicester's pardon, but their match against Red Star is probably the least - how shall we say - riveting of all the games and was picked up towards the end of last week by u>direct, who will charge a minimum £7.99 for the match.

For the moment, at least, pay-per-view, the great beast that was going to trample all over the game altering its landscape, is something of a chimera.

Live football on a big screen is set to become an even more regular feature of pub entertainment this winter.

ONdigital's Champions League coverage on Tuesday nights is being offered to pubs for the first time with the digital broadcaster hoping to emulate the branding success Sky have had serving up football in saloon bars since the early Nineties.

ONdigital will also offer Football League matches to pubs when they and ITV take over live coverage of the League next season.

Sky Sport's digital news channel - Dot.Com TV - is to axe its 'magazine' programmes, including Jimmy Hill's The Last Word, just a few months after introducing a new screen format with ticker-tape rolling statistics with an inset live studio presenter.

Another casualty is the regularly broadcast American sports service - Fox Sports news.

Sky plan to move Hill's chat show programme to one of their analogue satellite channels while Fox could be relegated to another digital service, Sky Sports Extra, a channel that has specialised in recent interactive innovations.

'The magazine shows did not fit the Teletext TV feel to the new service,' said a Sky insider.

jon.henderson@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Bland bombshells
fields.trailText: Starstruck | Last of the Blonde Bombshells | Blind Ambition
fields.body:
Starstruck C4
Last of the Blonde Bombshells BBC1
Blind Ambition ITV

'Yes, I realise I was quite lovely!' mused Sylvia Syms as she flicked through some dog-eared 10 x 8s in the final part of Channel 4's unflinchingly unsentimental documentary series, Starstruck. Time and space ensured Syms's ambivalence about the girl she had once been - the one who graduated swiftly from pretty-as-a-picture ingénue roles in would-be hip-looking Brit flicks of the 1950s entitled 'Whoops! There goes my virginity, Daddio!', to perspiring fetchingly in crisp, unbuttoned poplin opposite John Mills in Ice Cold In Alex, a 'classic' British movie even for those those who have only seen it spoofed in a lager commercial.

Anyway, the point is that Sylvia has worked steadily as an actress for the whole of her adult life without ever being very rich or famous (nope, that's Joan. And that's Sims ) while even at her most pulchritudinous, she was, she admitted, never perceived to be 'a sex symbol like Di Dors', despite the fact that 'Philip Larkin once told me he had had fantasies about me when he was at school'.

Now, of course, the girlish prettiness is wreathed in elderly fat and Sylvia does rumpled, mildly bonkers, national treasure-ish comedic turns in series like the bafflingly popular At Home with the Braithwaites . She may have talked about admiring Joan Collins's ability to work (so terribly hard!) at remaining glamorous, but the inference was clear - some ladies of a certain age act , darling, and some ladies of a certain age must struggle and self-flagellate in pursuit of a frankly pointless Norma Desmondish glamour . But, really, never the twain.

Sylvia was snappily petulant and occasionally rather fierce. 'I was never a star let. I was an act ress!' she corrected the interviewer peevishly. But later she said that though her own career has been solid (and judged by the industry norm, quite madly successful), she had really 'always wanted to be Judi Dench. Or Prunella Scales. Or Maggie Smith. Or, for a while, Glenda Jackson.'

Which was both sweet and sort of brave to admit and immediately made me wonder about the complex thespian pecking order and whom Judi, Prunella and Maggie might secretly yearn to be, if anybody.

Dame Judi is, of course, peerless when it comes to playing warmly bossy and slightly strident British queens and those pea-in-a-pod, middle-class wives of the pine kitchen, oversized cashmere and carriage drive variety. I can't, however, imagine her doing either an American accent or haute glamour, so I hope she harbours a wee-small-hours-of-the-morning fantasy about what it might be to be Joan Collins. Imagine: Judi and Warren Beatty! Judi in Dynasty ! Judi in shoulder pads! Judi in heart-shaped swimming-pools! Judi in (and out) of love!

Interestingly, in Alan Plater's one-off drama, Last of the Blonde Bombshells, Judi could easily have played alongside either Joan or Sylvia (and, in fact, the girl who played the young Judi looked just like the Ice Cold -era Syms). Instead, she found herself with mature co-stars as diverse as Cleo Laine, Olympia Dukakis, Leslie Caron, June Whitfield, Billie Whitelaw (whom I mistook, briefly and bizarrely, for Sue Johnston: good news for Sue, less so for Billie) and Joan Sims; obviously, there had to be a Sims, or a Syms, in there somewhere.

Dame Judi's character, Elizabeth, was a feisty, freshly widowed mother of some desperately dull adult children and a sweet grandchild - played, rather shockingly, by a child actor who spoke with received pronunciation - whom she liked to scare by using the F-word. Oh, how we love a dame who can curse as effortlessly as if she had Tourette's syndrome.

(This was, incidentally, a co-production with the US company HBO, home of The Sopranos and Sex and the City , where women, even dames, behaving badly may well be a contractual obligation.)

Elizabeth had a past as a tenor sax-playing schoolgirl member of a wartime female big band, the Blonde Bombshells, so we got a lot of those over-stylised 1940s scenes in which the blondes are just a bit too blonde, the dresses too bright and tight, the lipstick too red, the jiving too synchronised and the GIs far too pleased with their Rada Frank Sinatra routines.

And there was really no plot to speak of - widow struggles to reform band for her granddaughter's school dance while fending off the advances of the ageing Lothario (Ian Holm) who had once dragged-up to avoid conscription while playing drums for (and sleeping with) the Bombshells - just the opportunity to say things like: 'Isn't Leslie Caron fabulous?'; 'Olympia Dukakis looks like she should be in Some Like It Hot '; 'How many facelifts do you think Cleo Laine has had?'; 'Ah, Judi's doing her Fine Romance routine again'; 'I do love Sylvia Syms. Or is it Joan?' But, though slight and predictable and cosy and largely pointless, I couldn't have known then that Bombshells was going to turn out to be far and away the best drama of last week.

BBC1's two-parter, Waking the Dead, in which, oddly, Sue Johnston looked nothing like Billie Whitelaw, was a very bad drama. But I can't dwell on the merely bad, I must move straight on to the worst drama - Blind Ambition. This starred Robson Green as a runner who has a car crash, loses his sight, gets a bit angry, pulls himself together and decides to run again, for glory and gold, in the Sydney Paralympics.

Robson, you may be aware, is a very handsome man who vacillates prettily between furrowed intensity and lean machismo and has carved himself a very successful career in the process, even surviving singing 'Unchained Melody' on Top of the Pops alongside that Jerome, lately of the execrable Badger.

Indeed, until this week, I had assumed that Green's success must be attributable to his acting ability being the equal of his looks, but I was wrong: Blind Ambition revealed that the man has all the emotional range and intelligence of Rainbow's Bungle. No, sorry, make that Zippy, because I think Bungle had a comparatively rich, albeit largely inarticulated, interior life. Still, Blind Ambition was bad in so many ways that it is unfair to lay the blame wholly at Robson's plywood door of a performance, even though it's fun. No - Imogen Stubbs, as the emotionally rejected wife, must share some of it.

What kind of a casting decision was this, precisely, because Stubbs played a part-time primary-school teacher living in a Newcastle terrace as though she were a Notting Hill hausfrau with a taste for organic tofu and St John's Wort.

Even the running scenes, during which viewers were surely meant to be moved, or excited or something , looked like actors running highly unconvincingly for a director haunted by Chariots of Fire and therefore desperate to avoid slo-mo and any sort of a tune that may remind us of Van-da-da-da-da-daa-da!-gelis.

So, instead, we got fast-mo and house music, while the scenes shot in Sydney, at the Olympic stadium, looked as if they had been done with a combination of skin-of-the-teeth access and extras, which they had.

fields.headline: All and Kundry...
fields.trailText: Parsifal | Genoveva
fields.body:
Parsifal BBC Proms, Royal Albert Hall, London SW7
Genoveva Opera North, King's Theatre, Edinburgh

Last Sunday's Proms performance of Parsifal was the first complete Wagner opera that Simon Rattle had conducted in this country. It proved a triumphant debut, despite apparent drawbacks: concert performance only, in the opera-resistant Royal Albert Hall, and not with some opera-house orchestra that has Parsifal in its blood, but with the Rotterdam Philharmonic.

No doubt it helped that several of Rattle's singers worked with him on Parsifal at Netherlands Opera in 1997, so that Poul Elming (Parsifal), Wolfgang Schöne (Amfortas) and Petra Lang (Kundry) radiated genuine theatrical presence. By contrast, the fact that it was a concert performance freed it of the gruesome, Grailish paraphernalia that can clog Wagner's 'stage consecration play'. Here, the drama was played out on a large but always human scale.

Elming's Parsifal was a man first, humanity's redeemer second. The voice may not have shaken the rafters, but there was a vulnerable lyricism that meant more than sheer power. His Act Two encounter with Kundry surged with sexual energy, mostly hers. There was something rather overblown about Petra Lang's performance, but then for Wagner, Kundry was indeed a slut, desperately seeking salvation. Lang has a formidable vocal apparatus and the natural intensity to back it up, even in Act Three, when she had almost nothing to sing.

The other singers displayed equal authority. Robert Lloyd had a slightly nasal tone, but held superbly the narrative line that runs through Gurnemanz's mighty orations. There may not be many jokes in Parsifal, but Lloyd located scraps of humour to leaven the drama while also suggesting Gurnemanz's burden of awful knowledge. If Sergei Leiferkus's Klingsor had too Slavic an accent, that simply underlined the character's alien nature, while Schöne caught the pained dignity that afflicts Amfortas.

With smaller parts exquisitely cast and the excellent choruses, attention nevertheless focused on Rattle's way with the orchestra. In the main, the Rotterdam Phil proved equal to the task. The strings played with lustrous colour, from the tiniest whisper in the violins to the organ-like underpinning of the nine double basses. From the winds, there were moments of unsurprising, perhaps even welcome unevenness - high gloss is not always what's needed in Wagner. This was not Parsifal in overdrive but a nuanced account that never lost its narrative momentum. I hope our opera houses are queuing up to have Rattle do it in the theatre.

There are quasi-Wagnerian elements in Robert Schumann's only opera, Genoveva: a saucy sorceress, Germanic knights (one called Siegfried), a holy cause, streams of endless melody holding things together when the narrative falters. Although the plot is tangled, the basic structure makes reasonable sense: jealous husband goes to war, leaving his wife behind; while hubby's away, his best friend, mind fuddled by a witch's mischief, tries to bed the innocent wife.

David Pountney's Opera North staging, which brought the Edinburgh Festival to a close last weekend, proved rather undercooked, operative in the bad old sense. Chorus members milled about as if still learning their positions, soloists behaved as if a moment's stillness carried a serious penalty. Yet the story, so complicated in synopsis, came across clearly. As Genoveva, Patricia Schumann displayed a not always ingratiating soprano flutter but she had poise, most movingly when husband Siegfried (Christopher Purves in ringing voice) returns, convinced that she is an adulteress.

As the friend Siegfried doesn't need, Paul Nilon's breast-beating performance was dramatically excessive, vocally expressive, while Sally Burgess opted for panto style as the witch. Opera North's music director Steven Sloane believes in the score; conducting with a combination of subtlety and vigour, he proved Genoveva less than a masterpiece, but more than a museum piece.

 Genoveva, Leeds Grand Theatre, Friday (0113 222 6222); then touring

Fiona Maddocks is away

fields.headline: There's life in the old legs yet
fields.standfirst: Dancers of a certain age have been dominating our stages
fields.trailText: Irek Mukhamedov & Company | La Danse du Temps | Arcimboldo 2000
fields.body:
Irek Mukhamedov & Company Sadler's Wells, London EC1

La Danse du Temps Ballet Atlantique, Barbican Theatre, London EC2

Arcimboldo 2000 NDT, Edinburgh Festival Theatre

The Dance of Time (the English title of Regine Chopinot's work at the Barbican) is an apt description of last week's offerings in London and Edinburgh. All incorporated older dancers; choreographers love to make an issue of of ageing, equating the passage of time with mortality.

How to defy that convention without denying the inevitable loss of physical prowess? One option is modern dance - think Baryshnikov, 52, and his White Oak Project. Irek Mukhamedov, 40, is testing that route with his own ad-hoc group. Underused by the Royal Ballet, he wants to carry on doing what he can still do well: witness the Class Concert at the start of his Wells programme. He and his guest star, Altynai Asylmuratova, 39, outclassed the younger dancers in the routine academic exercises they have done all their lives.

Yet as soon as the two of them moved away from ballet, they looked clumsy, inexpressive. They had lost their physical history without gaining insights into alternative ways of using the body. Darshan Singh Bhuller devised a duet for them, Sita , that deliberately made them earthbound instead of airborne. Named after the Indian goddess of agriculture, it is a contemporary take on a fertility ritual.

Farmer Mukhamedov fructifies the soil by coupling with Asylmuratova, who spends most of the time on her back. Sensual and spiritual are supposedly intertwined. She flexes her feet and he tries to balance himself on her toes, sowing the furrow. Bhuller's ideas have always been more imaginative than their realisation. A fine contemporary dancer during the past two decades, he lacks a choreographer's craft. Powerful subject matter can carry him through, but Sita managed to reduce two of the most articulate performers to banal rutting.

They should have danced William Tuckett's duet, Unobtrusive Detail, which was witty and original (and sharply carried off by Nichola Davies and Martin Harvey). Other pas de deux were familiar party pieces for Russian and Royal Ballet dancers, with a jazzy Gershwin finale by Gillian Lynne. Called Some You Win, it lost Asylmuratova as a Cyd Charisse hoofer in Armani. She can do better, as can the token dancing girls. Mukhamedov was an unlikely Gene Kelly Still, they looked delicious, as did Lynne, 74, in her curtain calls.

Regine Chopinot uses dancers in their seventies for La Danse du Temps, in a stagescape by Andy Goldsworthy, sculptor of time. The backdrop is a film record of Goldsworthy's Earth River, in which a wall of clay dries to reveal the serpentine path of a water course. Watching clay crack, speeded up, is preferable to watching dancers slowly piling stones, branches and leaves, as they did in Chopinot's time-consuming Vegetal at a previous Edinburgh Festival.

At the Barbican, the dancers dominated the foreground, often linked in swirling currents of movement. Theirs was a simple rite of passage, to Vietnamese composer Ton-That Tiet's mesmerising music. Standing out among them were Francoise and Dominique Dupuy, veteran contemporary dancers, married for half a century. Elders rather than oldies, each was tenderly transported by a band of acolytes. He, sturdy, mouthed words, presumably of wisdom; she, slight, seemed a sybil, a snake goddess.

Chopinot's intention, like Goldsworthy's, is to show alteration, loss and renewal. There is plenty of time to reflect and to ponder on how and when a body reveals signs of ageing. The paradox in 'natural' work like this is that, apart from the Dupuys, treated as seers, older dancers in the company were unremarkable, unless you knew they were there.

Chopinot makes the case, as does Jirí Kylián for his Nederlands Dans Theater 3 group, that older dancers enrich the company, as well as the audience's experience. In that case, they need no apology. In Arcimboldo 2000, Kylián's extravaganza at the end of the Edinburgh Festival, NDT3 members were, for once, part of the whole. Some just danced; others had to do the silly bits, like contestants in a TV game show.

Meanwhile, 36 youngsters from the other two NDT companies frolicked about in red silk crinolines and bizarre outfits, sampling choreography from their combined repertoires. Arcimboldo was a surreal Fringe event on a Festival scale, complete with fireworks. Fun, and far less forgettable than I'd thought a week ago.
fields.bodyText: Irek Mukhamedov & Company Sadler's Wells, London EC1 La Danse du Temps Ballet Atlantique, Barbican Theatre, London EC2 Arcimboldo 2000 NDT, Edinburgh Festival Theatre The Dance of Time (the English title of Regine Chopinot's work at the Barbican) is an apt description of last week's offerings in London and Edinburgh. All incorporated older dancers; choreographers love to make an issue of of ageing, equating the passage of time with mortality. How to defy that convention without denying the inevitable loss of physical prowess? One option is modern dance - think Baryshnikov, 52, and his White Oak Project. Irek Mukhamedov, 40, is testing that route with his own ad-hoc group. Underused by the Royal Ballet, he wants to carry on doing what he can still do well: witness the Class Concert at the start of his Wells programme. He and his guest star, Altynai Asylmuratova, 39, outclassed the younger dancers in the routine academic exercises they have done all their lives. Yet as soon as the two of them moved away from ballet, they looked clumsy, inexpressive. They had lost their physical history without gaining insights into alternative ways of using the body. Darshan Singh Bhuller devised a duet for them, Sita , that deliberately made them earthbound instead of airborne. fields.headline: Rhymin' Simon
fields.standfirst: Simon Russell Beale is brilliant as Hamlet. Shame the production's not more rotten
fields.trailText: Hamlet, London | Hamlet, Edinburgh | In Flame | The Mystery of Charles Dickens
fields.body:
Hamlet Lyttelton, London SE1
Hamlet Royal Lyceum, Edinburgh
In Flame New Ambassadors, London WC2
The Mystery of Charles Dickens Comedy Theatre, London SW1

It has been worth waiting for Simon Russell Beale's Hamlet. Ironic, heartfelt, spoken with exemplary clarity, this is a performance which radiates intelligence. It confirms Russell Beale's position as one of the foremost actors of his generation.

But he's acting in a limited production. John Caird's conception of the play is imposing - in both good and bad senses. He has boldly cut the last scene and the character of Fortinbras, stripping the play of its public, martial dimensions. He has floated the action on a raft of religious sounds and images. He produces something impressive, grand and monolithic; he suggests that the core of Hamlet is to do, not with the doubts that any human being is likely to be heir to, but with sin and redemption.

Waves of holy music sweep over the stage: bells peal; choirs soar, at times threatening to interfere with the speech. Tim Hatley's design makes Elsinore into the bare dark lofty space of an Orthodox cathedral. Dozens of golden baskets burning with candles are lowered from the ceiling; when Ophelia is mad, she sets these swaying like censers. At the back of the stage, a wooden screen opens from time to time to admit actors and glimpses of a world outside. In the closing moments, this splits in two directions to show light in the shape of a massive cross. All this makes Hamlet more cohesive, but what's missing is the jangling uncertainty, the sense of impending chaos which turns the rottenness of Denmark into a matter of metaphysics as well as politics.

There are gaps in the acting, too. As Ophelia, Cathryn Bradshaw squeaks; Guy Lankester is a stolid Laertes; Denis Quilley's Polonius is efficient but routinely plummy. Only Sara Kestelman as a poised Gertrude can command the stage with Russell Beale. Shaken from his desolation, Russell Beale lets off a firecracker of a mad laugh to frighten Polonius; as he talks of hawks, he sug gests, without exact mimicry, the bright eye and cocked head of a bird of prey; when he instructs the Players, he hunkers down among them, as if he were one of the company. And when he comes to die, you believe - what you rarely believe - that the readiness is all.

Peter Zadek's more blatantly radical approach to the play supplies the note that's missing from Russell Beale's compassionate performance: that of snarling anarchy. In a wonderful opening scene, two guards in great coats and ear-flapped helmets pace round the corrugated railway truck from which all entrances and exits are made, while very slowly a piece of waste-paper is blown across the empty stage.

Zadek's Hamlet was famous before it opened for casting a woman in the title role. It's likely to be remem bered for its portrait of the Dane as waif. From the moment the celebrated German actor Angela Winkler appears - with ragamuffin locks and legs looking spindly in dark tights under a tunic - she has the air of a changeling among the opulently upholstered courtiers. She has none of their stateliness, but an unguarded affection: she jumps for joy when the Players appear. She delivers the soliloquies with an extreme candour, looking straight into the audience. She hardly moves as she does so. Once - not a good idea - in 'to be or not to be', she sniffs. This is an endearing Hamlet - too much so. But it could only be thought of as feminised by someone who thinks that women are more childlike than men.

Charlotte Jones's In Flame has arrived at the New Ambassadors after opening at the Bush last year. It features vivacious dialogue and a series of inspired performances by Marcia Warren, who plays a sour early-twentieth-century matron as well as a foul-mouthed late-twentieth-century victim of Alzheimer's. It's Warren who provides the high point of the evening when, in hospital nightie, with a rubber-tipped walking-stick tilted at a jaunty angle like a cane, and her frozen features shaken by knowing nods and winks, she patters across the floor in a scarlet-shod tap-dance.

Jones is a talented writer: her play has a lot of sparks. But it doesn't catch fire. Its use of the familiar feminist structure by which two women's lives are seen in parallel too often means that both are reduced to sketchiness. Kerry Fox ismuted, while the bigger stage has forced Rosie Cava liero's creation of two accident-prone young women into gawping, goggling, by-goom caricature.

There's no mystery in The Mystery of Charles Dickens. But there is an attempt to make a straightforward one-man show look complicated. Christopher Woods's design ponderously emphasises the fact that what's on stage is not simply a piece of impersonation. Under Patrick Garland's direction, Simon Callow appears at the Comedy in front of slanted and square-on picture frames: this is Callow presenting Dickens presenting his characters. No real mystery here.

The script, culled by Peter Ackroyd from his biography of the author, concentrates on the overlap, and the contradictions, between Dickens's life and his novels: it's interesting but not revelatory to hear about the discrepan cies between Dickens's sweetness on the page and brutality on the hearth. It's glancingly proposed that the real secret of the writer's life had to do with his liaison in middle age with the young actress Ellen Ternan: if that's so, why isn't there a show about Ternan?

Callow is skilful, and no fan of Dickens will come away without some thrill. He can strike off a grotesque - a lisping Fagin, a cringing Uriah Heep, a terrifying Mrs Gamp - as if he were simply shifting his weight from one foot to another. But his fruitily delivered narrative raises a real mystery about Dickens. Why is this least middle-class of English novelists routinely represented as if he was the plummiest of Establishment figures? When Simon Callow's good he's very, very good, but when he's bad he's florid.

fields.headline: Mutiny over the bounty
fields.trailText: Manhunt | The Sixties | Enfield Pedals After Byron
fields.body:
Manhunt R5

The Sixties R2

Enfield Pedals After Byron R4

'Run Rudolph run,' says a sticker on the wall of Peggy's Diner in Andrews, North Carolina - a one-horse town interchangeable with a hundred others in Hicksville except in one respect. It's the home of Eric Rudolph, the FBI's most wanted criminal - responsible, they reckon, for three devastating bomb attacks including the one during the Atlanta Olympics. Four years later Rudolph is still on the run which comes as no surprise to Bob Burton, a professional bounty hunter who knows that FBI really stands for 'Fucking Bunch of Idiots'.

Manhunt, last week's Five Live Report, was less the story of one dangerous nutter on the loose than the 1,800 nutty residents of Andrews prepared not just to protect Rudolph but to forsake the million bucks ransom for turning him in. Compared to this motley crew of hillbillies who regard Rudolph as a hero somewhere between Rambo and Robin Hood, Jerry Springer's studio guests look like Basingstoke accountants. 'People admire him because he outsmarted the government,' opines Peggy, dishing out her special brand of Rudolph burgers. 'It is just the government and the police, people in uniform he has a problem with - he don't have a problem with us. We ain't scared.'

And I ain't scared neither because Rudolph is a mystery, an enigma; even his school friends don't remember him. Whereas some of the other Andrews characters described by presenter Simon Cox would put the wind up Frankenstein's monster. The real message of Manhunt is that there is no such thing as ordinary people in America: everyone, everything is larger than life.

Cox asks the husband of one of the bomb victims to describe his wife's eye injury. 'Out vile jelly' is kid's stuff by comparison. Urging his class of trainee booty hunters to scour the North Carolina forest for their prey, Burton reminds them that the million dollars reward is just a start, it could be five million with the film and book rights. Only, I suspect, if the winner looks like Sylvester Stallone.

My only criticism of Julian Pettifer's feisty reappraisal of The Sixties is that it is on the wrong station. Radio 2 listeners know about the Sixties. They swung in it after all. It's Radio 1 listeners who need to know that their wrinkly old mums and dads were groovers once. This has to be the format for schools to teach Social History or Anthropology - sound bites from Mary Quant and Paul McCartney interspersed with a soundtrack from Capital Gold.

As for teaching Eng Lit, you couldn't do better than Enfield Pedals After Byron - the quirky peripatetic adventures of Edward Enfield riding in the footsteps of Lord Byron. Childe Harold was never my favourite epic poem but, declaimed on an Albanian hillside by Harry Enfield's dad, it achieves a certain extra dimension which I feel sure school children would appreciate. Armchair travel has become a bit of a cliché on Radio 4: I'm not altogether sure that Arthur Smith's Excess Baggage adequately replaces Loose Ends, but Enfield's unashamed old fogey approach hits the spot for me at any rate.
