fields.headline: Paperbacks
fields.trailText: Alexei Sayle's stories make you laugh out loud and cringe at the same time, plus Blue Light, The Search for the Panchen Lama, This is my Daughter and Ladysmith
fields.body:
Barcelona Plates
Alexei Sayle
Sceptre £6.99, pp215
Buy it at BOL

Raucously punchy and dark, Barcelona Plates is Alexei Sayle's new collection of 14 stories. Sayle writes of an old man masquerading as a hit man, a hypochondriac finding fame and destruction within his neuroses, a white Fiat Uno Turbo with Barcelona number plates liberating the Englishman who drives it back to London, and a mud-smeared, pidgin-speaking ex-nun returning from Papua New Guinea to the family who has forgotten that they excommunicated her and sent her there.

Sayle has a peculiarly funny outlook on both the grim and the mundane and his stories make you laugh out loud while cringing at the same time. His voice, and the pacing of these stories, is quick-witted and new; he's comedy and tragedy wrapped up in one and Barcelona Plates is a disturbingly amusing read.

Blue Light
Walter Mosley
Serpent's Tail £6.99, pp296
Buy it at BOL

Blue Light is a vibrant, bloody and utterly beautiful story about a group of people in San Francisco in the Sixties who are all witness to a cosmic blue light. The light changes each of their lives, and they become the Blues, each gaining a special power.

Walter Mosley's ability to write on death, race and sexual energy is mesmerising, often enlightening, although sometimes can verge on overkill. Chance, Mosley's half-black, half-white narrator, has a little piece of all of us in him: a mix of races, classes, educations and desires. We see this story through his eyes and Mosley's fluid and bizarre prose is so vivid you can almost taste the colour and absurdities.

As the Blues and the Half-Lights (those who did not actually see the light but are followers) realise that they are in danger, they must together hunt down evil, in the form of a character called Grey Man. Who's to say it couldn't have happened?

The Search for the Panchen Lama
Isabel Hilton
Penguin £7.99, pp311
Buy it at BOL

In this fantastically engrossing book, Isabel Hilton combines journalism, history and travel writing. Relating the actual search, as well as putting together an extremely readable crash course in the history of Tibet, Hilton's clear, intelligent writing is forceful and humorous, yet she doesn't make light of her subject.

She balances ancient history with her own travels and encounters throughout Tibet and China and also details the relationships and balances between the Dalai Lamas and the Panchen Lamas with remarkable clarity. You come away having learned a great deal about Tibet, while at the same time feeling as if you've just been on an amazing adventure.

This is my Daughter
Roxana Robinson
Bloomsbury £6.99, pp404
Buy it at BOL

A tale of two divorced parents and their children, Roxana Robinson's This Is My Daughter is a poignant New York drama. Set in the midst of Park Avenue society, where everyone has nannies and summer homes, Emma and Peter struggle out of their failing marriages and into life together. Also thrown into this package are Emma's sweetly adoring daughter, Tess, and Peter's sullen daughter, Amanda, as well as their tumultuous histories with their exes.

Robinson writes a compassionate novel, where no one is perfect and everyone has a difficult time finding enough love to go around. Her prose is a swiftly moving, interwoven narrative of the two protagonists' thoughts and actions.

Ladysmith
Giles Foden
Faber and Faber £6.99, pp366
Buy it at BOL

Ladysmith is historical fiction at its finest. Foden's grippingly detailed story of the Boer War, told from a variety of British, Dutch and African perspectives, is a chronicle of slaughter, exploding shells and enormous losses, as well as a painfully aware narrative of love, death and family loyalty.

Foden has a remarkable eye for the small details of war. He describes how wartime conditions change the face of a town and all the nations who live within it. Presenting all sides of the war with an observant and vividly aware eye, Foden makes the novel both an adventure story and a painful portrait of the bloodiest battles, victories and losses.

Foden has a remarkable eye for the small details of war. He describes how wartime conditions change the face of a town and all the nations who live within it. fields.headline: Children's choice
fields.trailText: The harsh reality of the Irish potato famine intrudes into a story that could have come from Enid Blyton
fields.body:
Black Harvest
Ann Pilling
Collins Modern Classics £5.99, pp192
Buy it at BOL

Imagine, if you can, an Enid Blyton story written in a realistic style. This novel, first published in 1983, starts off in the traditional way. The children have appropriately old-fashioned names. Colin and Priscilla (Prill), their baby sister, Alison, and their prissy cousin, Oliver, are spending the summer on the west coast of Ireland. All seems idyllic. The weather is beautiful. But an adventure is in store - and it is more sinister than anything that ever happened to Julian, Dick and Co.

There is a constant smell of decay, food goes bad, the baby becomes seriously ill and so does the dog. Prill sees strange, terrifying figures - an old woman crawling over the field, pushing soil into her mouth, children, thin as scarecrows, begging wordlessly by the side of the road. Colin wakes to find his bed covered in mould. Only Oliver appears strangely untouched by the mounting horror.

Pilling was inspired to write her novel after reading Cecil Woodham Smith's account of the Irish potato famine. Her story has a happy ending, so it won't depress young readers (10 up), but it will certainly make them think.

fields.headline: Changing of the old guard
fields.trailText: It is no longer as easy as it used to be to distinguish between the bourgeois world of capitalism and the bohemian counterculture.
fields.body:
Are you a Bobo? A bourgeois bohemian? Bobo is a word you won't yet find in any dictionary, the happy inspiration of an American journalist, David Brooks, author of Bobos in Paradise: The New Upper Class and How They Got There (Simon & Schuster) and it springs from Brooks's observation that it is no longer as easy as it used to be to distinguish between the bourgeois world of capitalism and the bohemian counterculture.

Once, if you were bourgeois, you wore a dark suit, probably worked for a corporation, and had life insurance. If you were bohemian, you were an artist and an intellectual, and knew about the avant-garde. Bohemians wore blue jeans and championed the values of the liberated Sixties. Your average bourgeois was the gung-ho yuppie of the Eighties and the Age of Greed.

Interestingly enough, both 'bourgeois' and 'avant-garde' are words that have, of late, rather dropped from the lexicon. And, to finish with Brooks's insight into the way we live now, the bohemian and the bourgeois are all mixed up.

You cannot, he says, readily distinguish an espresso-sipping professor from a cappuccino-gulping banker. More, he argues that these bobos are a new élite that combines the values of the countercultural Sixties with those of the high-achieving Eighties. These, he says, are the people who now set the pace, and the tone, of American society. Their hybrid culture has infiltrated all walks of life, and all areas of mass consumption. He doesn't say this, but Democratic presidential hopeful Al Gore is Bobo-in-Chief with his support for the internet and the environment.

Brooks is clever, but he's not intellectual, and he's not much exercised by the phenomenon he's describing. 'I just went out,' he writes, 'and tried to describe how people are living, using a method that might best be described as comic sociology.'

Brooks is writing about America, and very entertaining he is, too, in a Wolfe-ish, O'Rourke-ish, Buckley-esque sort of way. Equally troubled by a similar changing of the guard in Britain, but much less enjoyably so, is George Walden, disappointed man and former Tory MP. The New Elites: Making A Career in the Masses (Allen Lane £18.99) is a lengthy and rather muddled whinge about what Walden sees as a new oligarchy of professional egalitarians, and their populist 'corruption' of the pure well of British culture.

That's not all. Where Brooks is judgment-light in his assessment of Bobo values and freely admits that 'Max Weber has nothing to worry about from me', Walden is a prodigious name-dropper. A blizzard of allusion - to Kierkegaard, Flaubert, De Lillo, Arnold and William Morris - assails the reader in the first 20 pages. Shortly after, Walden abandons the quasi-journalistic tone of his opening and launches into a mini-lecture about 'the so-called classical élitists' Vilfredo Pareto, Robert Michels and Gaetano Mosca.

Although later he loosens up to take on the Dome, Channel 5 and the Booker Prize, here, in a nutshell, is the fundamental problem with his book. Briefly, it never decides whether it's an opinionated polemic against Tony Blair's New Labour establishment or a Tocquevillean treatise about representative democracy in the age of mass media. A prevailing tone of withering contempt ('To every fool is given his morsel of wisdom') and the absence of index, bibliography or footnotes tells us that Walden sees his efforts as essayistic.

Simultaneously, the sophomoric references to Fourier, Heidegger, Kundera, Nietzsche and Koestler remind us that Walden wants to pass, at least in Conservative circles, as an intellectual, an author of gravitas and learning. Or, as David Brooks might put it, he seems to want to be both bohemian and bourgeois. Some candid friend should take him to one side with a quiet word about the difficulty of being at once racy and respectable.

Walden's complaint about the crassness of contemporary cultural endeavour in the age of New Labour is more bilious than Brooks's but in other respects he is part of a trend, at least in Britain. These past few weeks have seen the publication of a number of grumpy jeremiads from a grouch of retired and/or deposed culture tsars, each of whom wants to say that in the age of the Bobo our culture is going to hell in a handbasket.

Next to Walden, there's John Tusa's Art Matters (Methuen £12.99) which feuds with Melvyn Bragg while wringing its hands over the cretinisation of cultural life. Another former BBC man, John Drummond, has also pitched into the fray with some spinsterish remarks about Nigel Kennedy in his door-stopping memoir Tainted by Experience (Faber £25).

The difficulty with taking this après nous, le déluge stuff seriously, as Professor John Sutherland recently pointed out, is that these writers are all into their bus pass years. Why doesn't some enterprising Bobo publisher commission a lively New Labour journalist to critique the supposed cultural crisis from a position of knowledge, sympathy and understanding?

webTitle: Observer review: The Night Listener by Armistead Maupin

fields.headline: Memoirs are made of this
fields.standfirst: Armistead Maupin draws on his life for his novel The Night Listener - until it gets even darker
fields.trailText: Armistead Maupin draws on his life for his novel The Night Listener - until it gets even darker
fields.body:
The Night Listener
Armistead Maupin
Bantam £16.99, pp342
Buy it at BOL

This is a novel that brazenly demands to be read as a memoir. Its narrator, Gabriel Noone, paunchy and generous chronicler of comings and goings in San Francisco's Castro district, is a ringer for Armistead Maupin in all but name.

And, if you like, you can go sleuthing for clues to support a strictly autobiographical reading: Noone's lover of 10 years, Jess, who he has nursed through Aids, and who has left him after a cocktail of drugs afforded him a new lease on life, is, it seems, Terry Anderson, one of the book's dedicatees, who left Maupin under identical circumstances, as he has frequently described in interviews.

And Maupin's own father's father did inexplicably commit suicide, just like Noone's; his own mother did vow to have her remaining breast tattooed to 'compensate' for a mastectomy, as does Noone's mother; and he did, just like Noone, once walk into a coffee shop and find his name on a gay pride mural sandwiched between that of Martina Navratilova and Oscar Wilde.

But seductive confessionals are not always quite what they seem. At the heart of The Night Listener is another memoir. This second 'true story' is the work of a 13-year-old boy, Pete Lomax. It appears here in manuscript form, sent to Gabriel Noone by a publisher in the hope he will write a blurb for it. And we have only Noone's secondhand word of its content.

Still, Pete's story is one of shocking cruelty and unbelievable courage. It is a narrative of a short lifetime of abuse telling of how, brought up in the Midwest, he has, since the age of four, been repeatedly raped in his garden shed by his father. These horrors have been filmed by his mother for distribution on the internet, from where Pete has been pimped to men who ordered him 'like a cheap ring or a beanie baby'.

Pete has escaped this life, lived to tell his tale in the most moving way, seen his parents imprisoned and been adopted by his psychiatrist, Donna. He has, though, contracted Aids, is dying, and while in hospital he has listened avidly to Gabriel Noone's Maupin-esque tales on the radio, a warm, humane, fatherly voice that 'often, though Pete knew better, seemed to be speaking to Pete alone.'

Noone adopts Pete, or at least he does so on the telephone, listening to him day and night, his fears and jokes, just as Pete once listened to Noone from the darkness of his hospital bed. Pete calls him Dad, wants Noone to call him Son, and they develop a conversational bond that calls on and exploits Maupin's great gift as a writer of wholly natural dialogue. Noone uses this relationship as a touchstone and a metaphor for the crumbling intimacies in his own life: with his absent lover and his distant and disapproving father.

As the relationship develops, however, Noone, against his better judgment, and for a number of reasons that could be dismissed as coincidence or paranoia, comes to doubt the truth of Pete's story, and the book becomes something else entirely, a powerful and moving suspense story, and an examination of the power of belief, of a writer's ability to induce it in his readers.

As Noone struggles in himself to authenticate Pete's horrors, the Dickensian tale of a boy he has never met, we are invited to listen intently to every riddling inflection of the boy's disembodied voice, and to question the basis of our own judgments of truth and credulity. At one point in his dialogue, Noone describes something called 'room tone', the charged silence of a pause in radio dialogue, into which our imagination jumps feet first. This is a novel all about room tone, about the gap between words, like the charged space between lovers, and the question of how we fill it.

It is also Maupin's first book for 10 years, the first since he closed the door on 28 Barbary Lane and concluded his Tales From the City. It is a departure of sorts: the anecdotal structure of Tales is replaced here by something more self-consciously intense; this is, in many ways, an older and wiser Maupin, and though much of the easy humour of his earlier writing is still in place, his narrative here is infused with autumnal sadnesses for lost loves and unreachable parents.

The result is a very knowing novel that holds tight to innocence, a rich and intriguing book about the obligations and liberations of dependency and the lies we like to tell ourselves in the name of love.

webTitle: Observer review: The Way of All Flesh by Midas Dekkers

fields.headline: The autumn of our lives
fields.standfirst: Decay, death, mustiness. Isn't old age great? Midas Dekkers argues for a new sense of the passage of time in The Way of All Flesh
fields.trailText: Decay, death, mustiness. Isn't old age great? Midas Dekkers argues for a new sense of the passage of time in The Way of All Flesh
fields.body:
The Way of All Flesh
Midas Dekkers
translated by Sherry Marx-Macdonald
Harvill Press £16.99, pp266
Buy it at BOL

In September 1940 London's Natural History Museum was hit in a Luftwaffe raid. Appalling destruction of invaluable collections followed, but in the dousing operations the fire-brigade unwittingly activated seeds brought back from China in the late eighteenth century. The author of this book, who is deeply ambivalent about museums, conservation areas and restored buildings, evokes here a scene of wonder. Amazed curators watched silk-trees grow from the obscure contents of a cupboard. But the occurrence didn't merit such amazement; it can be paralleled. In China itself, for instance, in 1995, lotus seeds were germinated after 1,200 years.

It is both pleasing and exhilarating to read of such things; the idea of seeds and sowing is dear to us, and from it we construct imagery to help us with the business of living. It informs the New Testament, while 'Fair seed-time had my soul,' wrote Wordsworth in The Prelude, his great account of the 'Growth of a Poet's Mind'. But, emphasises Midas Dekkers, 'decaying is living' also, and indeed he subtitles his book 'A Celebration of Decay', though it isn't until his last chapter (on human old age) that his decision to do so is vindicated.

We avert our attention from decay's relentless process, programmed for victory though it is, and from its countless agents. In the same way we relish spring and sigh over autumn (in truth the culmination of Nature's year) because we see in the season the approach of decline and death. We celebrate Christmas (a birth, with the promise of a life ahead) over Easter, the doctrinally more important of the two feasts, and this despite the Resurrection and the promise of life after death. Unlike many species, humans find degeneration and dying difficult - at times impossible - to cope with spiritually.

Dekkers's aim in his enthralling book is surely to change our mindset. Enormously successful in the Netherlands as writer and broadcaster on biological subjects, he presents us here with a plethora of natural phenomena - from the consideration elephants show their terminally ill and the grief they display over their dead to the longevity of sturgeon (80 years in one Wisconsin lake) - yet his purpose, I believe, is missionary and moral. Wouldn't our lives be richer, happier, wouldn't contemporary society be kinder and emotionally ampler, if we could accept more and deny less, if we stopped hugging our ignorance and aversions to ourselves lest we become too frightened?

Dekkers agrees with Stephen Jay Gould that, even in science education, there has been a conspiracy against recognition of bacteria. We would learn about an Age of Fishes, an Age of Reptiles, an Age of Mammals, yet nothing about an Age of Bacteria which occupied 2,000 million years. It is of course terrifying to consider the supremacy of bacteria over our own bodies, almost as terrifying as the contemplation of being devoured after death. But there are perhaps worse terrors still, those consequent on the protection of ourselves from multi-faceted reality, and on the inevitable breakdown of that protection - the irreparable collapse of some article of deceiving religious or philosophical faith.

Dekkers argues his cases with great brilliance, only occasionally vitiated by a certain over-determined jauntiness. Unsurprisingly he reveals the culture from which he is writing. The Netherlands is a country wrested from the sea, Nature has been fended off to a degree that has entered the national psyche, and this explains the animus behind some eloquent passages.

He tells us how the mind often supplants one event with another comparable but more recent one, and uses the example of the First and Second World Wars. No British, French or German writer could have written this: Holland, on the other hand, was neutral in the First World War.

But, on the whole, Dekkers is a percipient and accurate spokesperson for Western culture, knowing its plight and seeing possibilities for its alleviation. If we rejoice in autumn and celebrate decay as the undeniable evidence of a pluralist world, we shall go a long way towards remedying the contemporary shrinking from old age and old people. The old, he observes, contain the histories of both their individual selves and their fellow living beings, and should enable us to 'see the present as the future of the past'. In truth past, present and future are forming their precarious fusion every second of existence.

webTitle: Observer review: The Book of Kings by James Thackara

fields.headline: Everyone has a book inside them...
fields.standfirst: Sadly James Thackara's is terrible. Philip Hensher despairs of The Book of Kings
fields.trailText: Sadly James Thackara's is terrible. Philip Hensher despairs of The Book of Kings
fields.body:
The Book of Kings
James Thackara
Duckworth £19.99, pp773
Buy it at BOL

Reviewing someone's first novel, it is customary to be polite about it, to find things to praise in it. So let me say straight away that James Thackara's The Book Of Kings is printed on very nice paper; the typeface is clear and readable, and Samantha Nundy's photograph of the author is in focus. And, given that it's 773 pages long, the author has shown a commendable degree of application and spent a great deal of time on the project.

That, as it turns out, is the literary-London story of the book; that he's been writing it for years and years, and was writing the Story of the Twentieth Century. This, we were promised, was going to be the great novel of the European experience, covering continents in its magisterial stride. Now, at last, here it is and we can judge for ourselves.

And it's terrible. Startlingly badly written, with no apparent understanding of what drives people or how people relate or talk to each other, it is a book of gigantic, hopeless awfulness. You read it to a constant, internal muttering of 'Oh - God - Thackara - please, don't - no - oh, God, just listen to this rubbish'. It's so awful, it's not even funny. There is not one decent sentence in the book, nothing but falsity and a useless sincerity. It may be the very worst novel I have ever read.

Meanwhile, things are getting grim in Germany - 'My dear Son,' someone's dear old mum writes. 'Times are hard even in our little village. My old head is full of our new dictator.'

Soon, the time will come for our four students to part. David Sunda, Johannes Godard, Duncan Penn and Justin Lothaire; each comes from a different part of the world. History will treat some of them roughly, of that you may be sure! And some will survive the coming catastrophe, and some, mes braves, will triumph over the savage wavelets of History. (Thackara's style, distressingly, is rather contagious.) And the result is the usual stuff, the tragedy of Germany, the tragedy of Europe, former friends sundered by the movements of History and a book as thick as your wrist.

What sets Thackara apart from other writers in this territory is quite a simple fact. He can't write. After a while, the incredulous reader starts to play a game with this book. The game is to open the book at random and try and find a tolerable sentence.

Save your effort - you will never win. Thackara is always ahead of you, with his uncanny knack for the not-quite-right word and the yer-what turn of phrase. 'You could not see his parents' intricate cultivation, nor that the ball was in the Palazzo Farnese, just after the war.' 'Justin's friend was not in the courtyard, but the fountain was.' 'The Hanoverian battery commander, Egbert, was as delighted as a music conductor to show off for his guests behind the embankment wall.' 'Yet presently David was descending behind his parents' guests round the great staircase into the bright halls of white-tied gentlemen and crop haired ladies in clinging lace, with their cigarette stems and sashes.' Terrible as Thackara's prose is, it becomes quite unremarkable when set next to his idea of dialogue. It is the purest Hollywood mini-series idea of how foreigners talk to each other, a sort of language never spoken by man or woman. 'David... what about kindness and children, what about right and wrong? Also love. What about love?' 'Isn't the power and its refinement here?' 'The struggle there, Eli, is for the soil of my fathers.' 'All this will seem insignificant afterward. You and I must concentrate on Karin's beautiful wedding... you look so handsome and well-rested.' The truth is that it's Thackara who is just incapable of listening. Every single character talks in exactly the same idiotically macaronic way, and five hundred pages into it, you are still trying to remember which humourless pundit is which. The awful thing is that Thackara really wants to say something. He is utterly sincere and will probably be admired by people who believe that sincerity, rather than art, is the basis of a great novel. He is probably a nice man. He obviously cares deeply about these great historical movements and has done a great deal of research - my God, he has researched and researched and researched. But on the evidence of The Book of Kings, he could not write 'Bum' on a wall.

webTitle: Observer review: The Rising Sun by Douglas Galbraith

fields.headline: Taking tincture with 'Claret Colquhoun'
fields.standfirst: Douglas Galbraith puts himself amongst the very best of historical novelists with The Rising Sun
fields.trailText: Douglas Galbraith puts himself amongst the very best of historical novelists with The Rising Sun
fields.body:
The Rising Sun
Douglas Galbraith
Picador £16, pp520
Buy it at BOL

The old name for the Isthmus of Panama, the narrow waist of what Douglas Galbraith calls 'the great hourglass of the Americas', is most famously preserved in John Keats's sonnet 'On First Looking Into Chapman's Homer', where 'stout Cortez' and his fellow conquistadors glimpse the Pacific Ocean from their awed vantage 'upon a peak in Darien'. In the black book of Scottish history, however, the name of Darien has more grievous and embarrassing associations, which Galbraith takes as the matter of his massive and thoroughly impressive first novel, The Rising Sun.

In 1697, the Company of Scotland Trading to Africa was founded and floated in imitation of the English trading companies of the day. Scots great and small flocked to subscribe. The following year, a convoy of five ships, carrying around 1,100 volunteers, set out from Leith to establish a Scottish colony ('Caledonia') in the virgin territory of Darien and, by forcing an overland route through the jungle from ocean to ocean, to clear a dizzying prospect of commercial fortunes for Scottish investors. Instead, the destruction of the enterprise - by in-fighting, disease, the machinations of the superpowers and the unbelievable malice of the elements - bankrupted the nation and so brought on the indignity of takeover by England in the Act of Union (1707).

Galbraith's fictional recreation of the Darien catastrophe is presented through the chronicle, composed piecemeal like a diary, of Roderick Mackenzie, the young superintendent of cargoes on the expedition's flagship, the Rising Sun. A spirited, even flamboyant narrator ('the Herodotus of our comic tragedy', as he styles himself), Mackenzie is, by nature, at once cunning and naive, which makes his insight on the obscure rivalries at work in the settlement both rewardingly observant and intriguingly incomplete.

Part of Mackenzie's journal is given over to an account of his own earlier history in Edinburgh, before he begged and conned his way into the company and aboard ship. His first position is as bookkeeper to the wine merchant 'Claret' Colquhoun, a red-faced volcano of self-righteousness, the best of a gallery of vividly realised male characters (the women are a sorry little group of dumb prostitutes and pinched wives).

Like the rest of 1690s Edinburgh, Colquhoun speaks recent if not quite modern colloquial English ('Damn them all, damn that damned Dutchman!'). This may be strictly inaccurate, but it is also fresh and apt in its effect, not least because it protects Galbraith's city from the echoes of other historical Edinburghs, Scott's, Hogg's. Stevenson's. In other matters of material authenticity, though, Galbraith's reconstruction is as convincing as any of these.

Brought up in Scotland, Galbraith was a doctoral student in medieval history at Cambridge and it is his attraction to lost facts - menus, business practice, engineering, medicines, ways of thinking - that give his novel its depth of authority. An allusion, say, to the sequence of stages on the Bristol-to-London coach may be incidental, but the great stacks of documentary detail to which it contributes buttress the narrative and our belief in it. And none, or very little, of this appears as unprocessed research, for, besides being a responsible historian, Galbraith is a powerfully imaginative storyteller and a stylish writer.

The Rising Sun is distinguished by its supple and characterful prose, full of lively figures: to quote just one of a thousand pleasing examples: 'I had a vision of myself with one foot on the Company and one on Colquhoun. They drifted apart like a boat from the quay with cold water threatening beneath.' And the rhythm of the collapse in Darien ('where the powers of corruption are so fantastically accelerated'), the satisfying crescendo of appalling incident, is masterfully controlled.

The Rising Sun isn't quite perfect. The historian gets the better of the novelist when he extends the tale beyond its natural scope to encompass the affray about the Union. All but dead when he returns from Darien, Mackenzie has to kick his heels for nine years and 60 pages to witness it. And in their heyday, adventures in far-off lands would be fronted with maps: one here of 'Caledonia' would help us to enjoy detailing such as that of 'a fortified ditch across the narrow neck of the peninsula where it joins the mainland'.

But we finish the book with strong feelings of gratitude for the amount and variety of fictional entertainment it has provided. Its publication propels Douglas Galbraith to a place among the very best of our historical novelists.

webTitle: Observer review: Mauve by Simon Garfield

fields.headline: When the dye was cast
fields.standfirst: Simon Garfield's Mauve puts a little colour into the beginnings of industrial chemistry
fields.trailText: Simon Garfield's Mauve puts a little colour into the beginnings of industrial chemistry
fields.body:
Mauve
Simon Garfield
Faber £9.99, pp222
Buy it at BOL

A faded celebrity chemist, a flamboyant empress and an experiment to synthesise quinine gone wrong; Simon Garfield's history of the synthetic dye industry mixes chemistry and social history into quite a colourful tale.

The first synthetic dye was invented by British chemist William Perkin. He went on to manufacture mauve dye commercially with great success. By his death, he was famous on both sides of the Atlantic and the toast of chemists worldwide. A hundred years on, his portrait has been removed from the National Portrait Gallery and his name had slipped into obscurity. Mauve determines to set the record straight.

In 1856, at the age of 18, William Perkin of Shadwell, east London, a student of the newly founded Royal College of Chemistry, set out to make artificial quinine from coal tar (malaria was still rampant in England during the 1850s). Instead of quinine, his experiment resulted in a reddish powder. Further tests, this time using aniline as a base, produced a powder which turned purple in alcohol. In spite of the fact that aniline had been linked with colour-producing reactions for 30 years, Perkin was so excited by his discovery that he immediately stained some silk cloth a striking purple.

Yet, torn between the practice of pure chemistry and the pursuit of chemistry as a commercial enterprise, he was unsure what to do next. Eventually, he patented the colour and started producing the dye commercially. One year after his discovery, the flamboyant Empress Eugenie decided that purple would be the colour for the season, and Paris was soon awash with the new shade. Perkin stepped up production and became one of the wealthiest men of his day. However, control of the lucrative synthetic dye trade soon slipped into German hands. (This was neither the first nor the last time a British invention was made more profitable overseas; Tim Berners-Lee's worldwide web is a recent example.)

Ultimately, it was the many applications of Perkin's work that secured his fame - in medicine, photography and explosives. Not all the applications were beneficial, though. I.G. Faber, a large German dye company, ran the slave labour camp Monowitz-Buna for the Nazis.

On a lighter note, Garfield finds it ironic that the first synthetic dye to be mass-produced should be purple, given the colour's historic association with power and sovereignty. While Garfield's tone is a little dry, Mauve is a fitting tribute to the man who pioneered industrial chemistry.

webTitle: Observer review: That Summer by Andrew Grieg

fields.headline: Spirits in the sky
fields.standfirst: A pilot falls in love. You just know it won't last... Andrew Grieg revisits the Battle of Britain in That Summer
fields.trailText: A pilot falls in love. You just know it won't last... Andrew Grieg revisits the Battle of Britain in That Summer
fields.body:
That Summer
Andrew Grieg
Faber £9.99, pp261
Buy it at BOL

'One day, there may be a generation without a great war,' muses the heroine of Andrew Greig's tender novel. 'What will they do then to know themselves?' What we do is turn to history, burdened and blurred by the pasts we carry, increasingly aware of identities freighted with the dead.

Greig tells a love story set during the Battle of Britain, when for 12 weeks in the summer of 1940 British pilots battled their German equivalents in the English sky, staving off invasion. Greig has been here before - That Summer grew from A Flame in Your Heart, a book of poems written with Kathleen Jamie, which they have also turned into a play for Radio 4.

Stella, an assured university girl working as a radar operator, shares the narrative with the pilot, Len, a West Country lad 'full of silence and sudden blurts'. A plot which is as old as war itself - passion menaced by death - is intensified as the characters discover the fundamental things becoming urgent in their heightened situation, jolting into connection.

More than a love story, That Summer is a ghost story. Shades slip into the narrative, whether phantom aircraft claimed by the pilots or a man emerging ghostly white from bomb-damage plaster. Stella ponders an imaginary opposite number, a Fräulein who prompts doubts about moral equivalence. Even the war itself is haunted by the sense that it is the century's second great conflict, another attempt to end all wars. Reminders of the First World War prowl around Len: the ageing desk men and, especially, his father, shying from talk of the trenches. The swathe of young men lost mirrors the vulnerable fighter pilots, barely out of boyhood, but both generations cloak fearful experience in reticence, determinedly jocular.

Greig fights to reclaim his characters from posterity, reminding us of the unknowable instant. Poignancy is inevitable; even as he insists that they are 'as up to date as anyone alive, the last word in modern', we ache for their vanished age. A dance band plays 'These Foolish Things', popular music clutching at specifics already packed in nostalgia. The present moment continually shudders between past and future.

The green blips on Stella's radar screen intimate a perilous near future, while wireless reports of the battle, scrubbed to keep up morale, disconcert Len, divide him from his own experience. His diary, written to the moment, uses pencil, as if the possibility of erasure might prevent the present sliding into history. He scratches his name into a tree and returns to worry that it looks like a memorial, to see nature film over the exposed wood.

That Summer is a poet's novel only in as much as Greig's attentive vocabulary makes words seem nubbly and seamed as stones. He rubs his thumb over onomatopoeia, presses nouns into service as verbs. He is convincing on the rattling speed of aerial engagement, nipping up and hopefully back, 'two minutes of blurred intensity, incoherent as a waking dream'. Forget debonair David Niven in A Matter of Life and Death, another pilot romancing a radio girl and steeped in the hereafter. Len prefers his stolid Hurricane to the art-deco Spitfire ('too posh, too sleek'). And he spends the decisive day of the battle on leave, hobbling over a Scottish glen. In this off-centre history, significance pools at the margins rather than in the thick of great events.

'What are we becoming?' Stella asks, pitched into longing, into hatred with her 'beanpole pilot'. Emotional intensity is this honourable novel's argument, and Greig stitches amorous particularity into common experience. Shared terror inspires Stella with a feeling 'almost like falling in love, as subtle, as undeniable, as irreversible'. Life crawls across their skin, unpicks their hearts even as they try for distance.

Consider That Summer an oddly elegiac carpe diem, as a blinded pilot urges: 'Just being alive is being in love. It's a gift, and you don't hang on to gifts too tight.' And feel the sensuous immediacy of the past as Len goes hiking in the heavy mist, striding into nothingness.

fields.headline: Unsentimental voyager
fields.standfirst: Now 82, the creator of Miss Jean Brodie, whose twenty-first novel has just been published, tells Stephanie Merritt that she's a 'very bad picker' of men
fields.trailText: Now 82, the creator of Miss Jean Brodie, whose twenty-first novel has just been published, tells Stephanie Merritt that she's a 'very bad picker' of men
fields.body:
There is a line in Muriel Spark's new novel, Aiding and Abetting (her twenty-first) which gave me a shock of recognition when I read it, so neatly might it apply to the author herself: '[She] had long felt that sentimentality was a luxury she could not afford.'

'It could be true.' Dame Muriel rearranges herself on the sofa and considers. 'I have sometimes thought that.'

Others have noted it too, over her 50-year writing career, this lack of sentiment, and have called it coldness or ruthlessness. Miss Jean Brodie called it dedication ('You must all grow up to be dedicated women,' she tells her girls). Spark's co-religionist and former patron Graham Greene pinpointed the same quality in different words: 'There is a splinter of ice in the heart of a writer.'

In person, she is charming, with shrewd, smiling eyes and careful, dark-red lipstick that matches her hair. She offers me coffee, invites me to admire the exuberant flowers her publisher has sent to cheer up the small room of her genteel hotel, is very concerned with my tape recorder and whether it's working properly. She might be 82, but don't make the mistake of talking to her as if she's an old lady.

'Do you get to travel much these days?' I realise before I've finished the question how patronising it sounds. Spark draws herself up slightly and replies: 'This is my third trip to London this year and I'm coming back in October. But we nearly didn't get here because of those French fishermen.'

Sitting across from her, leafing through recent reviews and cuttings, is Penelope Jardine, Spark's friend and companion of more than 20 years; it is Penelope who does the driving to and from the converted Tuscan presbytery they share when not travelling, and Penelope who, rather like Mrs Tennyson, takes care of the practical side of life while Spark is writing and researching, Penelope who types up Spark's manuscripts, all written in long-hand in special notebooks she orders from the Edinburgh stationer James Thin.

Occasionally, Spark appeals to Penelope to corroborate a story or back up an opinion - 'I think it's not as hard for women writers to get noticed these days - what do you think, Pen? You always say women writers have a bad deal.' 'Do I?' 'Yes, you do.'

'Someone's got you down here as a single mother,' Penelope remarks, looking up from her cuttings, 'meaning you weren't married when you had a baby.'

'Well, I was virtually a single mother,' Spark cries, indignantly, 'he was absolutely abandoned by his father!'

Her critics might find this accusation a little disingenuous. Spark's relationship with her son, Robin, appears always to have been unorthodox. Her husband, Sydney Oswald, whom she married at 19 having emigrated to join him in Rhodesia, began to show signs of mental illness not long after the child's birth and was eventually interned in an institution; Muriel filed for divorce and, keen to experience the war in Europe at first-hand, left little Robin in a convent while she braved the voyage back to England on a troop ship. When her son joined her the following year, he went to live with her parents in Edinburgh, while Spark continued her war work for the Foreign Office, broadcasting subtle anti-Nazi propaganda and false information to German troops.

She was writing poetry in Rhodesia, but her literary career was launched in 1951, when she submitted a short story to a competition in The Observer and won first prize out of nearly 7,000 entries. 'You had to send it under a pseudonym,' she remembers, 'and put your real name inside. It was Philip Toynbee who opened it, and he was quite surprised to find that it was by a woman. I don't know if that's a compliment or not. But that was a great moment. The New Yorker gave me a party.'

A publishing contract followed, and Spark's career took her to New York. But the relationship with her son attracted attention again two years ago, when Robin, an artist and an Orthodox Jew who still lives in Edinburgh, suddenly flourished his grandparents' marriage certificate which, he claimed, disproved Muriel's assertion that her mother was not Jewish. Muriel, naturally, countered with characteristic energy and defiance; a letter of 1998 to The Observer begins: 'Your report (last week) that I "finally conceded" that I was not born of a Jewish father and a Gentile mother, is wrong. I conceded no such thing. I do not need to prove anything, anyway.'

'My mother falsified the marriage certificate so she could be married in a synagogue,' she says, her tone somewhere between weariness and protestation. 'I can't help it that she wasn't a Jew. When my son started playing up, I gave his letters to the National Library of Scotland, who handle my manuscripts. I think it's only right that people should know the truth, and his letters speak for themselves.'

Perhaps Robin felt his mother was threatening the identity he had painstakingly constructed?

'He thought I should have gone along with it and covered up,' she says, really quite affronted. 'I'd have done anything to make him a full Jew, but I wasn't going to lie! But I think he got annoyed because I pointed out that he was just pure damn jealous - he was very resentful of my success.'

Identity is a crucial theme for Spark; you can imagine she would be resentful of anyone who tried to rewrite her own past. 'I'm a Catholic,' she says, 'but if people attack the Jews, then I do feel very Jewish. I think environment is the provocation.'

She returns to the theme of literary success and jealousy. 'I'm a very bad picker of men. Obviously I didn't pick my son, but weak men can't cope with women who are successful, particularly if you're a writer, because your heart is always with the work, you exclude them. I've made three terrible mistakes - well, one was my husband and he was bonkers, so you can't count him. But the other two were writers, and they couldn't cope with my doing better than them. If you don't want that sort of treatment you should pick men who are more ambitious.'

I'm nodding, perhaps too vigorously, and her eyes turn suddenly sharp. 'Are you married?' I tell her I'm not. 'Well, not to worry, you've plenty of time.' She smiles, with a touch of benevolence. It seems a curious comment from someone who speaks of her own marriage as 'disastrous', never considered remarrying and tells, quite matter-of-factly, of having had 'lots of affairs'. I ask how she endeavours to keep in touch with new generations of readers.

'Ah, one can never be sure of that. You can only hope for the best - the thing is not to bore myself. I watch television, so I do know what's going on. We have Sky News, CNN and BBC World,' she says, proudly.

She also reads contemporary fiction, when it's sent her way. On the coffee table is a proof of Toby Litt's forthcoming novel. 'Do you know this writer? Terribly good. Word of mouth matters more than reviews.'

But does her semi-reclusive life in Italy mean that she is now obliged to draw on past experience and memory for her fiction? 'I've often wondered that - am I just left with my past? But no - the next novel I'm writing has nothing to do with my past. Well, only in the way that everything draws on your past to an extent, but this is a totally new thing.'

It's only when a tentative boy arrives with more flowers that I glance at my watch and realise we've been talking for half an hour past the allotted time. 'Now that we've met,' she says, getting to her feet, 'you must come and visit us in Italy, we'd love that, wouldn't we, Pen?' Dame Muriel may not be sentimental, she may be single-minded, unflinching and possessed of a wit that slices like cheesewire, but her splinter of ice is hidden under a warm and generous exterior.

webTitle: Players will lose in transfer roulette

fields.headline: Players will lose in transfer roulette
fields.trailText: The vision of players laughing all the way to the bank - even more heartily than many of them might do already - is very misleading.
fields.body:
Players wield so much power nowadays that it should come as no surprise to find a number earning more from their clubs than their team managers.

When Coventry's chairman, Bryan Richardson, and I were looking through the highest wage-earners at Highfield Road last season, we found that I was as low as sixteenth on the list.

We joked that I should count myself lucky, on the grounds that at least I was higher in the table than Bryan.

I have become used to this at Coventry. When I was player-manager, and taking part in matches at the age of 39 or 40, it was a source of amusement to me (if 'amusement' is the right word) that members of my squad were able to pick up more than me even when they were watching a match from the stands.

However, managers like me will not be in this situation if and when European football is forced by the EU to scrap transfer fees. Then, instead of managers being the poor relations, it will be the players. It has been argued that the end of the transfer system as we know it can only mean more money in the already full pockets of players. I beg to differ and, like Crystal Palace's manager Alan Smith in his column last week, I think that the vision of players laughing all the way to the bank - even more heartily than many of them might do already - is very misleading.

For me, the reality behind the principle of players being treated like any other workers under EU laws - being able to end their contracts whenever they wish to do so, and without transfer fees involved - is that the players will generally suffer as much as the clubs.

The players at the top level - the stars at places such as Manchester United, Liverpool and Arsenal - will get richer. In terms of funding players' salaries, transfer market income is comparatively unimportant to clubs of that financial stature because of the money they rake in from gate receipts, TV, corporate hospitality and merchandising.

It is a different story at most of the other clubs in England. To varying degrees, they all rely on the money they can make in the transfer market to keep their heads above water. Coventry are as good an example as any. I hate to think what position we would have been in today but for the £7 million profit we made through selling Robbie Keane to Inter Milan for £13 million. Had Keane not been sold, major cuts would have had to be made.

There seems little doubt that the inability of clubs to indulge in the transfer-market wheeling and dealing, which has been an integral part of the culture of the professional game, will result in the vast majority of players having to settle for much less money than they are getting now. It will surely hasten the move of the top clubs into a European super league, and widen the already massive gap between them and the rest of the professional football cast in England.

I think there is a lot to be said for some measure of sanity being restored to English football with regards to players' salaries. A lot of clubs are already spending more in this department than they can afford, so it can be argued that any legislation that might have the effect of bringing wages down to a more realistic level should be applauded.

However, I find it very difficult to look upon the EU's position as being good for European football. Of course, nothing has yet been decided, and until it is and we have everything down in black and white we can only make an educated guess at the final outcome. The initial interpretations of how it could all end up are, however, disconcerting to say the least.

For example, one argument is that if players are able to break their ties with a club more easily, it will also be easier for clubs to get rid of them. I can envisage a situation whereby clubs, in order to cut wage costs during the summer, would keep paying their best players but lay off the others with the view of re-hiring them - at a lower price - before the start of the new season.

Anyone who has been out of work for two or three months will appreciate how easy it can be to accept almost any offer to get back. There are a lot of cases of clubs being forced to honour the contracts of players they do not want, cases of players who - because of the money they are on - are quite happy to stay put even if it means not being in the first-team squad.

These days, one has to have a very good reason for releasing players, and even then, the decision can take you into a legal minefield. About 18 months ago, the 30 schoolboy players we released from our School of Excellence included an Asian lad. As with the others, we did not think he was of the required standard - it was as simple as that. But, amazingly, we have found ourselves being taken to court for racial discrimination. And I am particularly concerned about the danger of managers and players becoming impetuous.

If players run into problems with their clubs, I am not sure that they will be as prepared to tackle and overcome them as they might have been before. As for the managers, the best way I can sum it up is to say that when Coventry are beaten, and have not played well, my first reaction is to get rid of six players. I think we all feel that way initially - but by Monday morning, the hitlist has been reduced to three and by the following Friday, there is nobody on it at all and you are friends with everyone again. If getting rid of players was made easier for me, I am not sure that this would be the case.

I leave it to you to decide whether the players most at risk would be those earning more money than me.

fields.headline: Arsenal chief sounds transfer warning
fields.trailText: The Arsenal vice-chairman David Dein yesterday added his voice to those who fear that proposed changes to the transfer system will mean extinction for numerous small clubs.
fields.body:
The Arsenal vice-chairman David Dein yesterday added his voice to those who fear that proposed changes to the transfer system will mean extinction for numerous small clubs.

Speaking on the BBC's Breakfast With Frost programme, Dein said that the changes, which would enable players to switch clubs without commanding a transfer fee, will rob small clubs of their financial lifeline.

"Perhaps more than 20 or 30 small clubs will go to the wall," he said. "Clubs like Barnet simply can't survive if they can't sell their players to higher clubs.

"We can't have players moving at will every year. That would be nonsense. The industry needs stability. Where's the job security for the manager? It takes years to put a team together. And where's the stability for the fans who go out and buy David Beckham or Dennis Bergkamp shirts?"

webTitle: Revealed: bitter truth of Blair-Brown feud

fields.headline: Revealed: bitter truth of Blair-Brown feud
fields.standfirst:
The Euro debate - Observer special

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: A devastating portrait of the political and personal rivalries between Tony Blair and Gordon Brown, the two most powerful men in Britain, is revealed in today's  Observer.
fields.body:
A devastating portrait of the political and personal rivalries between Tony Blair and Gordon Brown, the two most powerful men in Britain, is revealed in today's Observer.

In the definitive account of their relationship during New Labour's first term in office, Andrew Rawnsley, this newspaper's chief political commentator, discloses in a new book that the Prime Minister and his Chancellor have regular raging arguments, which have threatened to derail the Government's most important policies.

The book, Servants of the People, serialisation of which begins today, says that the relationship between the two would often descend into petulant battles over who had the greatest authority. Blair and Brown both vied for the Labour leadership after John Smith died in 1994.

Rawnsley, who was given unprecedented access to senior officials and Ministers in government, reveals that the feuding extended to Blair being left in the dark by Brown over sensitive issues, such as the euro and the Budget. Supporters of both sides - Blairites and Brownites - would stoop to anything to beat the other camp.

The Prime Minister would shout in frustration at the way Brown operated and often explained Brown's mode of working with psychological theories, saying once that 'Gordon's problem is that he does not have a family'.

The book throws new light on the deep faults and brooding tensions at the heart of the New Labour Government and for the first time exposes the true scale of the divisions between Blair and Brown, which officials have hitherto tried to deny.

Ahead of publication, Labour officials signalled their concern that such a public airing of the most damaging details of the two men's relationship will undermine the New Labour image, which is being carefully constructed ahead of the party's conference in a fortnight.

The book reveals that:

 Brown wanted to sack the Governor of the Bank of England, Eddie George, in 1997 because he saw him as a threat. Blair had to telephone George personally to make sure he remained in post and prevent the markets collapsing.

 Blair often lost his temper with Brown's plotting and manoeuvring, saying 'God, Gordon can be impossible' and exploding: 'Jesus. What has Gordon done now?'. He said the Chancellor was often un-cooperative.

 On a fundamental change in policy on the euro in 1997, Blair was left completely in the dark and had to have Brown's new policy read over the phone to him from an article in a newspaper.

 Brown threatened to resign earlier this year over a pro-euro speech by Peter Mandelson, the Secretary of State for Northern Ireland, who has fallen out repeatedly with the Chancellor.

 Blair and Brown rowed over increases in health spending after the Prime Minister announced on a Sunday morning television programme that Britain's health bud get should be brought up to the European Union average. Brown was so furious with the Prime Minister he shouted at him: 'You've stolen my f****** Budget.'

 Blair was so angry with Brown's one-time chief press spokesman, Charlie Whelan, about pro-Treasury briefings on Government policy, that he repeatedly said he would force him out. When he failed to do so, Blair became an object of ridicule among his own senior aides. Whelan was finally forced out by Blair after details of Mandelson's home loan from Paymaster General Geoffrey Robinson became public.

In a disclosure that will infuriate the Blair camp, the book reveals that Brown is unimpressed with the Prime Minister's economic abilities and always knew he could beat him in an economic argument. 'Tony wants to tax less, spend more and borrow less,' the book quotes Brown as saying. 'Our job is to make it add up for him.'

The book, which is meticulously sourced at the highest level, also deals with the row over leaks about Brown's 'psychological flaws' - a comment Rawnsley says was made by someone 'with an extremely good claim to know the mind of the Prime Minister'.

Although Rawnsley does not reveal who made the comment, he does rule out Mandelson, who some blamed at the time. The book makes no comment on allegations that Alastair Campbell was the source, something that has been strenuously denied by the Prime Minister's official spokesman.

It does say that Brown, who confronted Blair about the remarks which he believed had come from someone in No 10, believed Blair was lying when he said he did not know who made them.

The book says Brown has harboured a burning resentment about the remarks ever since.

Brown's desire to get rid of the Governor of the Bank of England, who is still in position, will shock the markets. Brown wanted to give independence to the bank, a move he bounced on Blair in the first few days after the general election.

Blair supported the move, but did not know that Brown wanted to act immediately. Brown thought that George could be disloyal.

The most remarkable revelation centres on Government policy on the euro, which the book reveals descended into a shambles during 1997. Brown decided, after a five-minute phone call with Blair, that the policy needed to be 'clarified' in an interview with the Times political editor, Philip Webster.

The story was spun to suggest that Brown ruled out membership of the euro for the lifetime of the parliament, one of the most important Government statements on Europe since the general election.

Blair was unaware that Brown was going to make such a significant move and was stranded at his country home, Chequers, when the Times article was published.

The first the Prime Minister knew about the fundamental shift was when Mandelson rang him and read out the article.

Blair was furious but when he tried to contact Brown and Campbell, both had gone incommunicado. With his own press secretary having gone missing, Blair was left to telephone Whelan, who was briefing journalists about the policy change on a mobile phone outside a pub.

Nor have relations improved between Blair and Brown. The book reveals that the rows between the two men have infected the whole history of the Government up to the present.

Brown wanted to make a big announcement on health in the Budget last March but a flu crisis in January and criticisms about standards in the health service by New Labour peer Professor Robert Winston meant that Blair wanted to say something positive earlier in the year.

In an interview on Breakfast with Frost he made the European Union cash pledge. Brown was angry that the centrepiece of his Budget had been revealed and also that the amounts being talked about (£16 billion) were so high when he had yet to make a final decision.

In a further twist to the levels of discord in government, the book also reveals that Mo Mowlam turned down the post of Health Secretary in her bid to become first Foreign Secretary and then Defence Secretary.

Mowlam, who announced last week that she was resigning, then offered to fight Ken Livingstone for Mayor of London, even though Frank Dobson was already the official Labour candidate.

However, it is the disclosures about Brown and Blair that are of greatest interest. Rawnsley explains the remarkably fraught relationship between the Prime Minister and the Chancellor with reference to Brown's failure to become Prime Minister.

'The itch that Brown could not stop himself scratching was the smouldering resentment that Blair had taken the first prize of politics,' the book says.
fields.bodyText: A devastating portrait of the political and personal rivalries between Tony Blair and Gordon Brown, the two most powerful men in Britain, is revealed in today's Observer. In the definitive account of their relationship during New Labour's first term in office, Andrew Rawnsley, this newspaper's chief political commentator, discloses in a new book that the Prime Minister and his Chancellor have regular raging arguments, which have threatened to derail the Government's most important policies. The book, Servants of the People, serialisation of which begins today, says that the relationship between the two would often descend into petulant battles over who had the greatest authority. Blair and Brown both vied for the Labour leadership after John Smith died in 1994. Rawnsley, who was given unprecedented access to senior officials and Ministers in government, reveals that the feuding extended to Blair being left in the dark by Brown over sensitive issues, such as the euro and the Budget. Supporters of both sides - Blairites and Brownites - would stoop to anything to beat the other camp. The Prime Minister would shout in frustration at the way Brown operated and often explained Brown's mode of working with psychological theories, saying once that 'Gordon's problem is that he does not have a family'. The book throws new light on the deep faults and brooding tensions at the heart of the New Labour Government and for the first time exposes the true scale of the divisions between Blair and Brown, which officials have hitherto tried to deny. Ahead of publication, Labour officials signalled their concern that such a public airing of the most damaging details of the two men's relationship will undermine the New Labour image, which is being carefully constructed ahead of the party's conference in a fortnight. The book reveals that:  Brown wanted to sack the Governor of the Bank of England, Eddie George, in 1997 because he saw him as a threat. Blair had to telephone George personally to make sure he remained in post and prevent the markets collapsing.  Blair often lost his temper with Brown's plotting and manoeuvring, saying 'God, Gordon can be impossible' and exploding: 'Jesus. What has Gordon done now?'. He said the Chancellor was often un-cooperative.  On a fundamental change in policy on the euro in 1997, Blair was left completely in the dark and had to have Brown's new policy read over the phone to him from an article in a newspaper.  Brown threatened to resign earlier this year over a pro-euro speech by Peter Mandelson, the Secretary of State for Northern Ireland, who has fallen out repeatedly with the Chancellor.  Blair and Brown rowed over increases in health spending after the Prime Minister announced on a Sunday morning television programme that Britain's health bud get should be brought up to the European Union average. Brown was so furious with the Prime Minister he shouted at him: 'You've stolen my f****** Budget.'  Blair was so angry with Brown's one-time chief press spokesman, Charlie Whelan, about pro-Treasury briefings on Government policy, that he repeatedly said he would force him out. When he failed to do so, Blair became an object of ridicule among his own senior aides. Whelan was finally forced out by Blair after details of Mandelson's home loan from Paymaster General Geoffrey Robinson became public. In a disclosure that will infuriate the Blair camp, the book reveals that Brown is unimpressed with the Prime Minister's economic abilities and always knew he could beat him in an economic argument. 'Tony wants to tax less, spend more and borrow less,' the book quotes Brown as saying. 'Our job is to make it add up for him.' The book, which is meticulously sourced at the highest level, also deals with the row over leaks about Brown's 'psychological flaws' - a comment Rawnsley says was made by someone 'with an extremely good claim to know the mind of the Prime Minister'. Although Rawnsley does not reveal who made the comment, he does rule out Mandelson, who some blamed at the time. The book makes no comment on allegations that Alastair Campbell was the source, something that has been strenuously denied by the Prime Minister's official spokesman. It does say that Brown, who confronted Blair about the remarks which he believed had come from someone in No 10, believed Blair was lying when he said he did not know who made them. The book says Brown has harboured a burning resentment about the remarks ever since. Brown's desire to get rid of the Governor of the Bank of England, who is still in position, will shock the markets. Brown wanted to give independence to the bank, a move he bounced on Blair in the first few days after the general election. Blair supported the move, but did not know that Brown wanted to act immediately. Brown thought that George could be disloyal. The most remarkable revelation centres on Government policy on the euro, which the book reveals descended into a shambles during 1997. Brown decided, after a five-minute phone call with Blair, that the policy needed to be 'clarified' in an interview with the Times political editor, Philip Webster. The story was spun to suggest that Brown ruled out membership of the euro for the lifetime of the parliament, one of the most important Government statements on Europe since the general election. Blair was unaware that Brown was going to make such a significant move and was stranded at his country home, Chequers, when the Times article was published. The first the Prime Minister knew about the fundamental shift was when Mandelson rang him and read out the article. Blair was furious but when he tried to contact Brown and Campbell, both had gone incommunicado. With his own press secretary having gone missing, Blair was left to telephone Whelan, who was briefing journalists about the policy change on a mobile phone outside a pub. Nor have relations improved between Blair and Brown. The book reveals that the rows between the two men have infected the whole history of the Government up to the present. Brown wanted to make a big announcement on health in the Budget last March but a flu crisis in January and criticisms about standards in the health service by New Labour peer Professor Robert Winston meant that Blair wanted to say something positive earlier in the year. In an interview on Breakfast with Frost he made the European Union cash pledge. Brown was angry that the centrepiece of his Budget had been revealed and also that the amounts being talked about (£16 billion) were so high when he had yet to make a final decision. In a further twist to the levels of discord in government, the book also reveals that Mo Mowlam turned down the post of Health Secretary in her bid to become first Foreign Secretary and then Defence Secretary. Mowlam, who announced last week that she was resigning, then offered to fight Ken Livingstone for Mayor of London, even though Frank Dobson was already the official Labour candidate. However, it is the disclosures about Brown and Blair that are of greatest interest. Rawnsley explains the remarkably fraught relationship between the Prime Minister and the Chancellor with reference to Brown's failure to become Prime Minister. 'The itch that Brown could not stop himself scratching was the smouldering resentment that Blair had taken the first prize of politics,' the book says.

fields.standfirst:
Surrey 453-4 dec
Durham 241 and 144
Surrey won by an innings and 68 runs
fields.trailText:
Surrey 453-4 dec

Durham 241 and 144
Surrey won by an innings and 68 runs.
fields.body:
It seemes after only 20 minutes' play that champagne corks would be popping in the home team's dressing room here for the second time in a week. Alex Tudor had dismissed Jon Lewis and Simon Katich, Durham's principal batsman, with successive balls.

One requisite for Surrey clinching the title on the day was met within the first hour after lunch, in that Durham, who had inflicted on the champions a heavy defeat in the opening match of their campaign, had this time bowed the knee.

Lancashire, however, were less co-operative, capturing a full hand of bonus points. Now the only way the issue could be settled before sunset was if the pitches committee, convened to sit in judgment on the state of the Old Trafford strip later in the day, imposed a points penalty.

But the scenes enacted in front of the pavilion here suggested that the championship was again in Surrey's bag. Their supporters gathered under their balcony, chanting and cheering, and the players came out to join in the celebrations. They were indeed premature, for Lancashire were on their way to a fifth batting point and, weather permitting, a likely victory.

The light, when play began, was only just bright enough for Adam Hollioake to throw Alex Tudor into the attack at the Vauxhall End. With his third ball he had Lewis, caught on the crease, lbw and then greeted Katich with one that left him late to find the edge.

Tudor was not kept in the attack for long and Saqlain Mushtaq bowled three uneventful overs before Tudor returned. But Ian Salisbury, Durham's tormentor in the first innings, wheeled away from the Pavilion End. Trying to stop a violent straight pull by Michael Gough off his own bowling, he deflected the ball on to the stumps with non-striker Paul Collingwood out of his crease and Durham, who were following on 212 runs behind, were 30 for three.

Salisbury also participated in Gough's dismissal by holding a low catch at extra-cover from a drive at Tudor and then toppled Jimmy Daley, who offered no stroke to a prodigious googly. But his control and venom diminished as the morning wore on, and Durham took lunch without suffering any further casualties.

It was not that the partnership that held up Surrey for 23 overs was entirely secure. Andrew Pratt, left-handed, was either playing and missing against Tudor or making contact with the edge and collecting boundaries, which inflated his contribution to 31.

Also, he had got away with a chance to short-leg before he had scored, and then sliced a drive which bisected the gap between first and second slips at catchable height. However, Pratt's partner, Martin Speight, was completely assured. Familiar with Salisbury's bag of tricks from having kept wicket to him in their Sussex days, he eagerly preyed on anything loose. So much so that Salisbury was taken off ater conceding 18 runs in five overs after lunch.

Pratt's charmed life was ended by Martin Bicknell when he groped forward and edged to the first of two gullies, and Durham's last four wickets could resist for no more than another 38 minutes.

fields.body:
RIGHT MEN IN CHARGE

Even in South Africa, when they had the wrong team, the signs were there. The team were resilient; they rarely had two bad days in a row and were more cheerful than usual. Much guff was written about Nasser Hussain, that he was too selfish a cricketer to lead England. Even if this were true, it was irrelevant since priorities change when handed the captaincy. He has a sharp brain, a strong will and he's a realist. All he needs is to score a few runs. The more successful England become, the less we see of Duncan Fletcher, which is how it should be. Fletcher may not be that adept with a microphone in his hand, but he works well in the privacy of the training ground and the dressing room. He urges responsibility on to his captain and players.

RIGHT STRUCTURE

The expansion of the international season in England has - curiously - lightened the workload of our international cricketers. Once the programme of seven Tests plus a triangular one-day tournament was established the introduction of central contracts was inevitable. The contracts given to Dean Headley and Chris Schofield were a waste of money, but for the first time Darren Gough has got through an international season at home without injury, Andy Caddick still has an excess of fuel in his tank and the players are learning a new discipline, which will be handy on tour: preparing for the big game without incessant, sapping match practice. Some counties may be grumpy, but if England keep winning...

RIGHT SELECTION

Fletcher trusts his own eyes, which prompted the elevation of Trescothick to the A team last winter and an unlikely central contract for Craig White this summer. They have not been afraid to reconcile quality players regardless of their chequered recent history (Dominic Cork and Graham Thorpe) and the choice of Graeme Hick at number seven at Headingley was - to the disappointment of some scribes - justified.

RIGHT OPPOSITION

Duncan Fletcher and Nasser Hussain are realists. They will know - even if they won't admit it - that their success this summer has been against two of the weakest teams on the international circuit. The Zimbabwean bowling attack is the gentlest in the world. The West Indies, despite the presence of three world-class players, are fragile with bat and ball and travel no better than the Coventry City of old. Pakistan, where England have only ever won one Test match (and that was almost 40 years ago), and Sri Lanka pose a severer threat this winter.

MICHAEL ATHERTON

Has always pined to be a match-winning batsman, not just a match-saving one and he has managed that this summer. He played two crucial innings: his 45 at Lord's and his 109 at the The Oval. Don't let anyone suggest dropping him because of a little dip in form (one or two press box sages were tempted before the last Test). More than any of the batsmen he's there when you need him.

PITCHES

In the long term, it will be a commercial and cricketing disaster unless the standard of pitches improves at Test and domestic level. Three Tests this summer have failed to reach Sunday - and it would have been four but for rain in the Lord's Test against Zimbabwe. This has deprived the game of about £2 million that it can ill afford to lose. Poor pitches with uneven bounce will also undermine our young cricketers. Batsmen will settle for a rapid, swishing 40, which might be enough to win the game. Bowlers won't bother to try to swing or spin the ball since all they have to do is plonk it on a length and wait. Hence they feel naked and neutered when they come across a proper pitch.

SPINNERS

Seamer-friendly pitches have added to the decline of spin bowling. England's seam attack has been unusually reliable and fit in all forms of cricket, but their spin 'attack' for the winter is based on a wing and a prayer and influenced too much by the fact that Ashley Giles and Ian Salisbury are 'multi-dimensional', namely that they know which end of the bat to hold. Both are unproven; Giles has minimal experience at Test level; Salisbury's record prompts a grimace - 12 Tests, 19 wickets at 70 apiece. If Fletcher and Hussain can restore Salisbury's confidence at the highest level, then they truly are magicians. This weakness could easily be exposed this winter.

KEEPER

Alec Stewart may be indispensable, but he's not indestructible. A broken finger could upturn the balance of the England side at any moment and at some point old age will set in. England don't know who will replace him. Each winter they try someone new; it was Warren Hegg in Australia, Chris Read in South Africa and this winter Paul Nixon, fiercely competitive but limited and already in his thirtieth year. Finding the right replacement is a high priority.

AUSTRALIA

They're coming next summer. England may be getting better but they are still a long way off the standard set by the Australians over the past five years.
