fields.headline: Lloyd's effort in vain
fields.standfirst:
Somerset 163 and 65-4
Lancashire 463-9 dec
fields.trailText:
Somerset 163 and 65-4
Lancashire 463-9 dec.
fields.body:
Nominally Lancashire's opponents were Somerset, who didn't provide much resistance as the home side pursued their seventh Championship victory of the season. The real tussle was with Surrey, who 200 miles down south were striving to polish off Durham. Lancashire couldn't do much about that.

Lancashire were over-dependent on Durham's batsmen producing a defiant rearguard action at The Oval, which was asking too much. For only if Surrey failed to beat Durham would Lancashire have a chance of overhauling them in the Championship in the final fixture of the season at Old Trafford between the two counties. There was another source of concern: the pitch inspectors were in town and in force.

Yesterday Mike Denness was joined by AC Smith and the old groundsman Tom Flintoff. There were suggestions that the pitch was damp on the first day when 13 wickets fell. As the Lancashire total sped past 400 it seemed unlikely that any penalty would be imposed. Certainly there were no complaints from the Somerset camp, who acknowledged that they had batted poorly on Friday albeit in unhelpful, but not unfair conditions.

They did not bowl any better as Lancashire secured maximum batting points without much bother - and this was despite the early departure of Mike Atherton. His dismissal was noteworthy. For one ball Jamie Cox stationed Mark Lathwell in an old-fashioned position on the leg-side at close leg-gully. In came Steffan Jones and Atherton deflected the ball straight into Lathwell's hands. Judging from Atherton's reaction I would wager he did not realise the fielder was there. Getting him to admit that might be tricky.

In Jones's next over he found the inside edge of Schofield swishing bat and Somerset were briefly back in the game. However Graham Lloyd soon swatted them out of contention again. He was badly dropped by Jason Kerr at mid-on on 57 off the persevering Jones but then he swashbuckled his way to 126. Lloyd can be one of the most destructive players on the county circuit on his day as he punches the ball square of the wicket. Now he does not always get into the first team.

With acting captain Warren Hegg producing another impish innings this pair added a rapid 152 runs against a wayward attack. After lunch Cox tried his seventh bowler of the day, Michael Burns, who immediately won an lbw appeal against Lloyd. This gave Somerset a second bowling point, which ensured their survival in the First Division next year - quite clever really since they have only won two championship games. There are some virtues in playing on decent pitches. However their cricket chairman is adamant that they intend to win more games next season.

Glen Chapple helped add another 69 with Hegg before he was finally bowled off the inside edge by Jones; Gary Keedy was victim to a spectacular, diving catch by Adrian Pierson at point but this did not stop Hegg guiding his side to 400 and that fifth batting point and reaching his first hundred for four years.

However if we assume that Lancashire take 20 points from this game - which they surely will after their seamers reduced a hapless Somerset to 65 for four in the final session - they will still be 19 points behind Surrey. The mathematicians may tell us that they have a chance of overtaking Surrey. In reality they haven't.

Even if Lancashire posted a total of 400 for 2 in their first innings at Old Trafford later this week, Surrey could declare their first innings closed at the fall of their fifth wicket and this denial of two bowling points would be enough to stay ahead of Lancashire. Forget the mathematicians; Surrey can crack open the champagne.

fields.headline: Irish legacy from Gatt
fields.trailText: Mike Gatting may be departing from lowly Middlesex, but he leaves in place a signing that may represent a major accomplishment. Ed Joyce, a young left-hander who has only recently made his first-team debut, could become the most exotic of cricketers, an Irishman playing for England.
fields.body:
Mike Gatting may be departing from lowly Middlesex, but he leaves in place a signing that may represent a major accomplishment. Ed Joyce, a young left-hander who has only recently made his first-team debut, could become the most exotic of cricketers, an Irishman playing for England.

Gatting has compared Joyce's stroke-making to that of David Gower, while Warwickshire's coach, Bob Woolmer, has been reminded of Graeme Pollock. Joyce's head is not turned, though. He's committed to a 2001 summer of final geography and economics exams at Dublin's Trinity College - and to the Irish cricketing cause in a World Cup qualifying tournament.

That doesn't mean he can't also play for England - like Gavin Hamilton, who did so after representing Scotland, another 'associate' cricketing nation. But he has to live four consecutive years in Britain - to Gatting that's frustrating.

*****

Extending the replay umpire's role to include lbw decisions will definitely lead to more lbws and lower scores, says Dickie Bird. 'I'm sad that I'm seeing this happen,' he tells me. 'The third umpire will now become more important than the umpire in the middle. It's certainly not sport.'

*****

Ridley Jacobs won't be able to repeat the catch that claimed Nasser Hussain in the first innings at The Oval. The ball was caught in the pouch-like webbing between thumb and index finger, and from the start of the 'winter' season the new laws ban such gloves. They state that there can be a flat strip linking thumb and forefinger, to give support, but it can't be elasticated or form a pouch.

*****

A full house on each of the last Test's five days meant a healthy total of 92,500 spectators and a gate of £1.57 million - could that, then, dictate extra Tests at The Oval?

'Extremely unlikely,' says a spokesman for the England Cricket Board. 'We could play all Tests in London, if it was only about gates. But we want a geographic spread to foster the game all around the country.'

webTitle: How the figures added up for Nasser's men

fields.headline: How the figures added up for Nasser's men
fields.trailText: Bowlers are winners; batsmen are losers in the thrilling Wisden Trophy series.
fields.body:
Of all the specialist batsmen who played in the recent series, only Marcus Trescothick is a winner. He alone has improved his Test average - and that is only because, not having one to start with, 47.5 can be said to be an improvement. But everyone else, Englishmen and West Indians alike, came off the worse.

In our table below, the 'Comp' figure shows how the player's series average compares with his Test career average at the start of the series. Of course, minus figures are comparative. Michael Atherton's is fairly small, and over the span of a long, 187-innings Test career has a negligible impact of only a few decimal points.

Even the young man who ended up top of the visitors' batting averages, Ramnaresh Sarwan, was some way below his overall Test figures. That, though, was because his is a fledgling career, comprising just four previous innings, two of them not out, for an average of 55.5. At least, one assumes that figure was a little unrealistic. It is possible that what we saw in England 2000 will be a blip at the start of a very great career.

Like Sarwan's, the career of Wavell Hinds is also in its infancy. In his case, it may remain there if his disappointments this summer prove too much. The preceding series against Pakistan had provided a flying start to his Test career, and an average of 58.4. Now, a figure of 16.3 means there was no bigger loser in this series - though Hussain and Ramprakash might seem to run him close.

For the bowlers, of course, a minus figure is very good news, and nearly all of them were winners. There was dramatic improvement for Dominic Cork and Craig White, but the biggest winner was surely Courtney Walsh: all those wickets, nine more than anyone else, and at an average that very nearly halved his career benchmark.

But there were four English bowlers who averaged under - well under - 25 a wicket, and only two West Indians. Significantly, in this summer of ball-dominance, Reon King and Franklyn Rose bucked the trend and ended up with worse averages. With Robert Croft, they finished among the summer's many losers.

fields.headline: England pair in 'fix' report
fields.trailText: Illegal Indian bookies have repeatedly told investigators from the country's Central Bureau of Investigation that one of the most prominent English cricketers of the past 10 years has been mixed up in match-fixing.
fields.body:
Illegal Indian bookies have repeatedly told investigators from the country's Central Bureau of Investigation that one of the most prominent English cricketers of the past 10 years has been mixed up in match-fixing.

A CBI interim report into match-fixing will be issued on 29 September and is expected to name two England players and three from Pakistan. Officers from the CBI were in England as part of their investigations recently.

'The same name has cropped up again and again,' said an Indian media executive who was forced to leave his job for his dealings with bookmakers but who retains close links with cricket authorities.

'All the illegal bookmakers in the country are cooperating with the police and all of them seem to give the same name. They are singing like canaries.

'Some of them have alleged that their association with this cricketer goes back to the England tour of 1992-93.'

fields.headline: New 'beach ball' perplexes goalies
fields.trailText: The most disappointing news of the week was that Tony Blair should take time out from the UN millennium summit in New York to chat about transfer fees with fellow European leaders.
fields.body:
The most disappointing news of the week was that Tony Blair should take time out from the UN millennium summit in New York to chat about transfer fees with fellow European leaders.

For Blair to be concerned about something as trivial as football transfers during a conference dedicated to freeing people from the scourge of war and striving for an equitable world is doubly worrying. First, it betokens a lack of perspective. Surely the people of Rwanda have slightly more pressing concerns than those afflicting an advantaged minority fretting over their contract details. Second, it is an ugly sign that football might become an election issue.

Labour will go all out for footie-related photo shoots however crass. The Tories, meanwhile, will toe the Rangers line: in Europe, technically, but not for very long nor in any meaningful sense.

The shame of it is is that Blair needn't have bothered. Red cards were the first burning issue of this nascent football season, transfers the second, but the world has moved on. Now, the talking point is the new Nike ball.

As Silvinho proved at Stamford Bridge, it curves, it swerves, it busts the net. It's almost as if those clever peo ple at Nike have affixed some magnetic device within it to ensure an all-singing, all-scoring, all-Nike-boot-selling game.

So far this season there are 3.14 goals in a Premiership match - way above average. The goalies are disconsolate. Everton keeper Paul Gerrard says: 'There is a difference between the new Nike ball and the Mitre ball we used last season. The Nike ball is lighter and it moves through the air a lot faster. It also swerves like hell.

'The Mitre ball was heavier and it had a truer line through the air. The Nike swerves all over the place, but the one advantage for keepers is that you can kick it further. My goal-kicks are reaching the other penalty area at times and that's a good thing.' Certainly for Everton fans who, with Duncan Ferguson injured, were beginning to wonder where the goals might come from.

David Seaman, a goalkeeper who is an excuse short of an explanation, cannot agree fast enough.

'It's an exciting season but not for the goalies... There are a lot of goals going in and a lot of strange ones at that. I saw Benito Carbone's against Chelsea. People slagged off Ed de Goey but that ball has gone all over the place. It can make you look a fool. There is a massive difference. It's like one of those balls you buy on the beach for a quid. It moves around from side to side and everywhere.'

The Manchester United coach, Steve McClaren, chimes in: 'They have done certain tests and it moves through the air faster. Our players have noticed that it does fly.'

Something is clearly up, so I confidently predict that you will hear 'Oohhh yesss, that surely must be a contender for goal of the season' at least a dozen times between now and the end of the Olympics.

fields.headline: Said & Done
fields.standfirst: The Observer's football gossip column
fields.trailText: The Observer's football gossip column.
fields.body:
Tantrums in Florence

Are these the bitterest fans in football? Supporters of Fiorentina - furious about the £22.8m sale of hairy icon Gabriel Batistuta earlier this year - have walked out on the club. Last season Fiorentina sold 32,505 season tickets. This year they've barely scraped 5,000. Batistuta's departure in June was the most violently received transfer of recent times. When the Argentine announced his plans, fans began days of massive 'Please don't go' riots: three Molotov cocktails were thrown at the office of club president Vittorio Cecchi Gori, 500 fans surrounded the stadium, and 50 others held a candle-light vigil outside Batistuta's villa with a banner declaring: 'Florence loves you. You love Florence. So why leave?' Money would seem to have been a factor - but the fans remain appalled. Now, upset again by the appointment of unglamorous Turkish coach Faith Terim and his subsequent failure to sign Barcelona's Boudewijn Zenden, fans have deserted the club in droves, and more direct action could follow. In 1990, Roberto Baggio moved to rivals Juventus, and was the subject of furious death threats - almost fulfilled when a group of fans broke into the Italian national camp in Coverciano to try to reach him. If Fiorentina win their first couple of games, season ticket sales will no doubt recover. If not, it'll be a quiet few months at the Artemio Franchi.

Divine Bambino: cash rolls in

Vincenzo Sarno - the Italian preteen 'Bambino of God' profiled in Said & Done in January last year - has returned home to Napoli after his remarkable £50,000 move to Turin broke down. Vincenzo, discovered by Europe's money men after scouts reported a ten-year-old miniature Maradona with perfect ball control, joined Torino - 500 miles from home - when the club offered his unemployed father a car, a house and tens of millions of lira. 'You don't realise what this adventure means for us,' protested father Ernesto when the move was condemned as 'soccer paedophilia'. 'I haven't slept in days. I stay awake at night thinking, "The new Maradona was born in my house." I can't believe it.' But less than a year after the boy's first training session in Turin, financial disputes and an unhappy Vincenzo ('My friends miss me') have forced the family home. But he won't be there for long. After a recent promotional tour of New York, where the youngster made the rounds of the morning talk shows, little Vincenzo is again the subject of interest from Roma and Juventus. And with all the money from the Turin move gone, Ernesto's keen to do business. 'This season he'll be in a soccer school in Napoli,' he says. 'He can have a break. But he's still young - only 12. We have time.'

Rooms with a pew

Twenty-two nuns have opened a bed and breakfast at their Merseyside convent in an attempt to cash in on fans visiting Liverpool and Everton. The Augustinian Sisters hope the venture will provide much-needed resources, and encourage supporters to stay and pray. 'We decided to open a guesthouse to help us pay the bills,' says Sister Carmel, deputy mother superior. 'Our location means we should get a lot of trade.' The nuns are charging £20 for bed and breakfast, and £5 extra for a homemade dinner, served by the sisters. 'We think this is good value,' said Sister Carmel. Important facts for prospective guests : Saint Augustine, Bishop of Hippo, North Africa, died in 430BC, and is patron saint of brewers. Key Augustinian rules: 1. Chant only what is prescribed for chant; moreover, let nothing be chanted unless it is so prescribed. 2. Subdue the flesh, so far as your health permits, by abstinence from drink. 3. Although your eyes may chance to rest upon some woman or other, you must not fix your gaze. An abomination to the Lord is he who fixes his gaze. There's space for 30 guests - Manchester United are in town next week.

King Kev cleans up

The tenth edition of Private Eye 's Colemanballs is published in November - with precedence and the front cover given over to the increasingly profound Kevin Keegan...

Kev on England: 'England can end the millennium as they started it - as the greatest football nation in the world'; Kev on goalkeepers: 'Goalkeepers aren't born today until they're in their late twenties or thirties'; Kev on refs: 'The ref was vertically 15 yards away'; Kev on 2004: 'The 33 or 34-year-olds will be 36 or 37 by the time the next World Cup comes around, if they're not careful'; Kev on fire: '...using his strength. And that is his strength, his strength'; and most remarkable of all, Kev on his own: 'I have talked with Phil Neville and he knows that he has never let me down.' Colemanballs 10 will be published by Private Eye Books, priced £3.99.

Role model of the week

Twenty minutes before his second ever Everton start at White Hart Lane last Tuesday, Paul Gascoigne was spotted by curious young fans smoking a pre-match cigarette. Time, clearly, for an England recall.

Tales from the Tabs

CHELSEA'S £10m SAVIO Brazilian star Savio is desperately trying to secure a French passport in an attempt to salvage his £10m move to Chelsea. Gianluca Vialli bid for the classy Real Madrid left winger last week, but, says chief executive Colin Hutchison: 'We're aware of complications over a work permit.'

ARSèNE PRICE BUSTER Arsenal have put a massive bid for Sunderland's Kevin Phillips on hold with a view to signing him on a free if the transfer system is abolished in October. Arsène Wenger had been preparing a £15m deal - now he'll wait, and Phillips is keen: 'To play at Highbury is still a big dream of mine.'

GARETH: I'LL STAY, THEN Gareth Southgate is ready to tear up his Aston Villa transfer request after coming to terms with no one wanting to pay £8m for him. 'Nothing's happening on the transfer front and I just have to get my head round that,' says Southgate. 'If the deadlock remains I may just have to readjust my thinking.'

And the rest...

Arsène Wenger has told Arsenal chairman Peter Hill-Wood he'll consider extending his contract until 2004. 'He's been mulling it over and we're very confident,' says Hill-Wood. 'I'm happy at the moment,' says Wenger. Jermaine Pennant, meanwhile, is set to join Wolves on loan.

Doug Ellis has told Villa fans calling for his resignation to be quiet. 'John Gregory has never been refused a single penny for players he wanted to sign.'

Bradford have agreed to sell Ashley Westwood to Sheffield Wednesday for £150,000.

Charlton could miss out on Leicester's Tony Cottee after Norwich stepped up their interest.

Chelsea's Bernard Lambourde will have talks with Portsmouth over a £750,000 permanent move after joining on a month's loan.

Colin Hendry will leave Coventry this week after Gordon Strachan confirmed he won't be a regular starter.

Derby's Dean Sturridge could complete his long-awaited move to Birmingham in the next few days.

Young Everton striker Phil Jevons has been told he won't be leaving for Grimsby. 'We need him to stay here and we need him to play here and that's where he will stay', says Walter Smith.

Ipswich are leading the race to sign young Falkirk midfielder Mark Kerr - George Burley has also bid for a mystery foreign defender.

Robert Molenaar has turned down a move to Wimbledon from Leeds - the clubs had agreed a £1m fee.

Leicester boss Peter Taylor is still watching Charlton striker Andy Hunt and Bradford defender Andy O'Brien.

Liverpool's Rigobert Song is still a target for Blackburn despite Henning Berg's move from Manchester United.

Defender Richard Jobson could join Stockport from Man City on loan - Chris Killen is off to Wrexham for a month.

Manchester United officials have flown to Italy in an attempt to gazump Bari striker Antonio Cassano's move to Juventus.

Middlesbrough are set to spend again: Forest's £5m-rated youngster David Prutton, Tromso wonderkid Morten Gamst Pedersen and Colchester's Lomana Lua-Lua are top targets.

Bobby Robson won't be spending any more Newcastle cash until the future of the transfer system is determined: 'We don't want to make a move until we know what's going to happen.'

Southampton are considering a Crystal Palace bid for Matt Le Tissier after James Beattie's move to London collapsed.

Sunderland's Andy Marriot has rejected a £300,000 move to Sam Hamman's Cardiff.

Spurs have rejected a £3m offer for Steffen Iversen from Reggiana, but could sell Les Ferdinand to an unnamed Division One club to finance a big bid for Watford's Tommy Smith.

West Ham have enquired about Japanese defender Tsuneyasu Miyamoto - he'll be available for transfer when the J-League ends in December. Valencia, meanwhile, are ready to bid big for midfielder Frank Lampard.

fields.headline: Taggart on target for City
fields.trailText: Foxes again spurn Premiership goal glut to eke out deserved win.
fields.body:
While the rest of the Premiership has been feasting on a glut of goals in the first month of the season, Leicester City's output has been severely rationed.

But you will find nobody complaining at Filbert Street. Three wins and two draws from their first five matches have propelled Leicester to second place and while they have yet to encounter any of the big guns, Martin O'Neill's departure to Celtic has so far not proved to be the major loss many supporters feared.

The rugged Gerry Taggart has been instrumental in City's defence being breached just once and yesterday he again formed an imposing barrier alongside Matt Elliott.

Taggart also proved his team's match-winner, enabling Peter Taylor to put one over his pal Glenn Hoddle, the man who, when England coach, brought in Taylor to look after the under 21 side.

Frustration at a succession of wasted opportunities was beginning to grow when an in-swinging corner by Steve Guppy was bludgeoned into the net by the head of Taggart with 66 minutes gone.

It was a victory Leicester just deserved and which they would have sealed before half time but for profligate finishing. Robbie Savage and Andy Impey were both wide with close range headers, Taggart himself lost his bearings in front of goal when Darren Eadie set up the opportunity and a cross by Ade Akinbiyi was only inches away from the incoming Impey.

Southampton also had their chances but their failure to score was down more to some excellent goalkeeping by Tim Flowers.

Flowers was equal to a sharp volley from the edge of the penalty box by Hassan Kachloul, but his best work was done in the space of a few seconds when he kept out short-range efforts by the same Southampton player and Uwe Rosler.

The result was that Southampton are still looking for their first victory of a campaign which looks again as if it will prove a long and a hard one.

fields.headline: Hamann's great escape
fields.trailText: Liverpool cling on as Hamann puts seal on a captivating match.
fields.body:
For Manchester City it was yet another case of the weekend blues. Three Saturdays and three defeats for City to date this season. But make no mistake, if there is any justice in the football world, Joe Royle's team will soon begin collecting points in proportion to the entertainment they have brought to the Premiership.

Finding themselves rather harshly 2-0 down, George Weah's first goal for City and a Kevin Horlock penalty levelled matters, only for Liverpool's German midfielder Dietmar Hamann to put the finishing touch to a captivating match in the 82nd minute.

That took the tally of goals in City's five league games to 21, and while Royle's own views on the contest are unknown - he refused to attend a press conference as part of his long-standing feud with the Liverpool Echo over his treatment when manager of Everton - his opposite number spoke favourably for him.

'When you win at Leeds, as they did in midweek, that says everything,' said Gerard Houllier. 'They're well-organised, very good in the air, and use the second ball very well.

'When you look at the team they've got, with two international-calibre players up front, it will be no problem for them. They will stay up.'

It was Houllier's all- English international-calibre forward line of Emile Heskey and Michael Owen who combined for the opening goal after 11 minutes.

Owen is enjoying the sort of vein of form that will be sending that card-carrying eternal optimist Kevin Keegan into raptures ahead of the crucial World Cup qualifier against Germany at Wembley at the start of next month.

There was more than a hint of diplomacy in the praise from German manager Rudi Voller in midweek, extolling the virtues of the Liverpool striker after seeing him take his tally to six goals in three games for club and country.

But there is no doubt Owen is rapidly emerging as England's one, if not only, hope of starting their World Cup-qualifying campaign in winning style.

Ask the City defence, after Owen made it seven in four - much less than four, actually, when his appearance as an England substitute in Paris is considered.

Heskey took Rigobert Song's throw-in skilfully on his chest and separated Steve Howey and Alfie Haaland with a precise pass that sent Owen speeding through to beat Nicky Weaver with a typically composed finish from the edge of the box.

But this is a very different City team from the one who famously leaked 10 goals at Anfield in the same week - League Cup and Premiership defeats of 4-0 and 6-0 - in their last top-flight season four years ago.

Already this season their play at set pieces, from Mark Kennedy's pinpoint delivery and the aerial prowess of Paulo Wanchope, has been one of the season's most effective weapons.

It brought City two goals in the midweek win at Elland Road and could, should, have brought them at least one before the interval as they refused to be intimidated by Anfield, Owen et al.

fields.headline: Gazza's last laugh
fields.trailText: Jeffers double steals limelight as Gazza returns to Riverside.
fields.body:
Teenager Francis Jeffers scored the two goals that earned Everton their first away win of the season, but Paul Gascoigne just had to be involved on his return to the club which let him leave on a free transfer in the summer.

Gascoigne's through-ball in the 87th minute was simple and thoughtful - like much of his steady work here - and freed Jeffers to score at the second attempt after Jason Gavin had blocked on the line.

Gazza's headlong charge towards manager Walter Smith showed how much the goal meant to a player who good-naturedly warned his former Middlesbrough manager Bryan Robson beforehand: 'I'm coming to get you, gaffer.'

It can't be said that Gascoigne fully kept his promise to Robson, although he did ensure Everton's midfield ticked over as he completed 90 minutes for the first time this season and almost scored from a first-half free-kick.

Thomas Gravesen, another stout, balding midfielder from Everton, made a more positive contribution and created Jeffers' first goal, taken in style in the 54th minute after the Danish international's incisive, raking pass from inside his own half.

Still, this was a special day for Gascoigne, who may not have many more left ahead of him, and he revelled in his generous reception from a crowd who were less appreciative yesterday of the players he left behind in the summer.

Thousands were streaming out long before the final whistle and the belief exists that Robson is overloaded with strikers when his real problems lie at the back and in a midfield where Christian Karembeu is making little impression.

Middlesbrough started with three strikers, three more were among the substitutes and youngsters Andy Campbell and Alun Armstrong couldn't even make the bench. Yet their only goal came from an Everton defender.

Steve Watson volleyed it past Paul Gerrard, panicking unnecessarily as Alen Boksic crossed into an area which didn't contain a single Middlesbrough player. Watson recovered well from that setback - as did an Everton team which has thrown away leads in two away games this season.

Smith said: 'It makes a pleasant change for us to come back, but I thought we deserved it. I was pleased for Francis - he's just turned 19 and that extra year has made a big difference to him.'

Jeffers has scored six times in his last five games, one of them at the Riverside for England's under-21s. His intelligent running and crisp finishing suggested it may not be long before he is ready to step up another international level.

And Gascoigne? 'His passing was a wee bit astray at times, but he worked hard,' said Smith. 'He's put a lot in and has done it all season, but I felt the key was the way Steve Watson and David Weir handled Boksic.'

Middlesbrough's defensive problems did not surprise Robson: 'My concerns before the game came to fruition. We had three defenders out there who had very little match practice - and it showed.

'That's five games and we haven't kept a clean sheet yet. Everton deserved to win in the second half and the timing of Jeffers' runs gave us problems all afternoon.'

fields.headline: Average Chelsea lacking sparkle
fields.trailText: A match to forget for the Premiership 'imposters'.
fields.byline: Paul Wilson at St James' Park
fields.body:
What looked in advance to be an appetising contest turned out to be a disappointing stalemate between two teams of imposters.

On this evidence Newcastle are flattered by their present Premiership position, and Chelsea can forget about challenging Manchester United for the title. Gianluca Vialli's astonishingly ordinary- looking team appear to have forgotten everything else. Maybe events in midweek were traumatic, but they never looked like taking the lead here, let alone losing it.

It is exactly a year since Bobby Robson took over at a club he now claims were at crisis point. Listening to the tumultuous reception for him as he collected his manager of the month award before kick-off, it was tempting to reflect how much has changed.

It is still not clear whether Robson's revitalisation of Newcastle amounts to a whole lot more than talking to his players and righting the things Ruud Gullit was doing wrong. But with the Toon at the top of the table yesterday morning, no one is complaining. Vialli, slinking almost unnoticed to his dugout, could only look on enviously. Chelsea's patchy start to the season does not amount to a crisis, but you only have to look at Vialli to know what pressure he is under.

Similarly his team have lost the swaggering self-belief necessary to convince anyone, not least opponents, they are serious championship contenders. Chelsea now are in roughly the same position as Chris Sutton of 12 months ago - short on confidence and badly in need of results.

They did not make the most auspicious start here. Daniel Cordone could have opened the scoring in the first minute when he was given time to compose himself for a shot, but Carlo Cudicini managed a comfortable save. Gary Speed should have done better with a free header from a corner at the end of the first half, but by the time the interval arrived Newcastle were a shade lucky still to be level.

Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink was uncharacteristically off-target with a header from six yards out after 35 minutes, then in the last seconds of the half Mario Melchiot rolled an inviting pass along the goal line which Tore Andre Flo was unable to convert.

Chelsea began the second half brightly too, with Shay Given saving from Jon Harley and Marcel Desailly, but the game quickly settled back into the same pattern. Newcastle had most of the play but could not work out how to score. Chelsea treated them with the respect their position, rather than their performance, deserved.

The home side came up with the best move after an hour when Kieron Dyer got inside Desailly on the right and crossed for Kevin Gallacher to head down for Gary Speed. The shot flew over the bar, but when Newcastle study the video they might conclude they could have made more of a situation in which the defence were outnumbered.

'That game needed a goal,' the reliably honest Robson conceded. A draw was fair, though, and naturally Robson was happier about that than Vialli. How the Chelsea manager must wish he could cheerfully admit, like his Newcastle counterpart, that his side are not going to win the title this season.

'We made an improvement on the last game, and if we keep doing the right things we will get some luck and start winning,' Vialli said. 'I thought the criticism after the Arsenal game was fair, it's just the way you criticise here which is hard to get used to.'

fields.headline: Wimbledon wow woeful Wednesday
fields.trailText: Five-star Dons leave Wednesday in freefall.
fields.body:
The Wombles of Wimbledon make a living clearing rubbish, but even they might have baulked at the detritus Sheffield Wednesday's defence left behind here. It took the Dons 50 minutes to find the net, but after 21-year-old Damien Francis volleyed the ball home from 10 yards when Wednesday's defence had played head tennis with Neil Ardley's corner, the floodgates opened.

John Hartson, the multi-million-pound striker no one apparently wants to buy, tarted up his shop window image. In the space of three minutes he scored twice. Both goals derived from an old-fashioned striker's determination to shrug off defenders and force a shooting chance. Andy Hinchcliffe, Des Walker and Ashley Westwood were Wednesday's guilty men, though credit to Hartson - particularly for the second of his goals which was accomplished in spite of the fact that he was never really balanced.

Then Jason Euell, left to his own devices in the six-yard box, twice taunted Kevin Pressman by rolling the ball across the keeper's diving body before scoring his first. Hartson then turned provider with an inch-perfect pass that left Euell clear for a simple shot from six yards.

Wednesday's humiliation could have been greater, with players queuing up in the closing minutes to take a whack at poor Pressman. The home defence were in ruins. Walker, for so long a prince of defenders, has lost the pace that bought him so much time, and his central defensive partner Westwood looked completely outclassed by first Hartson and then Euell.

In the first half Wednesday had shown flashes of cohesion. Their under-19 England midfielder Matthew Hamshaw had set up the club's latest Italian import, Michele Di Piedi, for a header which was wastefully off tar get. And Gerald Sibon and Phil O'Donnell both had Kelvin Davis racing to the edge of his area diving at their feet.

But for most of the game they were second best to a Wimbledon who were smarter, more skilful and more determined. Wednesday's manager, Paul Jewell, has invited his squad in for training this morning. He said: 'The players are ashamed, and rightly so. Once the first goal went in they threw the towel in. I was disgusted with their lack of commitment.'

It's always a bad sign at a League game when you can hear the players calling each other. There were acres of space at Hillsborough and the cavernous stadium is unlikely to see its terraces filled again with performances like this.

fields.headline: Canaries off song
fields.trailText: Strugglers both miss out on win that would have put gloss on worrying week.
fields.body:
These are testing times for Crewe and Norwich. Struggling towards the foot of the First Division, both are desperately in need of some good news, and neither would have been pleased with this result, which came at the end of a particularly worrying week.

Both clubs have relied on the profits made in the transfer market to sustain their success in recent years. Dario Gradi's long reign at Gresty Road has seen David Platt, Rob Lee and Neil Lennon progress on to the international stage. Danny Murphy, now at Liverpool, and Derby's Seth Johnson may yet follow them, and still the youth scheme keeps producing: eight of yesterday's squad have come through the ranks.

Norwich boast a similar pedigree. Craig Bellamy's £6million sale to Coventry last month saw him join Darren Eadie, Chris Sutton, Ruel Fox and Keith O'Neill among the list of the Canaries' recent youth-scheme graduates. The outstanding players yesterday, goalkeeper Andy Marshall and winger Lee Marshall for Norwich, and Crewe's Mark Rivers and David Wright, are all former youth team members. If the income from selling their brightest stars were to be taken away, both sides would surely struggle.

'It's a large area of concern at the moment, there's no doubt about that,' said the Norwich manager, Bryan Hamilton, after the game. 'But it's been brewing for a long time. People have been aware that the transfer system needed changing. The only question is how.'

Hamilton's chief concern is the increase in player power, with clubs increasingly helpless to hold on to them: 'I can understand players moving when they come to the end of their contract, I can understand that completely. But it's not such a good idea if players have just signed a contract for two or three years.

'It looks as if, with these changes, players are being encouraged to leave. That's a worry, but you've got to encourage young players to be responsible and to stick with the agreement they've made.'

For the moment they have little choice but to wait until a decision is made, though it will affect their dealings in the meantime as Gradi has all but ruled out spending money on any new players. 'We're always looking for new players,' he said, 'but it's unlikely that we'll do anything until we know what's going to happen. It will affect us without stopping us.' Instead, he hopes to sign Sunderland midfielder Chris Lumsden on loan this week.

Hamilton is slightly more optimistic. 'At this moment in time, to spend money, aware that the situation could change and the money would be gone, is a risk. It has to be a concern, but if the right player was available at the right price I would probably do it, and take the risk.'

Both clubs insist that the youth scheme, however, will continue, whatever happens. 'It has to affect the youth team,' said Hamilton, 'but there has to be a youth academy. There has to be a development programme at any progressive club, or at any progressive business. You've seen businesses over the years who haven't done that and they've gone belly up. So I firmly believe in development, and always will.'

How Hamilton could do with another bright young thing to roll off the production line immediately. This was Norwich's second point of the season, and his team are now bottom of the First Division having scored in just one of five league games. Their performances thus far have, however, been encouraging, and they deserved more than a draw from this game.

While Andy Marshall twice saved from point-blank range in the first half, Norwich had the more chances to score, with Darel Russell hitting the post from two yards after the Crewe defence crumbled at an 80th-minute free kick.

'We need a little bit of luck,' Hamilton said. 'We've started quite slowly, but we've been playing quite well and we shaded the game today. But you've got to keep believing, you've got to keep working, and it'll change. We just need that elusive goal. We're creating the chances - we just need to put them away.'

fields.headline: Berg gives Blackburn boost
fields.trailText: Nationwide League round-up.
fields.body:
Two high-profile Premiership defenders made their debuts on loan to Nationwide League clubs yesterday, but only one can have found it an enjoyable experience.

That was Manchester United's Henning Berg, who was back in Blackburn's colours against Nottingham Forest and ended the afternoon celebrating a 3-1 win that emphasised why Graeme Souness's team are among the favourites for promotion. It was rather different for Chelsea's Bernard Lambourde, in Portsmouth's match against Watford.

The classy 29-year-old Frenchman, who was signed by Chelsea from Bordeaux for £1.7million in June 1997, has had only moderate success in the Premiership. Even so, Portsmouth's manager, Tony Pulis, says that it took him two months to persuade him to take the step-down.

Pulis likes to think that Lambourde will grow fond enough of Fratton Park to want to make the move permanent. However, one wonders what Lambourde will have thought of the game against Watford. Portsmouth did hit the woodwork twice. But Watford proved more accurate, deservedly winning the match 3-1.

'We dominated periods of the game and could have scored even more,' said Watford's manager, Graham Taylor, whose team leapfrogged over Fulham (who play today against Barnsley) to the top of the First Division.

With Walsall losing 2-0 against Bury, Fulham are now the only team with a 100 per cent league record. In terms of the teams who have yet to be beaten, they are joined by Blackburn, Watford, Bolton, Wycombe, Bristol Rovers, Leyton Orient and Cardiff.

Bolton maintained their record with a 3-2 win at Huddersfield - a success that owed much to the finishing of their substitute Michael Ricketts. He missed Bolton's opening three matches because of suspension and Bolton's manager Sam Allardyce, said: 'He has been superb since his return. He is big and powerful, and is beginning to show that he can turn his raw potential into reality. I am convinced he can achieve something in the game, and it is our job to keep his feet on the ground.'

This is bound to be less of a problem with the key men at Norwich - the only First Division team who have yet to win. Their inevitable lack of confidence in the goalless draw against Crewe was best illustrated when Darel Russell was put clean through by an Iwan Roberts flick-on. but hit his shot against a post when it seemed easier to score.

fields.headline: Villa victory comes at cost
fields.trailText: Villa punish Ipswich errors but suffer Luc Nilis injury sickener.
fields.body:
Ipswich Town are discovering to their cost that the Premiership does not allow the same margin for error as the First Division. Like Charlton and Watford in previous years, Ipswich are well-organised, play bright football and have not been outclassed since winning promotion.

But they are in danger of suffering the same fate as those other two teams - going straight back down to the First Division - unless they learn to make the most of their chances and cut out the basic errors which have cost them dearly so far.

Having lost winnable games against Tottenham and Leicester, Ipswich blew it again despite dominating in terms of possession and chances. And they must have fancied their chances against a Villa side who had not won a game so far and were further rocked by the loss of leading players Luc Nilis and Gareth Southgate within half an hour.

The injury to Nilis was more serious, a compound fracture of the left leg that could keep him out of action for most of the season. The Belgian striker collided with Ipswich goalkeeper Richard Wright in the fourth minute, and prompted frantic gestures from the players.

Nilis, signed in the summer from PSV Eindhoven, was carried off on a stretcher with his legs strapped and taken to hospital. 'It was a compound fracture, a really nasty injury, and he went straight to hospital,' said Steve Harrison, Villa's assistant manager.

Southgate jarred his ankle after landing awkwardly and was replaced in the 28th minute, moments after Villa had taken the lead. The goal began with a misplaced pass from the Ipswich defence, seized by Paul Merson, who transferred the ball to Lee Hendrie for the midfielder to sweep a curling shot into the far corner of goal from the edge of the penalty area.

Villa's second, nine minutes into the second half, was even worse from the point of view of Ipswich manager George Burley, who watched defender Herman Hreidarsson go missing as Merson whipped in a corner, allowing Dion Dublin to head home from close range without having to jump for the ball.

Both goals came against the run of play, as Ipswich wasted chance after chance, and although substitute striker Marcus Stewart scored from close range in the final minutes, it was too little, too late.

'One or two errors cost us the points,' admitted Burley. 'All teams make mistakes, but the good ones don't make as many as us. Teams like Villa will punish basic errors that you might get away with in the lower divisions.'

'I'm more confident now than I was earlier in the season. There is no doubt we need to score more goals, but I think we can stay if we continue to show the same level of commitment.'

webTitle: Scholes on a roll with goals

fields.headline: Scholes on a roll with goals
fields.trailText: Sunderland are flattened as the champions roar back to the top.
fields.body:
For the pilgrims who come from far and wide for a day out at Old Trafford, there isn't much point in debating the outcome, merely the degree of brilliance that they will witness.

Manchester United haven't lost here in the league since December 1998, and the scent of invincibility intoxicates their adversaries almost as much as the quality of their football. So it was for Sunderland, overwhelmed by a side still below their peak but with so much to admire, particularly from Paul Scholes.

Sunderland are enduring a sobering start to the season - three defeats from their first five games - and are struggling to show the kind of bullishness which impressed the Premiership last season.

It was a sign of Alex Ferguson's respect for his opponents - or perhaps more significantly the spirit engendered by their combative manager - that he restored his most potent selection after the midweek drubbing of Bradford doled out by less experienced personnel. Out went Ronnie Wallwork, Jonathan Greening and Olympics-bound Quinton Fortune, who had all earned the manager's praise for performing with aplomb, and back strolled Scholes, Jaap Stam and Ryan Giggs.

With goalkeeper Thomas Sorensen and defensive pair Steve Bould and Stanislav Varga unavailable through injury, it was a nerve-racking afternoon for young goalkeeper Jurgen Macho.

United went for the jugular immediately, passing round, through and over the fragile rearguard. High tempo, high quality, their pacy waltz made Sunderland, by comparison, look like they were playing a dirge.

Don Hutchison, trying to help out at the back, dithered and gave the ball to Giggs. A nimble touch from Scholes released Nicky Butt, whose drive was hard and true, but slightly high. Then Andy Cole's brutal shot on the turn was too hot for Macho to handle smoothly. Fortunately for the Austrian keeper, no red shirt could capitalise. But it was coming, though - you could feel it in the Stretford air.

United were duly ahead with their next attack. Ruthlessly engineered by David Beckham, clinically finished by Scholes, the devilish cross and deft header was textbook stuff. Only another 77 minutes to withstand, Jurgen.

Scholes, on rampant form, was at the heart of a spell of continued United attacking. Before long Cole, played in by his playmaker for club and country, was presented with a fine chance to double the advantage but prodded weakly at Macho. Then Scholes pounced himself to strike an upright with ferocity. The red waves were simply smothering Sunderland.

It was hard to envisage a way back for Sunderland. Niall Quinn and Kevin Phillips were largely isolated, Kevin Kilbane's galloping run was about as good as it got, and Fabien Barthez didn't have a save to make during the first half.

There was a glimmer of hope when Hutchison netted - although it was clearly offside, it was at least the first fluent move they had managed all game. Julio Arca, the £3.5 million Argentinan teenager manager Peter Reid has waxed lyrical over, was the architect, displaying a cool touch and keen imagination.

He also appeared to knock Scholes over in the box as the second half got under way with more of the same red pressure - referee Neale Barry waved play on. Barry was more decisive when Cole was obstructed by Jody Craddock. He awarded a free-kick, in perfect Beckham range just outside the box. When Sunderland's complaints became too prolonged, the official ordered the wall back - virtually into the mouth of the goal - to give the dead-ball specialist another 10-yard advantage. To Sunderland's relief, Quinn's hardy block prevented further damage.

But for wayward finishing United would have had the points sewn up. Cole and Scholes were both guilty. Teddy Sheringham made sure when he flicked home after 75 minutes - and he needed to. But for a spectacular Barthez save, clawing away Quinn's subtle glance seconds earlier, it would have been Sunderland celebrating.

United began to enjoy themselves again and Scholes crowned a polished performance with a sensational strike from 20 yards, rising all the way, which was a joy to behold.

fields.headline: Lax Gunners lack finish
fields.trailText: Arsenal flatter to deceive against tenacious Bantams.
fields.body:
There are no prizes in football for looking good, with the obvious exception of David Ginola. And it is too early to say that Arsenal have succumbed to style over substance, but surely teams destined for success would have buried Bradford yesterday.

Arsenal finished second-best last season for losing at places such as Valley Parade so at least they are a point better off. But they had chances to win this game with ease and although Bradford defended with tenacity, Arsenal's lack of ruthlessness in front of goal almost cost them the game when Benito Carbone missed two cracking chances late on.

Arsenal manager Arsène Wenger admitted that he feared another defeat, in the fashion of their loss at Sunderland on the opening day of the season, after Stuart McCall had given Bradford an 11th-minute lead, so he was relieved to see teenager Ashley Cole equalise after 66 minutes.

Wenger said: 'We were the better team and created chance after chance, but Bradford caused us problems too.'

And what of Bradford? Unexpected survivors from their first season in the Premiership, they have now faced Liverpool, Chelsea, Manchester United and Arsenal and have five points from five games.

Manager Chris Hutchings is therefore well-placed to judge the title race, albeit early doors and all that.

'Arsenal will be up there, but Manchester United are still the team to beat,' he said with little hesitation. 'We have great spirit and now need to add quality, although it is a great bonus to get a point from a game like this. We rode our luck at times but you need that sometimes.'

Initially, the visit of Arsenal seemed to subdue rather than inspire the home support, possibly still feeling tender following their mauling at Old Trafford in the week.

Bradford did their best to enliven the locals with a fantastic musical medley before kick-off. Yesterday's offering mixed Prokofiev, Robbie Williams, The A-Team theme tune and a blast of Carmina Burana.

Stirring stuff, but only Arsenal seemed to pick up the beat as they started with a series of attacks to a wall of silence from the crowd. Thierry Henry hit a post in the second minute and his French international team-mate Sylvain Wiltord was denied a goal on his full debut when goalkeeper Matt Clarke saved the follow-up.

The chances continued to flow before Bradford produced the thunderbolt which jolted their fans into life and made it a real contest.

David Seaman had conceded a corner from a stinging Ashley Ward shot, Bradford's first of the game. Martin Keown repelled the first cross and headed out the second attempt too, but this time the ball fell at McCall's feet and he drilled the ball in from the edge of the area.

Arsenal quickly regained their composure but Bradford were playing good passing football now while Arsenal were guilty of being too elaborate in front of goal and, at times, looked as solid as jelly in defence.

But after the break they besieged the Bradford goal again. Clarke made further great saves from Henry and Parlour, while Ian Nolan and Peter Atherton both made goal-line clearances.

Arsenal were finally rewarded when Freddie Ljungberg's chip sprung Bradford's offside trap, Henry ran clear and rolled the ball to his left for Cole to stroke in from six yards.

Both sides chased victory to the end and although an Arsenal win would not have been unjust, Carbone was guilty of failing to nick a win for Bradford. A good game and possibly a telling result for both teams.

fields.headline: Sara keeps the faith
fields.trailText: Amoruso blunder proves costly as bad-tempered affair ends all square.
fields.body:
A defensive clanger loud enough to be heard back in Glasgow cost Rangers two points at Dundee. Their flighty skipper Lorenzo Amoruso was the man who dropped it, committing the cardinal sin of being dispossessed in front of his own goal. The Italian tried to be too clever on the edge of his penalty area and was robbed of the ball by Dundee substitute Juan Sara.

Sara, the Argentine who had come on only minutes earlier, managed to poke the ball past Stefan Klos and ensure that an occasionally bad-tempered game finished with honours even.

A delighted Sara promptly tugged his shirt over his head to reveal a T-shirt bearing the legend 'Jesus Loves You', rather ironic considering his team's terrible disciplinary record so far this season. Dundee had already clocked up an astonishing six red cards and 21 yellows before kick-off.

Until then it had looked likely that Neil McCann's 56th-minute strike might be the decider. The left winger, who scored Scotland's winner against Latvia in their World Cup qualifier earlier in the week, smashed a 20-yard drive past his international colleague Robert Douglas after being set up by Tugay Kerimoglu.

Rangers dominated the opening exchanges as Dundee, obviously hoping to carve chances from counter-attacks rather than numbers up front, opted to defend in strength, leaving the Argentine Fabien Caballero as a lone, and often lonely, striker.

At the other end it took Rangers' Dutch striker Michael Mols, making his first competitive start since he was injured in a collision with Bayern Munich goalkeeper Oliver Kahn 10 months ago, 20 minutes to get a sight of goal and when he did Steven Tweed was in the way.

Rangers' early pressure began to evolve into chances and Marcello Marrocco had to be calm under pressure to head away McCann's far-post cross from the left before Mols could pounce.

Mols, warmly applauded by the visiting supporters, had few chances in total though, and spent much of the game on his backside claiming fouls which were rarely given.

His manager Dick Advocaat will at least have been encouraged that he managed to last the vigorous 90 minutes, especially with Rangers' Champions League campaign beginning on Tuesday, at home against Austrian side Sturm Graz.

With the home team snapping at their heels though, Rangers had no time to think of Europe. As one might expect from a game involving bad boys Dundee, the referee was kept busy throughout.

Scott Wilson was booked for bringing down Caballero, Marco di Marchi for fouling Neil McCann and Tugay received a similar punishment for fouling Dundee player-manager Ivano Bonetti, who was at the heart of many of his side's most pleasing moments.

fields.headline: Celtic go clear
fields.trailText: Larsson brace helps awesome Celtic leapfrog Hibs to go top of the table.
fields.body:
Things just keep getting better for Celtic. Their 100 per cent start was maintained here courtesy of an emphatic victory over Hibernian, thereby replacing their Edinburgh opponents at the top of the table. News of Rangers' stumble at Dundee only enhanced the buoyant mood.

Two goals from Henrik Larsson and a late strike from substitute Mark Burchill ended Hibs' unbeaten run as Martin O'Neill's side served awesome warning of their title credentials.

O'Neill has clearly given Celtic some resilience but it was complemented here by a considerable flair and it was again Larsson who led the way.

The pressure on the Hibernian defence was relentless from the first whistle as the home side made a whirlwind start. Jackie McNamara conjured up the first clear-cut chance when he cut into the box from the right wing before shooting powerfully just past the post.

The home side's tails were clearly up and Lubomir Moravcik tried his luck from over 20 yards out in the thirteenth minute with a dipping drive which Nick Colgan did well to push over.

Celtic's confidence was replaced by concern in the 14th minute when Alan Stubbs collided with team-mate Paul Lambert and the defender was carried off.

But those worries were forgotten after 19 minutes when the home side took the lead. Colgan came rushing out to clatter into Alan Thompson on the very edge of the box before Larsson slotted home from the spot.

The visitors did make a rare break into the Celtic half in the 23rd minute it almost brought them an equaliser when John O'Neill ran through unchallenged before hitting a right-footed drive that keeper Jonathan Gould brilliantly saved to his left.

Celtic, however, pressed for a second and their relentless pressure paid off at the close of the first half. After Chris Sutton glanced a header wide from Thompson's free-kick, and Moravcik shot straight at Colgan after being played clean through, Celtic doubled their lead when Lambert brilliantly played the ball out to Moravcik on the left flank and his precise cross was headed in by Larsson.

The home side began where they left off after the restart and Thompson went agonisingly close a minute into the second period when his 20-yard shot flew inches wide.

The former Aston Villa player was looking for his second goal in as many games and on 58 minutes he hit a venomous 25-yard free-kick just past the post.

Larsson himself had the scent of a hat-trick and only another great stop from Colgan denied the Swede a treble after he hit a first-time effort from just inside the box.

However, Hibs were refusing to fold and in the 79th minute they jolted the home side out of their complacency when Stuart Lovell's close range effort brought a brilliant save from Gould.

This sparked Celtic back into life and with nine minutes left Sutton and McNamara should have secured the points when the £6million forward rounded Colgan on the ground but Franck Sauzee cleared off the line and McNamara fired wildly over from the rebound.

Nevertheless there was still a time for Celtic to score their third goal in the closing seconds as Sutton beat the offside trap and unselfishly squared the ball to Burchill who side-footed into the empty net.

Their 100 per cent start was maintained here courtesy of an emphatic victory over Hibernian, thereby replacing their Edinburgh opponents at the top of the table. News of Rangers' stumble at Dundee only enhanced the buoyant mood. Two goals from Henrik Larsson and a late strike from substitute Mark Burchill ended Hibs' unbeaten run as Martin O'Neill's side served awesome warning of their title credentials. O'Neill has clearly given Celtic some resilience but it was complemented here by a considerable flair and it was again Larsson who led the way. The pressure on the Hibernian defence was relentless from the first whistle as the home side made a whirlwind start. Jackie McNamara conjured up the first clear-cut chance when he cut into the box from the right wing before shooting powerfully just past the post. The home side's tails were clearly up and Lubomir Moravcik tried his luck from over 20 yards out in the thirteenth minute with a dipping drive which Nick Colgan did well to push over. Celtic's confidence was replaced by concern in the 14th minute when Alan Stubbs collided with team-mate Paul Lambert and the defender was carried off. But those worries were forgotten after 19 minutes when the home side took the lead. Colgan came rushing out to clatter into Alan Thompson on the very edge of the box before Larsson slotted home from the spot. The visitors did make a rare break into the Celtic half in the 23rd minute it almost brought them an equaliser when John O'Neill ran through unchallenged before hitting a right-footed drive that keeper Jonathan Gould brilliantly saved to his left. Celtic, however, pressed for a second and their relentless pressure paid off at the close of the first half. After Chris Sutton glanced a header wide from Thompson's free-kick, and Moravcik shot straight at Colgan after being played clean through, Celtic doubled their lead when Lambert brilliantly played the ball out to Moravcik on the left flank and his precise cross was headed in by Larsson. The home side began where they left off after the restart and Thompson went agonisingly close a minute into the second period when his 20-yard shot flew inches wide. The former Aston Villa player was looking for his second goal in as many games and on 58 minutes he hit a venomous 25-yard free-kick just past the post. Larsson himself had the scent of a hat-trick and only another great stop from Colgan denied the Swede a treble after he hit a first-time effort from just inside the box. However, Hibs were refusing to fold and in the 79th minute they jolted the home side out of their complacency when Stuart Lovell's close range effort brought a brilliant save from Gould. This sparked Celtic back into life and with nine minutes left Sutton and McNamara should have secured the points when the £6million forward rounded Colgan on the ground but Franck Sauzee cleared off the line and McNamara fired wildly over from the rebound. Nevertheless there was still a time for Celtic to score their third goal in the closing seconds as Sutton beat the offside trap and unselfishly squared the ball to Burchill who side-footed into the empty net.

fields.headline: A top concierge reveals all
fields.standfirst: Sayed El Helw, Assistant concierge at The Four Seasons Hotel, Cairo
fields.trailText: Sayed El Helw, Assistant concierge at The Four Seasons Hotel, Cairo.
fields.body:
How long have you been at The Four Seasons?

The hotel opened in May, but I started last November. When they first asked me to be a concierge here I refused because the job is not usually important in Egypt. But Four Seasons have changed all that and I have totally changed my opinion. For example, in Egypt when a conciergecan't do something he just says no, but we try to find other ways of meeting requests. All the airline offices in Egypt close at 4pm so in any other hotel they can't make any flight changes or confirmations. We call a US Four Seasons and, because of the time difference, they can do the changes for us.

Any strange requests?

A guest from Qatar wanted a mazoun, who, like a priest, marries people. He had his girlfriend with him in the hotel and they had just decided to marry.

What sort of guests do you have?

We have not had the grand opening yet so most of our guests are business travellers, but there is an increasing number of tourists. The Saudi royal family have a high opinion of us and Prince the musician has also stayed. We arranged tours to the Pyramids and the Egyptian Museum for him.

What about a day out?

The Pyramids and the Sphinxare very well known, but not many people know that the art galleries in Cairo are amazing. Before the hotel opened we visited every gallery, museum and restaurant to see what they had to offer.

And an evening out?

We always ask what people want. They can have a meal on board the Nile Pharaoh, which cruises down the river from outside the hotel. There is a belly-dancing show which most Europeans enjoy. Cairo has a wide choice of Middle Eastern cuisines, such as Lebanese, Egyptian, Moroccan, as well as French and Italian. For a quieter meal we'd recommend Piano Piano and Justine. The best nightclub is the downtown Haroum El Rashid.

webTitle: Fury as Portland displays higher prices of rivals

fields.headline: Fury as Portland displays higher prices of rivals
fields.trailText: Tour operator Portland Direct has stirred up a storm by publishing competitors' prices in its 2001 brochure.
fields.body:
Tour operator Portland Direct has stirred up a storm by publishing competitors' prices in its 2001 brochure. In a travel industry first, prices of holidays with Airtours, First Choice, JMC and Direct Holidays are listed alongside Portland's prices, which are in many cases up to £100 cheaper. Thomson Holidays, Portland's sister company, is conspicuous by its absence from the brochure.

Most of the big package holiday players launched their summer programmes in April. By holding back its brochure launch until now the direct sell operator claims it has been able to guarantee lower published prices than its rivals.

For example, the new brochure features a seven-night package at the Aparthotel Barcelo Varadero in Tenerife for May 2001. It quotes its own price of £265 alongside JMC's £365.

The move has angered rivals, who claim that the published prices are misleading to customers as they do not take into account travel agent discounts, which have reached 30 per cent on some holidays, and other special offers.

JMC said the move was a 'short-lived publicity attempt' and 'highly inaccurate and irresponsible'. First Choice said the company was considering taking action against Portland for its 'misrepresentative prices'.

Portland defended its Price Guarantee saying that it stated clearly in the brochure that it applied only to brochure prices and not travel agent discounts, special offers, Teletext or website offers. 'Some people are prepared to shop around looking for agent discounts and free child places and insurance. This is for people who don't want to do that,' said a Portland Direct spokeswoman.

fields.headline: Tangerines slip away from pack
fields.trailText: Scottish round-up.
fields.body:
Dundee United fell further behind at the bottom of the table yesterday when they fell 1-0 at Kilmarnock.

The goal that sunk them came against the run of play after 30 minutes, when Ally Mitchell fastened on to a Paul Wright pass in his stride and beat the keeper with a shot into the root of the net. Five minutes later, United had further cause to bemoan their luck with a Steve Thompson shot which struck a post.

While United are still looking for their first league win, Motherwell claimed their opening victory at St Mirren.

After a first half in which there had been plenty of commitment from both sides, but little guile, Motherwell deservedly broke the deadlock in the 53rd minute through Lee McCulloch from Kevin Twaddle's cross. McCulloch, who had missed an excellent chance before his goal, also wasted a similar opportunity to make it 2-0.

Put through by Scott Leitch, he evaded St Mirren's defender, Scott Walker - and then blasted wide when it appeared easier to find the net.

All of which left Motherwell feeling grateful for having a goalkeeper of the quality of Andy Goram. In the last few minutes, he pulled off an outstanding save from St Mirren's substitute Mark Yardley.

Hearts, inspired by their Spanish star Juanjo, also had their first Premier League win, 2-0 against Dunfermline. He scored their first goal and Gary McSwegan added the other. 'He can be a bit frustrating at times,' said Hearts manager Jim Jefferies. 'But he has great skills and he showed them today.'

Dunfermline were disappointing and but for debut goalkeeper, Scott Thomson, would have lost by a considerably bigger margin.

St Johnstone had Jim Weir sent off for a 48th minute foul on Robbie Winters at Aberdeen. Surprisingly, it was St Johnstone who scored the first goal, through Mohammed Sylla, after 65 minutes, but Winters equalised in the 74th minute.

fields.headline: The Real villains
fields.standfirst: How the European champions' reckless spending, driven by their rivalry with Barcelona, has had a damaging effect on the game
fields.trailText: The European champions' reckless spending, driven by their rivalry with Barcelona, has had a damaging effect on the game, says Paul Wilson.
fields.body:
They play in pristine white, they have won the European Cup more times than any other club, and they stand for everything that is currently wrong with football.

Real Madrid begin their Champions League defence at Sporting Lisbon this week, days after admitting they are a crippling £170 million in debt. The Spanish giants are always in debt, but it appears the acquisition of Luis Figo, Pedro Munitis and Flavio Conceicao has undermined their tottering financial structure to the point where not even their celebrated friends in influential places can shore it up.

'The situation is bad,' the new president, Florentino Perez, admitted after an audit revealed even more of a money pit than had originally been feared. 'We have a grave sickness and it is a miracle the club is surviving day to day.'

He can say that again. It's a miracle football is surviving day to day with such an irresponsible role model. For it could be argued, indeed it should be argued since it is palpably true, that Real do not pay silly wages and play expensive games of oneupmanship with Barcelona in isolation. Their behaviour has a knock-on effect on the rest of the game. Barcelona went straight out with their Figo money and bought Marc Overmars and Emmanuel Petit from Arsenal, who were then obliged to pay over the odds for Sylvain Wiltord. Look at the money Liverpool had to come up with to try to tempt Steve McManaman to stay. Real are paying McManaman £3.4m per year even though they don't want him. Every club with a decent player approaching the end of his contract has to take a deep breath and consider what Real might pay him. Yet Real cannot make their own sums add up.

For a club who have won the Champions League twice in the past three years, Real are far from a picture of health. It is not just their overdraft either, although financial recklessness is at the root of most of Real's problems to such an extent it must gratify more prudent operations like Manchester United. Considering Real are still the most glamorous, impossibly romantic, football team on the planet, the way they have conducted themselves in recent years has been diabolical. This is the club to which every daydreaming schoolboy aspires, but grown-up footballers are finding the reality is distastefully different.

With the exception of Figo and the other newcomers, no one at the Bernabeu really knows whether they are staying or going, whether they are wanted or not. Rumours of a wholesale clear-out refuse to go away. 'The players have been left isolated and ignorant,' said former player and coach Jorge Valdano, who has just been taken on as sporting director. 'We need to support them and redefine their situations, so they can concentrate on playing and not be driven mad by different versions of the truth.'

This would be par for the course at an underachieving club like Internazionale or Barcelona, but it is only four months since Real were on top of the world. Their stylish and thrilling success is fast becoming a memory though, for every time Real achieve the prize they crave they promptly break up the band. Two years ago, manager Jupp Heynckes was sacked and given £1m compensation within eight days of their victory over the more fancied Juventus in the final in Amsterdam.

This time Vicente del Bosque has survived, although it looked touch and go at times last season, but the best midfield in the Champions League has been ripped apart. Fernando Redondo was packed of to Italy, Steve McManaman cruelly hung out to dry. The reason is either bad management or chronically poor accounting. Perez has had to raise £52m in four separate bank loans in three months since taking over - the first tranche was necessary to pay players' wages owing from June.

The big plus for Real fans is supposedly the arrival of Figo and his even bigger wages to simultaneously beef up the attack and put Barcelona's nose out of joint, though there are signs that the Bernabeu faithful are becoming tired of the capricious nature and sheer financial irresponsibility of the club. Figo was bought at record cost principally to honour an election promise made by Perez, who did not make it clear at the time that this extravagant purchase with money Real did not possess would effectively involve the sacrifice of the heart of last season's winning team.

Perez denies the club went out on a limb for Figo, arguing that most of the £38m fee was raised by the sale of Nicolas Anelka and Elvir Baljic. But that explanation hardly covers the unseemly haste with which Redondo was sold to AC Milan. Admittedly, £11m is a good price to pick up for a 31-year-old, but the Argentine was at the top of his form, extremely popular with Real supporters, and had just been voted the most valuable player in last season's Champions League by Uefa.

In recognition of his distinguished service for Real and his excellent form last season, supporters understood the club had placed an unofficial 'Not for sale' notice on Redondo, and were surprised and upset when he departed so quickly. A club statement explained the apparent u-turn by saying it was the player's 'express wish' to join Milan and that he had always wanted to end his career in Italy. Redondo himself has denied this, however, and supporters remain suspicious.

McManaman could never claim to be a club stalwart in the way Redondo was, but perhaps for that reason his treatment has been even more squalid. Indeed, it is hard to see how anyone can get to become a club stalwart if teams like Real are going to cynically exploit the Bosman ruling and make a quick buck on players who cost them nothing. There is not much more you can ask of a foreign player in his first season at a club than to settle into the side after a change of manager, play an integral part in helping reach a European Cup final in Paris and score a goal when he gets there. But do Real appreciate McManaman's contribution? Not unless trying to sell him to Middlesbrough against his wishes can be construed as a compliment.

Again, the club's almost desperate need to raise cash overlooks the fact that McManaman has proved himself a valuable member of the side. The manager has disputed this, describing McManaman as 'surplus to requirements' and doing his best to dishearten the player. The club president has even less interest in McManaman's welfare, undoubtedly viewing him merely as a potential source of income, but fortunately the Real supporters still know what's what.

When McManaman made his first appearance of the season as a substitute for Figo in a friendly against Santos last week, he was given a standing ovation by 35,000 fans at the Bernabeu. Perhaps they admire his Scouse pluck in standing up for his rights, more likely they know their club is once again in the wrong. 'I'm not in confrontation with Macca,' an uncomfortable del Bosque was forced to admit afterwards. 'It's great that the crowd love him.'

You can see why Valdano talks of being driven mad by versions of the truth. It is like when Perez says the only way to raise the £200m or so the club need is to convert into a limited company, only to dismiss the notion because the members would never stand for it. In point of fact, keeping Real as a members' club was another of Perez's election promises, and the idea that investors would flock to support such a financial black hole is risible in any case. Selling the training ground is more realistic. Until then, Perez will operate 'crisis measures'.

'We'll go through two difficult years until the club is restructured,' he said. So don't expect Real to rush out and buy an expensive short-term replacement for injured centre-forward Fernando Morientes. Well, not for a week or two.
