webTitle: My away day with the  Tartan Army

fields.headline: My away day with the  Tartan Army
fields.standfirst: The goblin-haunted Baltic city of Tallinn has overtaken Dublin and Amsterdam to become the capital of choice for adventurous lads in search of wild times. We sent  Howard Marks to find out why
fields.trailText: The goblin-haunted Baltic city of Tallinn has overtaken Dublin and Amsterdam to become the capital of choice for adventurous lads in search of wild times. We sent Howard Marks to find out why.
fields.body:
Estonia is a paradox: young, free and modern, but with a pagan soul. What good-time boy could resist a brew of heaving bars, beauteous nymphs, devilish revels and wild nights, not forgetting hairy beasts? No wonder the Tartan Army feels at home.

As a child, I had looked through enough old atlases and stamp collections to know that Estonia is not, as many seem to believe, in the Balkans, but not much more. One guidebook advises visitors to bring their own condoms, another to bring Mace to fend off stray dogs while jogging in the suburbs. I found a little poem by the renowned Estonian poet, Juhan Liiv:

You are too little
Little to be seen
To be known
To be felt
You are a little land
Little your speech
You have an indrawn heart
They cannot reach.

Estonia is not that small, actually: it's bigger than Switzerland, consisting of a sizeable chunk of the Northern European mainland plus well over a thousand islands. But it does boast one of the world's smallest population densities. It shares the Baltic Sea with Denmark, Sweden, Finland, Russia, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, and Germany. It has the same latitude as the northernmost tip of Scotland. Estonia emerged from the chaos of the First World War and the turmoil of Russian revolution as a highly literate country gaining its independence for the first time in 700 years.

The recently formed Estonian Airlines flight from Gatwick provided excellent food and service.Although smoking was not allowed, nicotine chewing gum of various strengths was thoughtfully provided. I was reading the in-flight magazine and strategically seated next to a fluently English-speaking Estonian beauty called Monica. An old lad's research prospects had never looked brighter.

Estonians are thought to be glum, pessimistic, stubborn, secretive, narrow (if not closed) minded, self-absorbed, unable to smile, brusque, and are expected to be so because of the long, dark mini-Ice Age winters and constant interrogations by the Gestapo and the KGB. 'May your face be as ice,' is an understandable and sensibly held motto.

None of this seemed to apply to Monica, with whom I struck up a conversation. She explained how Estonian independence lasted a mere 20 years and had been followed by half a century of Soviet occupation. The Soviets committed their standard catalogue of atrocities - secret murders, executions without trial, mass deportations, exile to Siberian prison camps, the ruthless destruction of cemeteries, national treasures and cultural memories. Even Father Christmas and privately owned windmills were abolished. All phone calls and mail had to be routed through Moscow. The Estonian national anthem was forbidden, and people were sent to Siberia for singing it. However, it was played on Finnish TV and radio, which could be covertly picked up.

Monica's eyes welled with the tears of painful memories. I tactfully changed the subject.

'Why do lads like Tallinn so much, Monica?'

She had no idea what I meant. My 20-minute summary of lad culture did nothing to improve her understanding, but she did infer the requirement of hedonism.

'Presumably, these lads like to sing?'

'Lads do quite like singing, yes.'

'Then it's easy. To have a good time in Estonia, you must go to the country, to the moonlight parties in the woods. Dance back to health. Sing away your sorrows. Drink and be merry. I suggest the island of Saaremaa. I have a summer-house there. Here is my mobile.'

The next morning, I made a sightseeing tour of the capital. Built as a fort, a marketplace and a port, Tallinn is a jumble of contradictions, with its winding, cobbled streets, hidden courtyards, open-air markets and theatres, gingerbread façades, and quirky defensive walls forming an intact medieval city encircled by tree-lined avenues, a belt of parks, a cluster of Soviet-era buildings, and the Baltic Sea. In the heart of the Old Town are pool bars, bowling alleys and subterranean 10,000-watt discos with all the lights.

Previously neglected monastic buildings have been turned into student cafés. Some establishments offered private striptease. Dimly lit cigar lounges enticed secret smokers. Hundreds of restaurants offered cuisines from dozens of nationalities. There were biker bars with real bikers, and country bars without country music.

The Russians, in their 50-year occupation, painted buildings to achieve an inner-city drab uniformity, turned the churches into sterile museums and offices, and renamed streets after Russian military heroes. Now the paint is being peeled away, constantly revealing scenes of multi-coloured medieval merriment. I peeped inside an Orthodox church where a wedding and a funeral were simultaneously taking place in front of bemused Japanese tourists.

I stumbled into haunted houses with heavily documented apparitions of crucified monks and black dogs with burning eyes. One house claimed to be the site of the Devil's wedding and subsequent reception; the clinking glasses could be heard all night. A well sits in the middle of a cobbled street. Food is thrown down to appease the goblin that lives at the bottom. Goblins and devils were more real in this city then in any other I've visited. Paganism is clearly alive and well. But where were the lads?

A cursory glance around the Old City clearly showed that the main entertainment is, indeed, liquid. The many varieties of Estonian beer are first-class. During the thirteenth century, bishops demanded beer as payment for taxes. Fines and sacrifices were also paid in beer, and brewing beer was obligatory on holidays. When sailors brought back potatoes from America, the idea of vodka was quickly and sensibly conceived. And the best beer and vodka in Estonia come from Saaremaa, the island of the wood nymph with the mobile, the island where, during the Soviet occupation, no foreigner was allowed to visit, the island where enforced isolation preserved the traditions and culture of Old Estonia. I decided to forget the lads and head for Saaremaa.

Renting a car was surprisingly cheap and easy, and the roads were very visitor-friendly and empty. Hitchhiking is actively encouraged, so I filled up the car with the first four thumb-wavers I encountered. They made helpful guides and informed me of the weird sports that have become popular in Estonia. These included wife-carrying races, mobile-phone throwing, and Keekiin (swinging in vertical circles).

The beauties of the countryside are subtle and delicate. Half the country is covered with primeval forests, which yield to deep peat bogs, vast swamps, wild fens, misty marshes, sparkling lakes and rivers, and long and lonely sandy coastlines. We took a 30-minute ferry ride to Muhu, an island joined by causeway to Saaremaa. Tourism provides a welcome income here. Everything is available for those who believe active holidays restore creative powers: water sports, hiking, hunting, cycling, canoe trips and horse-riding.

We passed through popular spa areas, where the locals have had centuries of experience with the curative properties of the shoreline mud. For those of us perfectly healthy but thoroughly inactive, roadside notices advertise fishing, open-air museums, and berry and mushroom picking. My passengers assured me that picking mushrooms could be a dangerous business for a visitor not accompanied by an Estonian able to distinguish the edible, the poisonous and those that render the consumer temporarily bananas.

We got out of the car and rambled through the forest. It felt like being let loose in a safari park. Estonia has more large wild mammals than anywhere else in Europe. My fellow pickers claimed to see brown bears, elk, deer, wild boar, wolves and lynx. Earlier, we had definitely seen beavers, seals and otters, as well as black storks, sea swans and golden eagles. We filled a bag with berries and mushrooms, and I ate some. On the walk back, we passed the eerie 8,000-year-old meteorite crater of Kaali, where in Scandinavian mythology the sun has its grave. I wondered what secrets of the past were hidden here. An elderly gentleman approached me.

'Are you from Scotland?'

'No. I'm from a similar country called Wales.'

'I study unidentified objects, you see, and I want to go to Loch Ness.'

The sun was beginning to set as we drove to the Illiku Ladu summer disco. It would soon open its doors. There would then be a moonlight party in the woods. Assuming (even if hoping otherwise) that the mushrooms I'd wolfed were of the non-psychoactive variety, I joined the festivities and sampled extensively the local brews and spirits. Several hours of heavy drinking later, I was unable to determine if my assumption had been correct. We were in a sacred oak grove with totem pole-like energy columns beaming out waves of psychic rejuvenation. It was a bonfire-lit night of magic and sorcery with naked witches running through the trees, casting their spells.

It was a night when dawn, furiously and swiftly, embraced the dusk. It was a night for boozing, a night for music, and a night for lovers. We adorned crowns of leaves, sported garlands of flowers, grasses, and herbs to ward off (or, in my case, encourage) those naughty wood nymphs. On ropes hung from trees, we swung over bonfires. We bathed in the magical, wrinkle-removing dew. The only forbidden activity was sleeping, punishable by a year's bad luck. I felt safe.

Back in Tallinn, the city was heaving with laughing drinkers. A bar called Molly Malone's was crammed but no one was Irish. This was made clear by the presence of what had to be all the blonde contestants of Ms World, the attire worn by each male boozer (kilt, sporran and beret), and the tune being sung - 'Doh, a deer, a female deer'. I had walked into the temporary headquarters of the Tartan Army, Scotland's football fans. As far as laddish behaviour goes, the Tartan Army are pretty hard to beat. Chas, the head barman (a Scot), recognised me. 'That was all British and American propaganda, wasn't it, Howard?' said Chas, surrounded by hand-picked, beautiful barmaids.

'What do you mean?'

'You know. All that bollocks about women in the Soviet countries being fat and ugly.'

'Why are the Scots here, Chas?'

'Well, the owner of Molly Malone's is a Scot, and Scotland are playing Latvia on Saturday. Whenever Scotland are playing anywhere in or fairly near to Estonia, they always spend a few nights here in Tallinn. It's become a tradition.'

The reasons are interesting. The region's worst maritime disaster outside of war was the 1994 sinking of the Estonia, a ferry operating between Stockholm and Tallinn. More than 800, including 500 Estonians, lost their lives. Some Scottish football fans, who had travelled on that same route, were so moved that they raised funds for the surviving families and presented the cheque to the Estonian embassy in London.

A year later, Scotland were playing Estonia away. The Tartan Army's first act was to visit Tallinn's memorial to the deceased. Led by a lone piper, they marched through the streets and paid tribute with flowers. The fans were officially given the freedom of the city. The floodlights of Tallinn's small stadium had gone badly wrong, so the match was brought forward to be played in daylight. The Estonian team was too far out of town to get there in time, so Scotland marched on to the pitch alone. Six hundred members of the Tartan Army stood in the stands, otherwise empty, apart from the Estonian army who were filling in for the security men. Scotland played for a few seconds, walked off, and hit the town, to be joined later by the tardy Estonian team.

The revelry was unprecedented and unsurpassed. Word gets around. Many fans return for weekend benders well outside the football season. They are complimented for their behaviour. A raggle-taggle mob of crazily dressed, skint people bevvying and swearing are not the usual criteria of civic order. But with Estonia and the Tartan Army, it's true love.

Estonians are far from prudish. They excel in mockery of state authority. Their folk heroes never become kings; they talk philosophy with the Devil, then double-cross him.

I shall definitely return. So will lots of lads.

webTitle: Blair should transfer attention to what he knows

fields.headline: Blair should transfer attention to what he knows
fields.trailText: 'Dismantling the entire transfer system is not the answer,' said Tony Blair. Don't hold your breath.
fields.body:
England's keenest football fan, Tony Blair, who can't remember the first game he went to and used to sit in Newcastle's Gallowgate End - even though it didn't have seats then - has come out in favour of keeping the present transfer system. Phew, that should save it then.

As nothing was happening at the New York Millennium Summit last week Blair made a statement on football transfers. The statement only amounted to nine words, 'Dismantling the entire transfer system is not the answer.' With a little help from Alastair Campbell, who unlike his boss does know about football, that was more than enough to make a story. We were told that Blair had the backing of the German Chancellor Gerhard Schröder - which he confirmed yesterday - and French President Jacques Chirac.

Don't hold your breath. I well remember attending a European summit meeting when the issue of saving duty free came up. Chirac turned to Blair and said, 'Why are we abolishing it when it's so popular with everyone?' Blair and the rest of Europe's leaders just shrugged their shoulders. Even though none of the elected leaders wanted to get rid of duty free, the Brussels bureaucrats did, and look who won.

'Transfers Herr to stay.' Get it? But The Sun's headline this week was certainly premature. What must be most worrying for those who want to keep the system is the 'setting up of a New Labour-style Transfer Task Force. Worse still, there is talk of adopting the Spanish system where players have a buy-out clause in their contract. This is the one that resulted in Luis Figo moving from Barcelona to Real Madrid for £38 million even though Real are in effect bankrupt.

If they were really serious, Uefa should have blocked the deal or insisted that any fee must be paid up front, not in instalments - but that would be too sensible. Uefa need to introduce financial accountability to the crazy football market and at least there's talk of them introducing a licence which would be withdrawn for serious financial mismanagement.

The intervention from Blair was strange and very un-Blair, because in no way could the keeping of the transfer system be seen as 'populist.' Most fans know that all the talk about 'the end of football' is tosh. The talking points for fans this week have been Keegan's decision not to start with Michael Owen and Chelsea's inability to defend a two-goal lead, not transfers.

Supporters will rightly scoff at any big clubs and big earners who claim that the end of the transfer system will end football as we know it, and laugh at their crocodile tears for the small clubs who they claim will suffer. Since when did they care about the small clubs? The reason for setting up the Premier League in the first place was to direct more money to them and less to the smaller clubs.

The fact is football has always resisted change and some of us are old enough to remember what the big clubs said about the abolition of the maximum wage when players were treated as slaves. You've guessed it - they said it would be the end of football, as we know it.

It's not surprising that the Premier League bosses (or the chairmen at least) were unanimous in their support for maintaining the status quo: it just confirms that they must be wrong. What is more surprising is the attitude of the players' union. You would have thought that ending the 'cattle market' transfer system would have the support of the PFA, particularly as the top players would stand to make even more money than they do now. They apparently argue that they are more worried about the wages of players in the lower divisions, which isn't that surprising given that a lot of them are on silly money and are paid far more than they are worth.

The present system is indefensible and football's claim to be a special case is not justified. It's not often that the Eurocrats get it right but they were right on freedom of contract and they are right about transfers. What other business operates like football, buying and selling workers for millions of pounds they don't have? And what has been done about all the corruption that goes with it, including 'bungs'?

Absolutely nothing. It's high time football's money madness was reined in.

fields.headline: Our choice
fields.trailText: Barrier Reef | Madeira | Farmers' markets at Brigg | Tuscany
fields.body:
Lounge on the Barrier Reef

Lizard Island, one of the tropical resorts on Australia's Great Barrier Reef, has reopened after a six-month £6 million modernisation. The 40 villas have been rebuilt: the Anchor Bay suites have private access to the beach while the Sunset Point villas are on the cliff overlooking the bay. The lounge and bar areas in the main lodge have been redesigned while the restaurant veranda has been extended, which means more tables directly overlook the bay. A spa has been built beside the pool. Lizard is one of the Natural Treasures set in World Heritage listed regions, owned by P&O Australian Resorts. Prices at Lizard start at A$630 (£260) a head, including meals and most activities. For details of this and othef Reef resorts see www.poresorts.com.au or call 020 7805 3875.

Madeira, my dear

Dolunay Holidays, a specialist in the quieter parts of Turkey and northern Cyprus, has spread its wings to cover Portugal and Madeira. In Madeira, character hotels in the capital Funchal are featured with hotels and self-catering in quiet locations. Seven nights at the Hotel Residencial Pina, in Funchal, costs £366 per person for arrivals before 31 October, including flights and B&B. City breaks in Lisbon and Sintra are highlighted along with self-catering in small Portuguese towns. There is a £50 discount per person for booking before 30 September. Brochures from 01452 501978.

Find the right market

Saturday farmers' markets at Brigg, Lincolnshire, are the focus of a weekend break initiative from North Lincolnshire Council Tourism Unit. Two-night short breaks are being offered on the fourth weekends of September, October and November with special rates from £16 B&B per person per night to allow visitors to shop at the market in the town square where fresh farm produce is sold. Book on 01652 657053 and get a free cool bag to take the produce home.

Tuscan walking

Autumn is the ideal time to cycle or walk in Tuscany, when the Blairs have returned home and temperatures have eased. Sherpa (020 8577 2717) offers independent walking or cycling holidays until the end of October. A six-night easy-paced walk from Volterra to Siena costs £762 (£707 in October), including return flights from Gatwick, hotel or guesthouse accommodation with breakfast and four evening meals, daily baggage transfer and route maps. See www.sherpa-walking-holidays.co.uk

fields.headline: England's quiet catalyst
fields.standfirst: Coach Duncan Fletcher has taken a low-profile route to winning: What Duncan Fletcher would never have said... but his predecessors at the England helm did
fields.trailText: Conspicuously absent from the champagne-soaked celebrations at The Oval was the England coach, Duncan Fletcher. In fact we've hardly seen him all summer. He could be glimpsed on the balcony throughout the Test series, stern-faced, lugubrious, betraying little emotion whether England were getting thrashed at Edgbaston or mounting a surreal comeback at Lord's.
fields.body:
Conspicuously absent from the champagne-soaked celebrations at The Oval was the England coach, Duncan Fletcher. In fact we've hardly seen him all summer. He could be glimpsed on the balcony throughout the Test series, stern-faced, lugubrious, betraying little emotion whether England were getting thrashed at Edgbaston or mounting a surreal comeback at Lord's.

He has appeared occasionally at press conferences, but only when demanded. There he speaks with clipped common sense, but in contrast to his predecessors, David Lloyd and Raymond Illingworth, he says as little as he possibly can without being obstructive. In any case, he soon learnt in South Africa last winter that he's only required to say anything when England are struggling, which has seldom been the case this summer. He does not need the plaudits of the press; he's adamant that 'players, not coaches, win matches'. Curiously, this stance now provokes more praise. Recently he's been hailed in the papers as England's 'best ever coach'.

More importantly, the players are coming to the same conclusion. Nasser Hussain admitted last year that 'I would not have recognised him if he had walked past me in the street' and was wary how the new coach might react to him given all the stories about 'bad boy Hussain', but he soon described him as 'a breath of fresh air'. None of the players I've spoken to has a critical, off-the-record word to say about him (I haven't talked to Robert Croft recently). But beyond the dressing room he remains to most of us something of an enigma, who guards his privacy carefully, who actively wants to keep out of the way - even in victory.

I met him at Lord's the day after England's series triumph; he had been overseeing some fitness testing of the players before popping back to South Africa for a brief holiday. I began with a bland - OK, maybe boring - question: 'What was the most satisfying aspect of the summer?' This was solemnly blocked. 'Winning and seeing the players enjoying their cricket,' he said, trying to be helpful after an exasperated pause. 'It's satisfying to identify certain players and to be proved correct.'

Hmmm... this was not getting us far. But somehow we were soon discussing the techniques of batting; suddenly he was animated and up on his feet; there was a spark in his eyes as on the concrete at the Nursery End he was demonstrating with an imaginary bat different ways of playing the hook shot. His thesis (we won't bother with the technicalities) made sense and his exposition was clear and dynamic. I thought how much I would have enjoyed being coached by this man.

This called to mind an observation about Fletcher made by the England newcomer Marcus Trescothick. 'He reminds me of Dermot [Reeve],' he said. This made me blink. Reeve is a good coach, but it's hard to think of many parallels with Fletcher. Reeve has never been one to shun the limelight, nor to choose his words sparingly. Then Trescothick explained how both men were prepared to challenge the traditional methods of playing the game; both were flexible, lateral thinkers, always positive in outlook.

However, there are some fundamentals, to which Fletcher sticks rigidly when coaching. He has a distinct method that he's used successfully at Western Province and at Glamorgan. 'Before I took the England job I was nervous whether it would work at international level.' His approach is based on the primacy of the captain. He explains: 'When I was first made captain [in Zimbabwe] I thought I needed a coach to run everything. I was an all-rounder and I wanted time to concentrate on my own game, so I had Peter Carlstein installed as an omnipotent coach. It took me two practice sessions to establish that this was not working. The players can't have two bosses; the captain must be the man in charge.' It was never so straightforward when David Lloyd, who pined to be Alex Ferguson, or Illy, whose book was proudly entitled One-Man Committee, were in charge.

'Give people responsibility and they'll respond,' says Fletcher. 'I learnt that from my days in the commercial world [he worked in the computer industry in South Africa]. With England we have a committee to discuss all matters relating to the team both on and off the field.' This summer it comprised Fletcher and Hussain plus Atherton, Stewart, Gough and Thorpe (interesting that he should reinstate Thorpe so rapidly after his self-imposed exile last winter).

Fletcher has sometimes referred to himself as a 'consultant' to a company, whose managing director is the captain of the team. Steve James of Glamorgan has recalled how Fletcher outlined this system at the first meeting with his players at Cardiff in 1997. His message was relayed with typical clarity until he climaxed his talk with, 'OK, let's get this road on the show', a slip they never let him forget. Fletcher, despite the dour demeanour, can laugh at himself. Indeed his solemn countenance can sometimes be an unlikely source of humour. Simon Hughes, yakking around Zimbabwe many years ago, was informed that Fletcher's brother held the world record for the number of press-ups. This impressed Hughes: 'At an opportune moment I asked him about his brother's press-up prowess. This summer, for example, he trekked up to Chester-le-Street to visit Steve Harmison, not for a net, but just to talk things over. He emphasises that the players 'must trust you and know that you are on their side'. After a fortnight in South Africa last winter, Andy Caddick felt that Fletcher understood the individual needs of a fast bowler far better than any of his predecessors; Craig White told me how Fletcher made him feel 'ten feet tall' one rainy afternoon in Cape Town after explaining how he might become an integral part of the Test team. Fletcher makes time to get to know his players.

At the start he didn't know any of them. He scarcely had any input into the selection of the touring party for South Africa last year. He recalls how he had never seen Michael Vaughan bat before. 'But I watched him in the nets at the beginning of the tour and thought, "This guy could bat at number four".' He trusts his own eyes, which has led to the rapid elevation of White and Trescothick this summer.

Increasingly he has more influence over selection, although he admits that he's barely seen Ian Salisbury, the surprise package for Pakistan, bowl. 'It's difficult given the international calendar to see them in action in county cricket. Players only perform one in three times and that's only if they happen to be batting or bowling on the day you're there.' He had only heard reports of England's other wrist-spinner, Chris Schofield, before he was offered a central contract in April, but he vehemently rejects the idea that Schofield's experience this summer undermines the validity of the central-contract system.

Indeed he says that he was very fortunate that his tenure as coach coincided with the advent of that system. 'There're bound to be teething problems. It was just the same when it was introduced in South Africa five or six years ago. Initially the state sides were up in arms. But at Western Province we often did better without our international players. Someone like Gary Kirsten would come back from the Tests; he'd be willing himself to do well for his state side but the spark wasn't there. The same can happen here.

'Next year I would like 15 or 16 to be contracted. That would give healthy competition and a degree of security to the players involved. You're never going to get it 100 per cent right in your selection for central contracts.' I suggest that the counties are less grumpy now that England have prospered this summer. 'Success this summer should be irrelevant. This is the right way forward,' he says. He agonised long and hard about whether to allow players to turn out for their counties at the end of this season. 'I thought about letting some of the younger ones, like Flintoff and Trescothick, play a few games, but in the end I concluded that they might be weary by the time we reach the second Test in Pakistan.'

He's never been to Pakistan, where the cricket is unlikely to be played on the seamer-friendly surfaces that have suited England so well this summer. 'I've already talked to some of the batsmen about playing spin, offering a few technical suggestions [which he was reluctant to divulge]. They will be working on those in Nairobi and during the one-day series in Pakistan. But when the Tests are approaching it is no longer right to dwell on technicalities.'

He may acknowledge England's frailties in the spin department, but like the good coach, he's swift to defend those chosen (Salisbury and Ashley Giles) even if he doesn't know them well - yet. He knows that Salisbury has potential even though he's never shown it at Test level. 'We'll just have to make sure he has plenty of bowling early on and give him as much confidence as we can.' Judging by England's performances this summer, that's what Fletcher is remarkably good at.

He has appeared occasionally at press conferences, but only when demanded. fields.headline: England players in 'fix' report
fields.trailText: Illegal Indian bookies have repeatedly told investigators from the country's Central Bureau of Investigation that one of the most prominent English cricketers of the past 10 years has been mixed up in match-fixing.
fields.body:
Illegal Indian bookies have repeatedly told investigators from the country's Central Bureau of Investigation that one of the most prominent English cricketers of the past 10 years has been mixed up in match-fixing.

A CBI interim report into match-fixing will be issued on 29 September and is expected to name two England players and three from Pakistan. Officers from the CBI were in England as part of their investigations recently.

'The same name has cropped up again and again,' said an Indian media executive who was forced to leave his job for his dealings with bookmakers but who retains close links with cricket authorities.

'All the illegal bookmakers in the country are cooperating with the police and all of them seem to give the same name. They are singing like canaries. Some of them have alleged that their association with this cricketer goes back to the England tour of 1992-93.'

That tour was one of the worst in England's recent history. They lost the Test series 3-0 and drew the six-match one-day series despite having led 3-1. They went on to Sri Lanka where they lost a Test for the first time and both one-day matches.

The executive added: 'The police are amazed at the extent of the bookmakers' grip on cricket. Whether their evidence will stand up in a court of law is a different matter but a few shocks may be in store for English cricket.'

One of the problems confronting the Indian police as they attempt to pursue their case against Hansie Cronje, the disgraced South African captain, is that the tapes of mobile phone calls that first revealed his involvement may not be allowed as evidence in court.

No action was taken after the former Test all-rounder Chris Lewis alleged he had been given the names of three England players who had been paid by bookmakers. So far 16 Indian cricketers have been questioned by police.

webTitle: Escape guide to Britain's top hotels (part two)

fields.headline: Where guests come first (part two)
fields.standfirst: Caroline Raphael, editor of  The Good Hotel Guide, picks 50 of the best from the 2000-2001 edition
fields.trailText: Child-friendly hotels
fields.body:
Child-friendly hotels

Unlike their continental counterparts, many British hotels impose age restrictions on children. Here are some that make a point of welcoming families.

1 The Blakeney Hotel
Blakeney, near Holt, Norfolk NR25 7NE
01263 740797; fax 01263 740795

In yachting centre by estuary: long-established hotel catering for young and old. Cheerful staff; indoor swimming pool, mini-gym, games room; small garden. Dinner, B&B (minimum two nights) £64 to£106.

2 The Evesham Hotel
Cooper's Lane, Evesham Worcestershire WR11 6DA
01386 765566; fax 01386 765443
email reception@evesham hotel.com
www.eveshamhotel.com

On the edge of a market town, run, with humour, by John and Sue Jenkinson. Imaginative family suites (eg, Alice in Wonderland, ancient Rome). Child under 12 charged according to age and amount of food eaten. Eclectic menus in popular restaurant overlooking large garden. Indoor swimming pool. Forty bedrooms. B&B £49 to £71. Dinner, B&B two nightsminimum.) £55 to £68.

3 Le Manoir aux Quat'Saisons
Church Road, Great Milton, Oxfordshire OX44 7PD
01844 278881; fax 01844 278847
email lemanoir@blancco.uk
www.manoir.co.uk

At Raymond Blanc's luxurious country house hotel/restaurant (two Michelin stars) in village near Oxford, children 'are welcomed, not just tolerated'. Special menus; designer high chairs and silver spoons for babies. Lovely grounds with roses, potager, apple trees, ancient pond. Thirty-one bedrooms. B&B: single/double £230 to £340, suite £395 to £550. Menu gourmand £84.

4 22 Jermyn Street
22 Jermyn Street, London SW1Y 6HL
020 7734 2353, fax 020 7734 0750
email office@22jermyn.com
www.22jermyn.com

Henry Togna's luxury hotel in St James's. Very hi-tech, very welcoming. Decor a mix of contemporary furniture and fabrics with antiques. Childrens' dressing gowns, Kids' Talk newsletter; games, toys. Dogs welcomed. No public rooms. 13 suites £290-£325; 5 double rooms £205.

5 Biskra Beach Hotel
17 St Thomas's Street, Ryde, Isle of Wight PO33 2DL
01983 567913; fax 01983 616976
email info@biskra-hotel.com
www.biskra-hotel.com

Composed of two Victorian houses by sea on north-east coast. Calm modern decor (natural fabrics, stripped pine, wrought iron); informal feel. Bistro-style restaurant. Dogs also welcomed. Fourteen bedrooms. B&B double £57.50 to £120. À la carte meal £30.

6 Calcot Manor
near Tetbury, Gloucestershire GL8 8YJ.
01666 890391; fax 01666 890394
email reception@calcotmanor.co.uk
www.calcotmanor.co.uk

Former ancient Cotswold farmstead, now Richard Ball's flexibly run family hotel, which also caters for child-free adults wanting sophisticated comforts. Nine-acre grounds: heated swimming pool, tennis, croquet; children's playroom. Conservatory restaurant; Gumstool bar/brasserie for informal meals. Twenty-eight bedrooms. B&B £65 to £115. À la carte meal £30.

7 Watersmeet
Mortehoe, Woolacombe, Devon EX34 7EB
01271 870333; fax 01271 870890
email watersmeethotel@compuserve.com
www.watersmeethotel.co.uk

Traditional hotel on cliff, with views to Lundy Island, National Trust land all around. Mr and Mrs Wickman head long-serving staff. Indoor swimming pool with wave machine; outdoor pool, tennis, in large garden; wide beach (sand and rock pools) nearby. Twenty-one bedrooms. B&B £58 to£110. Dinner, B&B (two nights mimimum.) £71 to £125.

8 Porth Tocyn Hotel
Abersoch, Gwynedd LL53 7BU
01758 713303; fax 01758 713538
email porthtocyn.hotel@virgin.net
www.porth-tocyn-hotel.co.uk

Family hotel above yachting village - glorious views of Snowdonia and Cardigan Bay. Traditional decor: country antiques; cottagey bedrooms. Children's sitting room with games, TV, video. Twenty-five-acre grounds, swimming pool, tennis. Beach nearby. Good food. Seventeen bedrooms. B&B £32.75 to £64. Set dinner £23.50 to £30.

9 Dunain Park
Inverness, Highland IV3 8JN
01463 230512; fax 01463 224532
email dunainparkhotel@btinternet.com
www.dunainpark.co.uk

Italianate nineteenth-century mansion in gardens and woodland, now Edward and Ann Nicoll's comfortable country hotel. Good cooking; succulent steaks, children's menu. Copious breakfasts. Thirteen bedrooms, two cottages. B&B £49-£99. Dinner, B&B £69-£124.

10 White House
Herm, via Guernsey GY1 3HR
01481 722159; fax 01481 710066
www.herm-island.com

On tiny car-free Channel island (pristine beaches, high cliffs, small harbour): very friendly hotel owned by Pennie and Adrian Heyworth, well geared for a family holiday. Great views; good food in carvery and restaurant helpful staff. Tennis, croquet, swimming pool; beach 100 yards. Thirty-eight bedrooms. Dinner, B&B £58.50 to £79.

Value for money

It is easy to find cosseting for a price; here are some places where you can stay without busting the bank.

1 Abbey House
Church Street, Abbotsbury, Dorset DT3 4JJ
01305 871330; fax 01305 871088
email info@theabbeyhouse.co.uk
www.theabbeyhouse.co.uk

In garden with a view, Jonathan and Maureen Cooke's unpretentious no-smoking guest house. Copious breakfast; light lunches, teas. Five rooms. B&B £30-£32.50.

2 The Henley
Folly Hill, Bigbury-on-Sea, Devon TQ7 4AR
01548 810240, fax 01548 810020

Edwardian holiday cottage, now Martyn Scarterfield's small hotel: six pristine bedrooms, charming veranda restaurant with wide views across estuary. Small terraced garden. B&B £35 to £45. Dinner, B&B £51 to £61.

3 Blackmore Farm
Cannington, near Bridgwater, Somerset TA5 2NE
01278 653442; fax 01278 653427
email dyerfarm@aol.com
www.dyerfarm.co.uk

Medieval manor house with chapel, on large working farm. Ann and Ian Dyer offer B&B in generous style. Four bedrooms in simple good taste. Good breakfast at long refectory table by huge fireplace. B&B £21 to £38.

4 Oak Tree Farm
Hints Road, Hopwas, near Tamworth, Staffordshire B78 3AA
01827 56807; fax 01827 56807

Sue Purkis's rural oasis: renovated farmhouse in grounds between River Tame and a canal. Six thoughtfully equipped bedrooms. Good breakfast. B&B £32 to £52.

5 The Nobody Inn
Doddiscombsleigh, Devon EX6 7PS
01647 252394; fax 01647 252978
email inn.nobody@virgin.net

Lovely old quirky inn, up narrow roads near Exeter. Huge wine list, vast selection of Devon cheeses. Nick Borst-Smith presides. Seven bedrooms: best ones in manor house close by; simple ones above the pub. B&B £23 to £38. À la carte dinner £20.

6 Beechwood
Cromer Road, North Walsham, Norfolk NR28 0HD
01692 403231; fax 01692 407284

Don Birch and Lindsay Spalding's ivy-clad 200-year-old house. Peace guaranteed. Good food (New World/traditional) with lots of choice. Small garden. Ten bedrooms. B&B £35 to £62. Dinner, B&B £40 to £84.

7 Garthmyl Hall
Garthmyl, nr Montgomery, Powys SY15 6RS
01686 640550; fax 01686 640609

Elegant late-Georgian house amid wild and formal gardens and fields. Nine tastefully furnished bedrooms, good dinners, copious breakfasts. Enthusiastic owners Nancy and Tim Morrow welcome children. B&B from £27.50. Set dinner £19.50.

8 Ty Isaf Farmhouse
Llanfachreth, near Dolgellau, Gwynedd LL40 2EA
01341 423261; fax 01341 423261
email raygear@tyisaf.freeserve.co.uk
www.tyisaf78.freeserve.co.uk

Ray and Lorna Gear's small guest house in hamlet in Snowdonia National Park. Thick walls, oak rafters, inglenook fireplace, country decor, imaginative food. Garden with stream; two llamas in meadow. Three bedrooms. B&B £27. Dinner, B&B £42.

9 Apple Lodge Lochranza
Isle of Arran KA27 8HJ
01770 830229; fax 01770 830229
email applelodge@easicom.com

John and Jeannie Boyd's little guest house by sea loch (romantic sunsets). Four pretty bedrooms. Very good no-choice dinners; no licence; bring your own wine. Excellent hillwalking from the door. B&B £30 to £37. Set dinner £18.

10 Cuilcheanna House
Onich, by Fort William, Highland PH33 6SD
01855 821226
email relax@cuilcheanna.freeserve.co.uk

Secluded by Loch Linnhe, white country house in garden with views to Mull mountains. Hospitable owners Russell and Linda Scott; creative dinners. Seven bedrooms. B&B £29 to £44. Dinner, B&B £48 to £63.

The rates given are per person unless otherwise stated. The à la carte price given is for a three-course meal for one person, including a half-bottle of reasonably priced wine.

fields.headline: Battle to ban offroaders
fields.standfirst: Joanne O'Connor  reports on the havoc caused by 4x4s
fields.trailText: Joanne O'Connor reports on the havoc caused by 4x4s.
fields.body:
Halfway between the villages of Talybont and Pontsticill in mid-Wales is a hill which walkers have long climbed to enjoy spectacular views from the summit over the Brecon Beacons. Climb that hill today and you will see ruts up to six foot deep and huge bald patches where the vegetation has been eroded. 'It looks like a battlefield,'says Sue Mabberley, head warden at the Brecon Beacons National Park.

The cause of the damage is four-wheel-drive vehicles: the increasing popularity of off-road driving as a recreation has become a major environmental problem for the National Parks and a nuisance for residents and other park users. The sharp increase in ownership of four-wheel drives has been matched by a rise in the number of commercial operators offering 'jeep safaris' for tourists and corporate entertainment.

The problem is not confined to Wales. Other areas of rugged terrain such as the Yorkshire Dales, North Yorkshire Moors and the Lake District are facing similar issues.

Bob Cartwright, head of park management for the Lake District National Park Authority has identified 146 routes within the park which are regularly used by 4WD vehicles, sometimes in convoys up to 17 vehicles long. 'It is a fundamentally inappropriate activity for a national park and we have been increasingly concerned about the impact on the landscape and local communities,' he said.

'In upland areas where the soil is thin or fragile heavy vehicles rip through the soil affecting the habitat and plant life, but it also impacts on other recreational users such as ramblers, horseriders and cyclists when a path becomes a quagmire. We've had incidents where a path was so bad that a farmer couldn't reach his stock to feed them and a horse had to be put down because it got caught in a bog.'

Efforts to control the problem by putting up no entry signs on paths and a code of conduct for offroad vehicles have had minimal impact.

The Countryside and Rights of Way Bill, now going through parliament will designate certain roads as Restricted Byways - putting the onus on motorists to prove a precedent of vehicular access before they can use it.

However, Cartwright and many of his national park colleagues believe that nothing short of a complete ban will suffice.

British Off Road Driving Association chairman Richard Beddall believes the solution is not to place restrictions on roads but on drivers. 'I have a lot of sympathy with the national parks but they are fighting the wrong battle,' he said. 'It's not a question of regulating the ground but regulating the people with some kind of basic training. There are lots of people charging about the countryside in four-wheel drive vehicles who are totally ignorant. You have to have a license to drive on the road so why not have one for driving offroad too?'

Reputable clubs such as the All Wheel Drive Club and Association of Landrover Clubs offer training and environmental guidelines but these clubs only account for around 20 per cent of off-road drivers.

Sue Mabberley fears the problem will get worse before anything is done: 'We get letters all the time asking us why we aren't doing something about the problem, but our hands are tied.'

fields.headline: Missing travellers' web link
fields.trailText: The National Missing Persons Helpline has joined forces with a new travel website in an attempt to track down young British travellers who have vanished abroad.
fields.body:
The National Missing Persons Helpline has joined forces with a new travel website in an attempt to track down young British travellers who have vanished abroad.

The site, youngtravellers. com, offers services and advice to young backpackers visiting the UK. It has a direct link to the National Missing Persons Helpline website, which has pictures and information on 63 British travellers aged between 18 and 30 who disappeared in mysterious circumstances while abroad.

'The internet is a great tool because even the most remote towns have an internet cafe and they are widely used by travellers,' said Sophie Woodforde, the helpline's head of web development.

The majority of young people on the helpline's database are not presumed to be in danger and have either lost touch with their families or deliberately broken off contact.

'We hope it will act as a gentle nudge to young people who are travelling to get in touch with their families and let them know they are OK.'

The helpline guarantees confidentiality and can forward an 'alive and well' message to relatives without revealing the sender's whereabouts.

The helpline is actively working on 1,235 cases of missing young travellers. Of this number, 10 per cent are foreign nationals believed to have disappeared in the UK and 4 per cent are Britons missing overseas. The US, France and Germany are the countries most commonly listed for a last sighting of a missing person.

The National Missing Persons Helpline is on 020 8392 4545

webTitle: Hotel bargains when Olympic flame dies

fields.headline: Hotel bargains when Olympic flame dies
fields.trailText: Tour operators are predicting that there will be plenty of bargains down under after the Olympic flag has been lowered.
fields.body:
A deluxe 18-night Olympic package with flights, five-star hotel accommodation and tickets for Friday's opening ceremony and top athletic events would have set you back around £15,000 - a prohibitive price tag for most people. But tour operators are predicting that there will be plenty of bargains down under after the Olympic flag has been lowered.

Flight specialist Trailfinders has fares for under £500 with Japan Airlines available until the end of September, and for £677 with Qantas and British Airways in the pre-Christmas period.

An extra 2,000 hotel rooms were built in Sydney in the run up to the Olympics, which should mean some competitive accommodation packages as hoteliers seek to fill the extra beds. Andrea Robinson, Travel 2's Australasia product manager, said the best deals would not filter through until after the peak Christmas period: 'With so many new hotels, the increased competition will inevitably mean better deals for visitors to Sydney. This is particularly true in the four and five-star market; some have reduced rates for next spring by up to 10 per cent.'

A recent survey by American Express Foreign Exchange shows that Australia and New Zealand top the league of good value destinations for British travellers. While the pound is dipping against the currencies of several leading long-haul destinations, including the US and Hong Kong, it is steadily increasing in strength against the Australian and NZ dollars.

Last September £1 would have bought you NZ$3. One year later it buys NZ$3.30 - a 10 per cent increase.

The countries are also benefiting from a resurgence of Asian currencies. Robinson said: 'While the Far East remains cheaper than Australia and New Zealand, the difference is not so great as in previous years. With the recovery of the Asian markets there are fewer cheap packages to Thailand and Indonesia.'

fields.headline: Life's rich tapas trays
fields.standfirst: Sheryl Garratt found Italian ice cream, German coffee and, eventually, real Spanish snacks in Mallorca
fields.trailText: Sheryl Garratt found Italian ice cream, German coffee and, eventually, real Spanish snacks in Mallorca.
fields.body:
Mallorca is an island celebrated for its beauty. I've been there a few times and know all about the fertile valleys, scenic mountains, shady citrus groves, fine restaurants and picturesque villages. Yet somehow, up till now, I' d never managed to see any of it.

Mallorca - or Majorca, as we called it then - was where we took our first family holiday abroad. I was 14 and it was heaven, a two-week package of sun, sea, sangria, hotel discos and all-you-can-eat BBQ excursions. We didn't see a great deal of the island, but my parents came back to Birmingham with the copy of 'Y Viva Espana' they' ve played at every family get-together since and I flew home feeling worldly and sophisticated with a sombrero on my head and a 3ft high plastic donkey on my lap. It was, we all agreed, a perfect holiday.

Later, I came back with friends from the club world to visit BCM in Magaluf, Europe's biggest disco and a regular summer stopover for British DJs. The hospitality of the club' s manager, Toni Palmer, is legendary, and his guests always end up going to bed early. Usually a day or two after they first enter his establishment. So it is that I know more about Magaluf bar life than is perhaps healthy or desirable and am also familiar with a handful of charming after-hours clubs and bars in the island's capital, Palma. I've even staggered into the cathedral there once, admiring the Gothic architecture and examining in a dazed and confused way the rather peculiar altar added by Antoni Gaudí before wandering off for some long overdue sleep.

But this time, things were going to be different. This time, we had our four-year-old son and an air-conditioned Volvo that was a pleasure to drive. Finally, we were going to explore Mallorca. And after the gaudy bustle of Magaluf, the first revelation was our tranquil base on the south-east coast. Porto Petro is the kind of place brochures still like to call 'a sleepy fishing village', although it is now more a marina for tourist sailing boats, surrounded by restaurants with menus in several languages. But it's protected from over-development by its lack of beach and our villa stood on a quiet, pine-shaded road that was only a short walk from the waterside but felt like a private retreat.

For the first few days, we barely strayed from the safe, sandy twin coves of nearby Cala Mondrago. We drove, but a van pulled a cute little tourist 'train' through the resorts strung along this part of the coast several times a day, ferrying its red-skinned cargo to the beaches. Mondrago is its last stop and also the prettiest. Both of its beaches had clear, clean water shelving gently into the sea. The closer of the two boasted a big restaurant pumping out loud music and an endless supply of chips, bumper-to-bumper sunbeds and children splashing in and out of the sea while screaming loudly in a variety of languages. The other beach, accessed along a long concrete path, was far more peaceful, with only a small booth serving drinks and hiring out sun-beds. (No prizes for guessing which one our son preferred.)

Lunch came most days from a man selling melon, pineapple and coconut on the beach, all of which he' d expertly cut using a lethal-looking machete. Children who you suspect never touch fruit at home queued to buy from him and our son developed a taste for watermelon that has lasted long after the holiday ended. At night we ate at first in the excellent restaurants overlooking Porto Pedro' s marina. The lobster we ordered one night was delicious but took well over an hour to arrive: great if you' re sharing a bottle of wine or two with friends; an eternity if you're trying to entertain a small boy who cannot understand why food should ever take longer than a Big Mac and fries.

At home, one of our solutions to the fast food versus good food conundrum is tapas: the food comes quickly, there' s endless variety and lots of different things for picky kids to try. But in Mallorca, the problem was finding it. Only one place in Porto Petro claimed to serve tapas, but their technique of coating every ingredient in thick batter before chucking it into the deep-fat fryer for what seemed like an hour owed more to Scottish chip shops than Spanish bars. Along the coast we found wood-fired pizzerias, an Italian ice-cream parlour, German-run cafes - but no tapas.

So we drove around the island. A restaurant in a back-street in the north-west resort of Port de Pollença offered a delicious bread-and-vegetable stew as part of a ridiculously cheap set lunch. A café at the Mirador de ses Barques up in the mountains had cold drinks and breathtaking views down to the sea. Down among the citrus groves by Sóller, we drank a fresh orange juice at a table shaded by the trees the fruit had been picked from. But by tapas-time, the culinary trail had grown cold. The day-trippers had left and lovely Deià seemed to have closed for the night, so we drove on and finally ended up in a promising-looking bar opposite the church in nearby Calvià with a cold beer and a plate of assorted mashed vegetable bits that was called tapas but looked more like something you see thrown up in the gutter in Magaluf after the bars have closed.

It was the end of the week before we left the beach again and ventured into Palma. It is a beautiful city, interesting and easy to walk around with fantastic shops and delis, extravagant turn-of-the-century modernista exteriors, cafés in shady squares selling excellent food and coffee at a fraction of the price of the resorts. And it was at the end of the day here that we finally found our perfect tapas. There are plenty of establishments along or around Passeig d'es Born and Avinguda d'Antoni Maura serving fresh snacks at the bar or at little Formica tables and I'd like to tell you we found a hidden gem among those. But our son was tired and hungry, so we chose El Pilon from the Rough Guide To Mallorca . Judging by the testimo nials on the wall outside in Calle can Cifre, the authors weren't sharing a secret either: most of the guidebooks in Europe seem to list this dark, cramped little establishment.

It's easy to see why. When we arrived just at opening time, the staff were still enjoying a drink together at one of the back tables, and although they gestured us to sit and wait, our arrival did nothing to hurry the three men through an evening ritual they looked as if they had enjoyed together for many years. Later, when the place was full, they moved effortlessly around each other in the tiny cooking area stuffed behind the bar, dancers in a ballet choreographed by only time; the chef occasionally pulled a ladder out from above the cooker and hoisted his bulky form effortlessly up into the roof to bring down pots or ingredients, the two waiters stepped elegantly around him and a vast array of dishes were cooked and served from the tiny kitchen with a minimum of fuss.

The drama came from the locals who popped by for a drink, leaning against the bar while shouting, gesticulating and theatrically sharing the day's news. ('Are they fighting?' asked our son anxiously.)

While we tucked in to tender grilled squid, garlic prawns, lemony sardines, vegetables so delicately fried they could have been tempura and a fine selection of breads, cheeses and salads, he picked at choice morsels and enjoyed the cabaret the waiters laid on especially for him. Between memorising and delivering long orders to and from the crowded tables, assembling dishes, flirting with a table of black-clad matrons and catching up with the gossip at the bar, our waiter managed to fish a live lobster out of the tank by the door for our child to examine, and keep up complicated games of tickling, chasing and face-pulling that kept him fully amused for an hour. This is what I've come to love about eating out in Mediterranean countries: children are a natural part of the process, not ignored, tolerated or catered to with separate menus.

Flying home we all agreed that Mallorca is indeed beautiful. We hadn't bought a donkey or even seen a sombrero, but 25 years after my first trip there, the island can still provide the perfect family holiday.

 Sheryl Garratt's visit to Mallorca was arranged by Meon Villas (01730 230370). She stayed at the four-star Casa Baskings in Porto Petro where prices start at £432 per person for one week (based on six sharing). This includes flights from Gatwick, welcome pack, twice-week maid service and car with unlimited mileage.

But our son was tired and hungry, so we chose El Pilon from the Rough Guide To Mallorca . Judging by the testimo nials on the wall outside in Calle can Cifre, the authors weren't sharing a secret either: most of the guidebooks in Europe seem to list this dark, cramped little establishment. It's easy to see why. When we arrived just at opening time, the staff were still enjoying a drink together at one of the back tables, and although they gestured us to sit and wait, our arrival did nothing to hurry the three men through an evening ritual they looked as if they had enjoyed together for many years. Later, when the place was full, they moved effortlessly around each other in the tiny cooking area stuffed behind the bar, dancers in a ballet choreographed by only time; the chef occasionally pulled a ladder out from above the cooker and hoisted his bulky form effortlessly up into the roof to bring down pots or ingredients, the two waiters stepped elegantly around him and a vast array of dishes were cooked and served from the tiny kitchen with a minimum of fuss. The drama came from the locals who popped by for a drink, leaning against the bar while shouting, gesticulating and theatrically sharing the day's news. ('Are they fighting?' asked our son anxiously.) While we tucked in to tender grilled squid, garlic prawns, lemony sardines, vegetables so delicately fried they could have been tempura and a fine selection of breads, cheeses and salads, he picked at choice morsels and enjoyed the cabaret the waiters laid on especially for him. Between memorising and delivering long orders to and from the crowded tables, assembling dishes, flirting with a table of black-clad matrons and catching up with the gossip at the bar, our waiter managed to fish a live lobster out of the tank by the door for our child to examine, and keep up complicated games of tickling, chasing and face-pulling that kept him fully amused for an hour. This is what I've come to love about eating out in Mediterranean countries: children are a natural part of the process, not ignored, tolerated or catered to with separate menus. Flying home we all agreed that Mallorca is indeed beautiful. We hadn't bought a donkey or even seen a sombrero, but 25 years after my first trip there, the island can still provide the perfect family holiday.  Sheryl Garratt's visit to Mallorca was arranged by Meon Villas (01730 230370). She stayed at the four-star Casa Baskings in Porto Petro where prices start at £432 per person for one week (based on six sharing). This includes flights from Gatwick, welcome pack, twice-week maid service and car with unlimited mileage.

fields.headline: Let's go!
fields.standfirst: Ten things to do today
fields.trailText: Buxton Country Music Festival | Creating Sparks | Osborne House
fields.body:
 Kick up your heels at the Buxton Country Music Festival. The Octagon Pavilion Gardens (01298 23114) are the venue for a variety of Country and Western music artists, line dancing classes and country music trade stands. Stetsons are optional. Open 12.30pm to 11pm. Adults £9.

 The Natural History Museum, Science Museum and Victoria & Albert Museum open their doors to the public free of charge today as part of South Kensington's Creating Sparks festival of art and science. Exhibition Road will be closed to traffic from 11am to 4pm for a free street carnival with acrobats, abseilers, tightrope walkers, street theatre, music and food stalls.

 The head gardener at Osborne House (01983 200022) will give guided tours of the grounds of Queen Victoria's former residence on the Isle of Wight. These start at 2pm and take in the walled garden and shrubberies. Adults £3; children £2; free for under-fives.

 Pink Lace is Nottingham's annual gay and lesbian festival, taking place today at Victoria Embankment on the banks of the River Trent. Festivities include live music and cabaret, a dance tent, a funfair, bars and a children's play area. Noon to 7pm. Admission free (0780 3885857).

 Screeching tyres and burning rubber will be the order of the day at the FIA European Drag Racing Championships at Santa Pod Raceway in Northamptonshire. Tickets for the event, which originated in illegal street racing in America in the Fifties, will be available at the gate. Opens 10am. Adults £20, under-16s free (08700 782828).

 Regent Street, London, will be closed to traffic for the first time today for a festival in aid of Sargent Cancer Care for Children. There will be live music, open-air cafes, barbecues, a fairground, toy stalls, children's activities in Hamleys toy store and an aerial display team. Noon to 8pm. Admission free (020 7491 4429).

 North Yorkshire's Bilsdale Silver Band will play a selection of classical favourites from Gilbert and Sullivan to The Lion King at Rievaulx Abbey (01439 798228). The concert starts at 2pm. Adults £3.40; children £1.70; under-fives free.

 Watch classic cars chasing a flotilla of hot-air balloons at the Balloon and Vintage Car Fiesta at Leeds Castle, Maidstone, Kent (01622 765400). Balloon races will take place at 7.30am and 6pm. There will be a champagne tent and free-fall parachute display. Open 6.30am to 6pm.

 Join the Pre-War Austin Club annual vintage car rally at Belsay Hall (01661 881636) near Newcastle. Vehicles dating from the 1920s to the 1970s will leave Newcastle Civic Centre at 10.30am, arriving at Belsay Hall at 11.30am where they will be on display for the afternoon. Adults £3.80; children £1.90.

 Learn how to recreate a typical Victorian dish at Kenwood House in London (020 8348 1286). Enjoy the cookery demonstrations and explore Kenwood's Eat Drink and Be Merry exhibition which looks at British food through the ages. Adults £2, children £1.

fields.headline: Where guests come first
fields.standfirst: Caroline Raphael, editor of  The Good Hotel Guide, picks 50 of the best from the 2000-2001 edition
fields.trailText: Caroline Raphael, editor of The Good Hotel Guide, picks 50 of the best from the 2000-2001 edition.
fields.body:
The best way to find a good hotel is by personal recommendation and The Good Hotel Guide could be described as word-of-mouth in print. A good hotel was defined by Hilary Rubinstein, who founded the Guide 24 years ago, as: 'Where the guest comes first.'

We look for hotels of unusual character and quality. They are usually on the small side and owner-managed; almost no hotels in the book belong to a chain, since these usually fail to provide the welcome and care for guests' comfort that can be found in the best of the small, individually owned hotels. Most have been recommended by correspondents who have taken the trouble to write to us. We verify and collate the reports, making an anonymous overnight inspection where necessary.

The Guide is independent: we accept no free hospitality, contributors are not paid for writing to us and hotels do not pay for their entry. This gives us the freedom to criticise where appropriate. The entries are updated each year. Hotels are dropped if critical reports outweigh those in favour, if we have had no reports for some time or if there has been a change of ownership, unless we are sure that standards have been maintained. Despite the name, we also include inns, guest houses and B&Bs, since many of our readers like their good value and lack of formality.

Each year 10 special hotels are given our César award for excellence. Some of the winners in the 2001 edition are included in this selection (they are marked with a laurel leaf).

Town house hotels

One of the interesting trends in recent years has been the development of the small townhouse hotel in major cities.

1 Hotel on the Park
Evesham Road, Cheltenham, Gloucestershire. GL52 2AH
01242 518898; fax 01242 511526
email stay@hotelonthepark.co.uk
www.hotelonthepark.co.uk

Regency townhouse across road from Pittville Park, five minutes' walk from centre. Elegant decor (fine antiques, swagged curtains); friendly owner, Darryl Gregory; small garden. Contemporary British cooking. Thirteen bedrooms. B&B £48.31 to £86.71. Set dinner £22.50.

2 Haley's
Shire Oak Road, Headingley, Leeds, West Yorkshire LS6 2DE
0113 278 4446; fax 0113 275 3342
email info@haleys.co.uk
www.haleys.co.uk

John Appleyard's turreted Victorian house in leafy suburb near university. Open fires, period furniture, lavish drapes. Friendly staff; very comfortable rooms. Lounge/bar, library, restaurant with modern cooking. Twenty-nine bedrooms. B&B £42.50 to £120. Set dinner £25.

3 Hazlitt's
6 Frith Street, London W1V 5TZ
020 743 41771; fax 020 7439 1524
email reservations@hazlitts.co.uk
www.hazlittshotel.com

In Soho: three eighteenth-century terrace houses (the essayist lived in one), now a small, trendy hotel. Edwardian decor. Continental breakfast (£7.25) brought to the bedroom. Twenty-three bedrooms: single £140, double £175, suite £300.

4 Number Sixteen
16 Sumner Place, London SW7 3EG
020 75895232; fax 020 75848615
email reservations@numbersixteenhotel.co.uk
www.numbersixteenhotel.co.uk

In residential street near South Kensington underground station, one of London's first townhouse hotels: attractive conversion of four houses. Conservatory; flower garden with fountain; chintzy lounge, library. Thirty-six bedrooms. B&B £85 to £143.

5 Eleven Didsbury Park
11 Didsbury Park, Didsbury Village, Manchester M20 5LH
0161 4487711; fax 0161 4488282
email enquiries@elevendidsburypark.com
www.elevendidsburypark.com

Eamonn and Sally O'Loughlin's Victorian townhouse in conservation area, 20 minutes by bus from centre. Informal; modern decor. Terrace, walled garden, rooftop terrace with hot tub; pleasant breakfast room; snack menu. Fourteen bedrooms: double £69.50 to £119.50.

6 Horton Grange
Seaton Burn, Newcastle upon Tyne NE13 6BU
01661 860686; fax 01661 860308
email andrew@horton-grange.co.uk;
www.horton-grange.co.uk

In open country six miles north of centre, Sue and Andrew Shilton's stone-built house in four-acre grounds with water garden. Home-like feel; good breakfasts and dinners in conservatory style restaurant. Thirteen bedrooms. B&B £37.50 to £74. Set dinner £34.

7 Morgans
The Townhouse, 34 The Ropewalk, The Park, Nottingham NG1 5DW
0115 957 0017; fax 0115 957 0018
email info@morgans34.com
www.morgans34.com

Kathy Morgan's Grade II listed nineteenth-century house on leafy ridge above the Park (conservation area). Stylish conversion retaining original features. Five spacious rooms with big bed, fresh fruit, flowers, excellent bathroom. Complimentary drinks in panelled lounge. Good breakfast. Electronically gated carpark. B&B £55 to £120.

8 The Mansion House
Thames Street, Poole, Dorset BH15 1JN
01202 685666; fax 01202 665709
email enquiries@themansionhouse.co.uk
www.themansionhouse.co.uk

Eighteenth-century townhouse in quiet cul-de-sac. Grand staircase; stylish lounge. Exemplary management by Jackie Godden; interesting cooking by her husband, Gerry, in restaurant and bar/bistro. Thirty-two bedrooms. B&B £44.50 to £88. Set meal £16.25 to £23.50.

9 The Bonham
25 Drumsheugh Gardens, Edinburgh EH3 7RN
0131 226 6050; fax 0131 226 6080
email reserve@thebonham.com
www.thebonham.com

Posh, chic and pricey: two Victorian buildings in quiet square, now designer hotel. Paintings by Scottish artists throughout. Californian-inspired food in restaurant (open to the public). Forty-eight bedrooms, full of hi-tech. B&B £77.50 to£165. À la carte meal £34.

10 The Town House
4 Hughenden Terrace, Hyndland, Glasgow G12 9XR
0141 357 0862; fax 0141 339 9605
email hospitality@thetownhouseglasgow.com
www.thetownhouseglasgow.com

Not smart, but reasonably priced and welcoming: Michael Ferguson's B&B, in Victorian sandstone building on quiet street in conservation area. Deep cornices, high ceilings, carved architraves, simple furnishings, easy parking. Eight bedrooms. B&B £34 to £58.

Romantic hotels

A selection of fine buildings in a lovely setting; you can get married in some of them.

1 Burgh Island Hotel
Burgh Island, Bigbury-on-Sea, Devon TQ7 4BG
01548 810514, fax 01548 810243
email reception@burghisland.com
www.burghisland.com

Lovingly restored by Tony and Beatrice Porter: Art Deco extravaganza on private island in Bigbury Bay. Twenties/Thirties furniture, fittings and cocktails. Peacock-domed palm court; sun lounge; dinner in ballroom (formal dress). Natural swimming pool in rocks; beach. Fifteen suites. Dinner, B&B £110 to £172.

2 Gravetye Manor
Vowels Lane, East Grinstead West Sussex RH19 4LJ
01342 810567; fax 01342 810080
email gravetye@relaischateaux.fr

Handy for honeymooners (12 miles from Gatwick airport): Peter Herbert's luxury hotel in magnificent grounds designed by William Robinson. Tudor drawing room with carved wood. Eighteen bedrooms: double £120 to £280. Breakfast £14 to £16. Set dinner £38 or £48.

3 Combe House
Gittisham, near Honiton, Devon EX14 3AD
01404 540400; fax 01404 46004
email stay@thishotel.com
www.thishotel.com

Grade I listed Elizabethan manor house with nineteenth-century additions. On hill in vast Devon estate (woodland, meadows, pastures with Arabian horses). Panelled public rooms have plastered ceilings, ancestral portraits, antiques. Friendly owners, Ruth and Ken Hunt, and staff. Fifteen bedrooms. Dinner, B&B £83 to £130.

4 Hambleton Hall
Hambleton, Oakham, Rutland LE15 8TH
01572 756991; fax 01572 724721
email hotel@hambletonhall.com
www.hambletonhall.com

Victorian pile on peninsula in Rutland Water, now Tim and Stefa Hart's luxury hotel: sophisticated decor; Michelin-starred restaurant; manicured gardens with terrace (alfresco breakfasts), swimming pool. Seventeen bedrooms. B&B £85 to£160. Set dinner £35 to £40.

5 Bolebroke Mill
Edenbridge Road, Hartfield, East Sussex TN7 4JP
01892 770425; fax 01892 770425
email b+b@bolebrokemill.demon.co.uk

Domesday-old watermill, mill house and Elizabethan barn by tree-lined stream with ducks and geese. Now David and Christine Cooper's B&B. Five cottagey bedrooms; two up steep loft ladder. Award-winning breakfast, communally served. B&B double £65 to £78.

6 Lavenham Priory
Water Street, Lavenham, Suffolk CO10 9RW
01787 247404; fax 01787 248472
email tim.pitt@btinternet.com
www.lavenhampriory.co.uk

Lavishly restored by Tim and Gilli Pitt: Grade I listed thirteenth-century house: Elizabethan wall paintings, oak floors, Jacobean staircase, exotic beds (four-poster, bateau, polonaise). Lovely garden. Communal breakfast; dinner by arrangement. Five bedrooms. B&B £39 to £69.

7 The Beetle and Wedge
Ferry Lane, Moulsford-on-Thames, Oxfordshire OX10 9JF
01491 651381; fax 01491 651376

In magical Thames-side setting on manicured lawns: Richard and Kate Smith's old inn. French cooking in main restaurant; informal food in Boathouse; water garden for summer meals. Handy for Heathrow. Fourteen bedrooms. B&B £67.50 to £120, double £135 to £150. À la carte meal £31.50 to £48.50.

8 Ynyshir Hall
Eglwysfach, near Machynlleth, Powys SY20 8TA
01654 781209; fax 01654 781366
email info@ynyshir-hall.co.uk
www.ynyshir-hall.co.uk

Rob and Joan Reen's white Georgian longhouse in landscaped gardens on Dyfi estuary, surrounded by RSPB reserve. Bright colours, paintings, excellent meals, lavish breakfasts. Ten bedrooms. B&B £60 to £135. Dinner £36.

9 Bodysgallen Hall
Llanrhos, Llandudno, Conwy LL30 1RS
01492 584466; fax 01492 582519
email info@bodysgallen.com
www.bodysgallen.com

In large hillside park: seventeenth-century Grade 1 listed mansion, immaculately restored (panelled rooms, ancestral portraits, mullioned windows), now a luxury hotel. Spa (54ft swimming pool, gym, beauty salons), knot garden, rose garden. Thirty-six bedrooms: single £99-£104, double £140-£235. Breakfast £13.50. Dinner £33.90.

10 Ardanaiseig
Kilchrenan by Taynuilt, Argyll and Bute PA35 1HE
01866 833333; fax 01866 833222
email ardanaiseig@clara.net
www.ardanaiseig.com

In huge estate on Loch Awe: Scottish baronial mansion in glorious, rambling gardens; highland cattle in pasture; classical Greek-style amphitheatre (performances of song and dance held). Sixteen bedrooms. B&B: £73 to £120. Set dinner £35.

Breakfast

All too often, after a good dinner and a comfortable night, breakfast is a letdown, with off-hand service, packaged jams and butters, commercial juice and toast, and teabag tea. In the places listed below, it is something special.

1 Little Barwick House
Barwick, Somerset BA22 9TD
01935 423902; fax 01935 420908

Georgian house in garden near Yeovil: run by Tim and Emma Ford, with emphasis on food. Breakfast includes fresh orange juice (seconds offered) and they know how to scramble eggs. Six bedrooms. B&B £42 to £46.50; D,B&B £60 to £66.50.

2 Michael's Nook
Grasmere, Cumbria LA22 9RP
015394 35496; fax 015394 35645
email m-nook@wordsworth-grasmere.co.uk
www.grasmere-hotels.co.uk

Full of character: stone house in gardens above Grasmere. Run by Reg Gifford. Excellent modern cooking in Michelin-starred restaurant. Breakfast as good: freshly squeezed juices, leaf tea, cold meats, cheeses, impeccably cooked eggs. Fourteen bedrooms. Dinner, B&B £90 to £205.

3 The Old Rectory
Hopesay, Craven Arms, Shropshire
01588 660245; fax 01588 660502

Home-made yogurt and preserves, fruit compote, home-baked bread and traditional cooked dishes are served by Roma and Michael Villar at their guest house in a hamlet above Clun valley. Sophisticated house party-style evening meal, with good wine, reasonably priced. Landscaped gardens. Three bedrooms. B&B £37.50. Set dinner £22.50.

4 Penrhos Court
Kington, Herefordshire HR5 3LH
01544 230720; fax 01544 230754
email martin@penrhos.co.uk
www.penrhos.co.uk

Tranquil collection of ancient buildings around pond with wildlife: now Martin Griffiths and Daphne Lambert's smoke-free, Muzak-free, eco-friendly hotel. Good organic dinners. Breakfast has freshly squeezed fruit and vegetable juices (eg, cucumber), wholemeal bread, organic honey and preserves; no fry-up, but Welsh rarebit or tofu sausages. 15 bedrooms. Dinner, B&B from £80.

5 Lea Hill Hotel
Membury, near Axminster, Devon EX13 7AQ
01404 881881; fax 01404 881890
www.leahillhotel.co.uk

In large grounds on hilltop, in designated area of outstanding natural beauty: Chris and Sue Hubbard's fourteenth-century thatched longhouse (beams, flagstone floors, inglenook fireplaces). Good dinners. Breakfasts include freshly squeezed orange juice, local sausages and black pudding, Manx kippers, smoked Finnan haddock. Eleven bedrooms, most with private patio or garden. B&B £56 to £68. Dinner, B&B £78 to £89.

6 Howard's House
Teffont Evias, Wiltshire SP3 5RJ
01722 716392; fax 01722 716820
email paul.firmin@virgin.net
www.howardshousehotel.co.uk

In picture-postcard village near Salisbury, quirky Swiss-style building (steeply pitched, broad-eaved roof), in garden by River Teff. Informally run by owner/chef Paul Firmin. Excellent dinners. Freshly squeezed orange juice and well-presented cooked dishes for breakfast. Nine bedrooms. B&B £47.50 to £75. Set dinner £19.95.

7 The Old Vicarage
66 Church Square, Rye, East Sussex TN31 7HF
01797 222119; fax 01797 227466
email oldvicaragerye@tesco.net
www.homepages.tesco.net~oldvicaragerye

Paul and Julia Masters's pink B&B in eighteenth-century ex-vicarage. Breakfast, in bay-windowed room by garden, has properly brewed tea, home-made scones, bread and jams, free-range eggs, award-winning sausages. Tea on arrival, evening sherry, morning newspaper, included in price: B&B £18.50 to £37.

8 Sharrow Bay
Ullswater, near Penrith, Cumbria CA10 2LZ
01768 486301; fax 01768 486349
email enquiries@sharrow-bay.com
www.sharrow-bay.com

The original country house hotel, pampering and luxurious. Michelin-starred restaurant with lavish menus. Breakfast with veteran owner Brian Sack in attendance, white-coated waiters, fresh juices, fruit, porridge with cream, huge range of cooked dishes. Twenty-six bedrooms. Dinner, B&B £120 to £145.

9 Three Chimneys Restaurant and House
Over-by, Colbost, Isle of Skye, Highland IV55 8ZT
01470 511258; fax 01470 511358
email eatandstay@threechimneys.co.uk
www.threechimneys.co.uk

On edge of sea loch (much wildlife): restaurant with six luxury suites in house across courtyard. Brilliant modern design. Very good dinners in beamed, candlelit dining rooms. Breakfast has porridge with cream, smoked duck, venison and salmon, home-made oatcakes and jams. B&B double £130 to £155. À la carte dinner £45.

10 Clifton House
Viewfield Street, Nairn, Highland IV12 4HW
01667 453119; fax 01667 452836
email macintyre@clifton-hotel.co.uk
www.clifton-hotel.co.uk

Wonderfully eccentric hotel in rose-covered Victorian stone villa. Octogenarian owner J. Gordon Macintyre presides over good restaurant, occasional theatricals. Breakfasts (no time limit) include large choice of teas, porridge, home-made oatcakes, free-range eggs, fresh kippers. Twelve bedrooms. Dinner, B&B £85.
