fields.headline: Nigel Slater's mushroom recipes
fields.standfirst: Is there a more perfect start to a Sunday morning  than digging into a luscious breakfast of  butter-fried mushrooms on toast?
fields.trailText:
Is there a more perfect start to a Sunday morning
than digging into a luscious breakfast of
butter-fried mushrooms on toast?
fields.body:
Early morning, open window, church bells, birdsong, Sunday papers, mushrooms on toast. Utter bliss. At least, I see it that way. Others may notice that last night's wine bottles and empty glasses are still on the table, the open window looks out on to someone else's bathroom and the peal of church bells is drowned out every time a bus passes. The birds are not nightingales, but city pigeons stuffing their faces with my elderberries, and who will relieve themselves in magnificent purple splatters down my freshly cleaned windows. Still, the mushrooms on toast are genuine enough.

When I am asked (for the 200th time) to name my favourite food, I invariably mutter, 'Mashed potato.' In truth, that is more a comfort thing and has more to do with my state of mind than my tastebuds. What I should really say is, 'Mushrooms on toast.' But they need to be quite perfect; that is, cooked thoughtfully, tenderly and with almost obsessive attention to detail.

The toast must be cut thick and from a good, old-fashioned white loaf. It should be crisp, even faintly burned around the edges, forming a soggy hollow towards the middle, on which will be perched one, two or three flat mushrooms as soft as velvet and as black as your hat. There must be butter and plenty of it. This is not bruschetta - olive oil and garlic have no place here. This is the best of the something-on-toasts. Crunchy, soggy, buttery, velvety and woodsy - that's a mouthful of mushrooms on toast.

Remember the way Richard Bohringer buttered his baguette in Diva ? Well, I can, of a late-summer Sunday morning, get as fixated by making my mushrooms on toast. No fancy fungi, thank you. With due respect, you can keep your pleurottes, girolles, porcini and trompettes de la mort. Field mushrooms are what we want at this point, and as I am being a touch perfectionist about the whole thing, I think they should be the sort whose gills open flat rather than the ones that sit cup-shaped. Of course this is perfection we are talking about. But why not? There is more pleasure to be had in getting something right.

The bread-and-mushroom idea is a pleasing enough way to start the day, but it can just as easily lapse into lunch, though by then it might well be using some of those posh toadstools I cannot face at breakfast. We could also involve a crushed clove of garlic or two, some olive oil and even a scattering of oregano or basil. Some tender salad can sit at the side, too, so that their fragile leaves virtually melt into the warm mushroom juices. I recommend that you try a mushroom bap. Bake the largest fungi you can lay your hands on with garlic butter and sandwich them between a floury bun. I use a bit more butter than I would normally here so that it moistens the soft, doughy bread.

Baked mushrooms take on a warm, savoury depth if you include mustard and a palmful of tarragon or oregano leaves. Add to that a squeeze of lemon and we are approaching a supper of almost beefsteak toothsomeness. My father used to upend the Mushroom Ketchup bottle over his, which sounds like coals to Newcastle, yet he swore by its salty-sharp seasoning. I am sure he was right. Even now, I won't argue with him.

Depending on how they are to be eaten, you can grill, fry or bake mushrooms with equal success. The trick is simply to keep them moist. This need not be with butter, although it is tempting. I have baked a terracotta dish of them with a spoonful of balsamic vinegar and a little water before now and not a knob of butter in sight, and they stayed silky, the vinegar for once having good reason to be there.

Cream is an obvious choice when baking fungi, though one I turn to less often than I did. Such luxury - especially if you fry some finely chopped shallot first, taking care it doesn't colour, then introduce some white wine or, better still, Madeira. You can pour seasoned cream (salt, pepper, and don't forget the nutmeg) over some lightly fried chestnut mushrooms, then bake them in a moderate oven till bubbling. It takes about half an hour from start to sumptuous finish. But I am sounding a lush.

If mushrooms alone are not enough, you might like to mix them with another ingredient. At this time of year, I suggest mussels. It is a fine, though slightly unexpected marriage and full of salty, earthy depth. Briefly, you could do worse than to steam the mussels and pick them from their shells, then tip them into a shallow pan of sautéed button mushrooms, garlic and just a little cream. Thick toast to mop up the juice would be good.

Other mycological marriages with bread include the large capped variety, now christened portabella or portabello in some shops, stuffed with crabmeat or minced prawns, seasoned with finely chopped fried onion, a little pepper and ground mace, then coated with a thin layer of fine, fresh breadcrumbs. I hadn't believed the crabmeat and mushroom match till I tried it, despite it being a favourite of the late Mrs Grigson. Which reminds me of that forgotten autumnal starter of deep-fried mushrooms in crisp breadcrumbs, the sort you used to dip into garlic mayonnaise before we discovered the far more flattering salsa verde.

Oh, and did I mention that the mushrooms should have been in a bag in the fridge for a day or so, so that they become a bit damp and woodsy, and smell like an autumn forest underfoot?

Baked mushrooms with tarragon mustard butter

Serves 2

4 large field mushrooms

for the tarragon mustard butter

125g butter
2 level tbsp smooth Dijon mustard
the leaves pulled from 8 or 9 stems of tarragon
the juice of half a lemon
olive oil

Cut the butter into cubes and mash it in a small bowl with a wooden spoon. You could use a food processor but I am not sure you really need to. Add the mustard, the roughly chopped tarragon leaves, and a few grinds of salt and pepper, then squeeze in the lemon juice. Mix to a thick paste.

Lay the mushrooms in a roasting tin; they can be snug but only barely overlapping. Trim the stalks if they are woody, or even remove them entirely, then fill their hollows with the butter, dividing it up more or less equally, then drizzle with olive oil.

Cover the tin with foil or baking parchment, then bake at 200 C/gas mark 6, basting the mushrooms from time to time with the melted butter and pan juices. When they are tender and sodden with juice - a matter of 25-30 minutes or so - serve with rice, toast or sandwiched between two soft baps. Take care not to waste any of the hot herb butter.

Potatoes, baked mushrooms, cream and Parmesan

Serves 3 as a principal dish, 6 as a side dish.

a plump, juicy clove of garlic, peeled and cut in half
30g butter
600g waxy yellow-fleshed potatoes
150g white mushrooms
600ml whipping cream
Parmesan for grating
a handful of fresh, white breadcrumbs

Take a shallow, earthenware dish, a good 30cm across, and rub it hard with the garlic (this discreetly seasons the dish). Rub the lump of butter around, leaving about half of it smeared on the dish.

Peel and slice the potatoes - they should be a little thicker than a pound coin. Make a layer of overlapping slices in the bottom of the dish with half of the potatoes, then season with salt and pepper. Slice the mushrooms likewise, and lay them over the potatoes. Dust with salt and pepper, then place the rest of potatoes on top, covering up the mushrooms as best you can. Grind again with salt and pepper.

Mix the cream with a faint dusting of nutmeg, if you have it, then pour it over the potatoes. It won't quite cover. Grate over a fine layer of cheese, then scatter with the breadcrumbs. Dot the rest of the butter on top and bake for 60 minutes at 150 C/gas mark 4, nudging the heat up to 180 C/gas mark 5 for a further 30 minutes. The potatoes and mushrooms should be soft enough to take the point of a knife, the crust golden and the cream bubbling.

A green mushroom salad

Enough for 2 as a side dish.

200g small mushrooms
the juice of a lemon
a small handful of basil leaves
a small handful of watercress leaves
1 tbsp young tarragon leaves, or Thai (aniseed) basil
6 tbsp olive oil

Cut the mushrooms in half, no matter how small, and put in a bowl. Squeeze in the lemon and set aside for at least 30 minutes (they will produce a lot of juice). Put the basil, watercress, tarragon, olive oil and a little salt into a blender. Drain the juice from the mushrooms and add that, then whiz to a thick green slush. Toss the mushrooms in the green sauce and serve. Jolly good with cold roast beef.
fields.bodyText: Early morning, open window, church bells, birdsong, Sunday papers, mushrooms on toast. Utter bliss. At least, I see it that way. Others may notice that last night's wine bottles and empty glasses are still on the table, the open window looks out on to someone else's bathroom and the peal of church bells is drowned out every time a bus passes. The birds are not nightingales, but city pigeons stuffing their faces with my elderberries, and who will relieve themselves in magnificent purple splatters down my freshly cleaned windows. Still, the mushrooms on toast are genuine enough. When I am asked (for the 200th time) to name my favourite food, I invariably mutter, 'Mashed potato.' In truth, that is more a comfort thing and has more to do with my state of mind than my tastebuds. What I should really say is, 'Mushrooms on toast.' But they need to be quite perfect; that is, cooked thoughtfully, tenderly and with almost obsessive attention to detail. The toast must be cut thick and from a good, old-fashioned white loaf. It should be crisp, even faintly burned around the edges, forming a soggy hollow towards the middle, on which will be perched one, two or three flat mushrooms as soft as velvet and as black as your hat. There must be butter and plenty of it. This is not bruschetta - olive oil and garlic have no place here. This is the best of the something-on-toasts. Crunchy, soggy, buttery, velvety and woodsy - that's a mouthful of mushrooms on toast. Remember the way Richard Bohringer buttered his baguette in Diva ? Well, I can, of a late-summer Sunday morning, get as fixated by making my mushrooms on toast. No fancy fungi, thank you. With due respect, you can keep your pleurottes, girolles, porcini and trompettes de la mort. Field mushrooms are what we want at this point, and as I am being a touch perfectionist about the whole thing, I think they should be the sort whose gills open flat rather than the ones that sit cup-shaped. Of course this is perfection we are talking about. But why not? There is more pleasure to be had in getting something right. The bread-and-mushroom idea is a pleasing enough way to start the day, but it can just as easily lapse into lunch, though by then it might well be using some of those posh toadstools I cannot face at breakfast. We could also involve a crushed clove of garlic or two, some olive oil and even a scattering of oregano or basil. Some tender salad can sit at the side, too, so that their fragile leaves virtually melt into the warm mushroom juices. I recommend that you try a mushroom bap. Bake the largest fungi you can lay your hands on with garlic butter and sandwich them between a floury bun. I use a bit more butter than I would normally here so that it moistens the soft, doughy bread. Baked mushrooms take on a warm, savoury depth if you include mustard and a palmful of tarragon or oregano leaves. Add to that a squeeze of lemon and we are approaching a supper of almost beefsteak toothsomeness. My father used to upend the Mushroom Ketchup bottle over his, which sounds like coals to Newcastle, yet he swore by its salty-sharp seasoning. I am sure he was right. Even now, I won't argue with him. Depending on how they are to be eaten, you can grill, fry or bake mushrooms with equal success. The trick is simply to keep them moist. This need not be with butter, although it is tempting. I have baked a terracotta dish of them with a spoonful of balsamic vinegar and a little water before now and not a knob of butter in sight, and they stayed silky, the vinegar for once having good reason to be there. Cream is an obvious choice when baking fungi, though one I turn to less often than I did. Such luxury - especially if you fry some finely chopped shallot first, taking care it doesn't colour, then introduce some white wine or, better still, Madeira. You can pour seasoned cream (salt, pepper, and don't forget the nutmeg) over some lightly fried chestnut mushrooms, then bake them in a moderate oven till bubbling. It takes about half an hour from start to sumptuous finish. But I am sounding a lush. If mushrooms alone are not enough, you might like to mix them with another ingredient. At this time of year, I suggest mussels. It is a fine, though slightly unexpected marriage and full of salty, earthy depth. Briefly, you could do worse than to steam the mussels and pick them from their shells, then tip them into a shallow pan of sautéed button mushrooms, garlic and just a little cream. Thick toast to mop up the juice would be good. Oh, and did I mention that the mushrooms should have been in a bag in the fridge for a day or so, so that they become a bit damp and woodsy, and smell like an autumn forest underfoot? webTitle: Family waits as custody death inquiry is dogged by delays

fields.headline: Family waits as custody death inquiry is dogged by delays
fields.trailText: From the moment Roger Sylvester died in January last year, after being restrained by officers of the Metropolitan Police, his family began searching for answers.
fields.body:
From the moment Roger Sylvester died in January last year, after being restrained by officers of the Metropolitan Police, his family began searching for answers.

They wanted to know why yet another black man had died as a result of a confrontation with the police. They wanted to know how he died and who, if anybody, was going to be held responsible. Twenty months on, they are no closer to the truth.

Lawyers for the Sylvester family were told last week that the Crown Prosecution Service, which was passed a file on the case last October, will delay any decision on over possible prosecutions until late next month at the earliest. No full inquest into Sylvester's death can be held until a decision over prosecution has been taken.

'Our mother is still traumatised by Roger's death,' said his older brother, Bernard, last week. 'And this is all compounded by the frustration caused by the CPS delay. Why on earth are they taking such a long time? We can't get on with our lives because we have no idea what happened to Roger.'

Sylvester, 30, died a month before the Macpherson Report into the Stephen Lawrence murder was released, branding the police as institutionally racist. The inquiry into his death has been dogged by controversy. He was arrested outside his home in Tottenham, north London, after allegedly being found naked and in an agitated state on 11 January.

He was handcuffed and put in a police van before being taken to a nearby hospital, where he collapsed while being restrained by officers. He was placed on a life support machine but died a week later. Eight officers were subse quently withdrawn from the beat and placed on desk duties.

While Sylvester lay in a coma, the police issued a press release claiming the night he collapsed he had been banging on a neighbour's door in 'an aggressive manner'. The police eventually apologised after it emerged the door in question was his own, and there was no evidence that he had been behaving aggressively.

Later, after the family complained about the conduct of two Criminal Investigation Bureau officers appointed by the Metropolitan Police to investigate the case, the CIB was replaced by a team from Essex Constabulary under the supervision of the Police Complaints Authority.

Their inquiries took eight months. Since then, the CPS has taken a year to consider its findings. Meanwhile the family has heard Sylvester described as a drug addict - claims made on the basis of incorrect medical records.

'Given just how politically sensitive this case has been in the light of the Stephen Lawrence inquiry, you do have to ask whether the Crown has learnt anything at all,' said Deborah Coles of Inquest, an organisation which supports families of those who die as a result of police or prison service custody.

The Metropolitan Police Federation, which represents the eight officers who are still waiting to hear whether they will be prosecuted, has also condemned the CPS delay. A spokesman for the CPS, which itself is awaiting publication of a report into racism in its ranks, said the hold-up was caused by problems in obtaining opinions from expert witnesses.

jay.rayner@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Admiral of the Fleet
fields.standfirst: Dorset's Moonfleet Manor welcomes people with young children. But its restaurant is a very grown-up affair. Jay Rayner went back for seconds, thirds...
fields.trailText: Dorset's Moonfleet Manor welcomes people with young children. But its restaurant is a very grown-up affair. Jay Rayner went back for seconds, thirds...
fields.body:
Never underestimate my commitment to this job. To give you the most accurate appraisal of the restaurant at the Moonfleet Manor Hotel, on the Dorset coast just to the west of Weymouth, I did not merely eat there the once. I did not eat there twice nor even three times. No. I ate there on five - count them - five different occasions in 10 days. Impressive, huh!

Okay. I confess. The 10 days were the family summer holiday and Moonfleet Manor, a glorious place designed specifically for people with young kids (full-on baby listening in every room, hot and cold running milk, a sandpit the size of Shropshire), was where it was taken; I didn't have an enormous amount of choice in the matter. That aside, it was still a useful exercise. Every restaurant has its purpose and how well it succeeds will depend on how well it understands what that purpose is.

There is little doubt, from a quick glance at the menu at Moonfleet's restaurant - a drizzle of balsamic here, a herb crust there - that it is keen to drag in a non-resident crowd looking for that special night out. At the same time it must serve old lags like me in for a longer stretch. Most restaurants deserve to be reviewed on the basis of one visit because that is how most of us experience them; Moonfleet deserves to be tried five times because that is how a lot of its punters will experience it.

And, after a marathon day entertaining the kids, it can be a sublime experience. The long, white-washed dining room at Moonfleet overlooks the Fleet Lagoon, a stretch of water a dozen miles long which was cut off from the sea aeons ago by a massive drift of shingle called Chesil Beach. At sunset on a summer's evening it turns from red to gold and back again as the light fades. Parents, their offspring now abed, would sit each night staring at the scenery with a mix of awe and blessed relief.

Chef Tony Smith has, wisely, taken his inspiration from the view. There's a lot of fish on the menu. A starter of crisp crabcake on an orange saffron butter sauce, for example, could have stood as an advertisement for the quality of the seafood available in this part of the country. If there was anything other than sweet, fibrous crab in the cake it was hiding out of embarrassment. Main courses of roast cod, grilled talapia (a new one on me; it's a bit like bream) and scallops also made a serious virtue of local produce. There were always bells and whistles with each of these dishes - garlicky crushed potatoes with the talapia, an aromatic mussel and ginger broth with the scallops - but the point was always the fish at their heart.

Non-fish dishes were equally accomplished. A double act of a duck pté and duck rilette to start came with a delicate mound of sweet Muscat jelly. A main course of boned pot-roasted quail was stuffed with wild mushrooms and laid upon a gooey risotto cake. Duck breast, with a seriously crispy skin, was accompanied by a lush meaty jus. There is a fine list of rich puddings of the mandarin crème brlée and chocolate mousse variety and an equally well thought out wine list, almost entirely taken from the New World.

It reads, I'm sure, like ambitious stuff and it is, sometimes overly so. Occasionally there was the feeling the kitchen was trying just a little too hard. Tony Smith appears, for example, to have a thing about wilting rocket. There is no point wilting rocket. You might as well wilt grass for all the flavour it is left with. Likewise, a herb-crusted fillet of beef always came up dry however hard we asked for it to be served rare.

These are the minor niggles. The real problem is the numerical one. Orange saffron butter sauce and its ilk is lovely once a week. I could probably give it a good seeing to twice from one Sunday to the next. But every other day is just a bit much, even for a professional, battle-hardened stomach like mine. Moonfleet is aware of the problem. In the summer months, when guests tend to stay for longer than just a weekend, they lay on a couple of barbecues and a buffet each week. (All three were simple and straightforward which was exactly what we wanted from them.)

But even so that still left us studying Chef Smith's glorious creations every other day. The menu just cries out for a few simple grilled fish options, for bangers and mash or dressed crab or steak and chips; for the opportunity once in a while to merely feed the soul. One of the problems, I'm sure, is pricing. For non-residents three courses à la carte is charged at a pretty reasonable £26.50, but nobody would want to pay that for bangers and mash.

Residents, on the other hand, get it thrown in as part of a dinner, bed and breakfast deal which, even at the very top end (around £255 a night for two adults), works out at pretty good value. Such is the sturdy circle that Moonfleet is trying to square. Still, my job isn't the economics of the business. It's the eating, which I think I did admirably. All five times. Now I'm going for a long lie down, at least until dinner time.

 Moonfleet Manor Hotel, Fleet, near Weymouth, Dorset (01305 786 948). Dinner for two non-residents, including wine and service, is around £70.

Contact Jay Rayner at jay.rayner@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Don't be dotconned
fields.standfirst:
Buying up domain names is a mug's game, says Jamie Doward
Net news
Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Buying up domain names is a mug's game, says Jamie Doward.
fields.body:
Domain names are seen as the new real estate. A strong one helps to guide internet users to a company's website, which is why they can sell for the sort of fortunes made when the property market is soaring.

The domain name year2000 fetched $10 million recently, while business.com went for $7m. The UK owner of ebuy.com claims he turned down a similar sum for his domain name. The owner of America.com is offering it to anyone prepared to pay $30m.

But experts are warning that many punters shelling out for names they believe will bring them riches are facing nothing but embarrassment and disappointment. The problem is that an increasing number of so-called domain names are not what they seem. Wily internet companies have started selling what are known as 'sub-domain' names, which cannot be registered and are largely worthless.

The sharp practice has been given impetus by Icann, the Internet Corporation for Assigned News and Numbers, the world body which oversees the allocation of domain names on a not-for-profit basis. It is poised at its current meeting in Japan to ratify a new batch of domain name identities, known as 'Top Level Domains' (TLDs) because they are recognised globally. Typically, these include names ending in either .com, signifying a commercial web address, or .org, signifying a public organisation. Most of these have been bought up, and there is still huge untapped demand. Hence the batch of new names.

These will eventually include the suffix '.eu', an important signifier for companies wishing to show customers that they have a European presence.

However, the suffix has created confusion, - and internet firms have cashed in. One, CentralNic.com, bought 'www.eu.com' for an undisclosed sum, and is selling two-year licences to 'own' names such as Harrods.eu.com and Microsoft.eu.com at £80 each. Yet the addresses offered are not acknowledged as true domain names by the internet's official registration agencies. These agencies will recognise only those TLD names that end in '.eu' - for instance www.Microsoft.eu, rather than '.eu.com'.

All of the names for sale are registered with CentralNic's important-sounding 'Global domain names registry'. However, it has no official standing as a registry. Buyers of the subdomains simply have their names entered in its database. CentralNic is lobbying to have subdomain names recognised by Icann, for obvious commercial reasons, but for now this remains only a remote possibility.

Other names that have been offered for sale by CentralNic include those with Ford, Ferrari, Marks & Spencer and Barclays before the eu.com suffix. The company also owns 16 other TLD names, including us.com, uk.com and gb.com, allowing it to rent out further sets of sub-domain names.

Another company which acts as an agent for CentralNic, named 123.com, is also selling addresses ending in '.eu.com' for £69 each. Those for sale on its website include the titles of large companies, such as Hilton Hotels, Pepsi-Cola, Microsoft and Virgin, as well as the Nationwide building society.

CentralNic claims to have a network of 300 dealers licensed to sell its wares.

Many subdomain names have already been bought up, some by CentralNic's staff. But any punters looking to buy names and sit on them in in the hope that the firms involved will agree to buy them - a practice known as 'cyber-squatting' - are likely to end up out of pocket. Marks & Spencer, for example, says it will take legal action if the name Marks&Spencer.eu.com is sold or used for a website.

CentralNic's own site claims it is 'fulfilling pent up demand' and helping com panies 'seeking a European identity' during a 'shortage of domain names [which] has concerned internet authorities'.

Some people may agree that a .eu.com subdomain name helps achieve this. But don't buy one expecting to make millions. They are the fool's gold of the internet.
fields.bodyText: Domain names are seen as the new real estate. A strong one helps to guide internet users to a company's website, which is why they can sell for the sort of fortunes made when the property market is soaring. The domain name year2000 fetched $10 million recently, while business.com went for $7m. The UK owner of ebuy.com claims he turned down a similar sum for his domain name. The owner of America.com is offering it to anyone prepared to pay $30m. But experts are warning that many punters shelling out for names they believe will bring them riches are facing nothing but embarrassment and disappointment. The problem is that an increasing number of so-called domain names are not what they seem. Wily internet companies have started selling what are known as 'sub-domain' names, which cannot be registered and are largely worthless. The sharp practice has been given impetus by Icann, the Internet Corporation for Assigned News and Numbers, the world body which oversees the allocation of domain names on a not-for-profit basis. It is poised at its current meeting in Japan to ratify a new batch of domain name identities, known as 'Top Level Domains' (TLDs) because they are recognised globally. Typically, these include names ending in either .com, signifying a commercial web address, or .org, signifying a public organisation. Most of these have been bought up, and there is still huge untapped demand. Hence the batch of new names. These will eventually include the suffix '.eu', an important signifier for companies wishing to show customers that they have a European presence. However, the suffix has created confusion, - and internet firms have cashed in. One, CentralNic.com, bought 'www.eu.com' for an undisclosed sum, and is selling two-year licences to 'own' names such as Harrods.eu.com and Microsoft.eu.com at £80 each. Yet the addresses offered are not acknowledged as true domain names by the internet's official registration agencies. These agencies will recognise only those TLD names that end in '.eu' - for instance www.Microsoft.eu, rather than '.eu.com'. All of the names for sale are registered with CentralNic's important-sounding 'Global domain names registry'. However, it has no official standing as a registry. Buyers of the subdomains simply have their names entered in its database. CentralNic is lobbying to have subdomain names recognised by Icann, for obvious commercial reasons, but for now this remains only a remote possibility. Other names that have been offered for sale by CentralNic include those with Ford, Ferrari, Marks & Spencer and Barclays before the eu.com suffix. The company also owns 16 other TLD names, including us.com, uk.com and gb.com, allowing it to rent out further sets of sub-domain names. Another company which acts as an agent for CentralNic, named 123.com, is also selling addresses ending in '.eu.com' for £69 each. Those for sale on its website include the titles of large companies, such as Hilton Hotels, Pepsi-Cola, Microsoft and Virgin, as well as the Nationwide building society. CentralNic claims to have a network of 300 dealers licensed to sell its wares. Many subdomain names have already been bought up, some by CentralNic's staff. But any punters looking to buy names and sit on them in in the hope that the firms involved will agree to buy them - a practice known as 'cyber-squatting' - are likely to end up out of pocket. Marks & Spencer, for example, says it will take legal action if the name Marks&Spencer.eu.com is sold or used for a website. CentralNic's own site claims it is 'fulfilling pent up demand' and helping com panies 'seeking a European identity' during a 'shortage of domain names [which] has concerned internet authorities'. Some people may agree that a .eu.com subdomain name helps achieve this. But don't buy one expecting to make millions. They are the fool's gold of the internet.

fields.headline: Don't line up, get online
fields.standfirst:
Scarce library resources needn't hamper your studies, says Sean Dodson, the answer may lie in cyberspace
Clearing 2000
fields.trailText: The massive rise in undergraduate places in recent years has left many of the UK's academic libraries struggling to keep up with demand. Many library books are in short supply, and sometimes in a shocking state of disrepair, so online resources are now vital to practically every degree.
fields.body:
The massive rise in undergraduate places in recent years has left many of the UK's academic libraries struggling to keep up with demand. Many library books are in short supply, and sometimes in a shocking state of disrepair, so online resources are now vital to practically every degree. Using the internet as a study aid will not replace books, but it will shorten the time it takes to acquire information.

A good starting point is the Encyclopædia Britannica, whose full text is available free at www.britannica.com. Although your university library will have copies of the old tome, searching online is much quicker, and it is updated regularly. For about £30 a year you can subscribe to www.eb.com, Britannica's enhanced service. This includes a web directory filtered by Britannica staff.

Similarly, a site such as the CIA's World Fact Book (www.odci.gov/cia/publications/factbook) can prove useful. With information from the net GDP of Guatemala to the legacy of the KGB in Peru, academic writing can be qualified with the most recent data.

True, not everything is on the web, and many things are still difficult to find. Beware relying too heavily on search engines where the order in which sites are presented is affected by factors other than academic utility or objectivity. While still useful tools, search engines seem to be struggling to keep up with the enormous growth of the web. According to research from science journal Nature, even the best search engine (www.northernlights.com) has only 16 per cent of the web in its database.

Still, with a handful of good sites, including major acade mic portals such as the Government's National Grid for Learning (www.ngfl.gov.uk), researching on the web is often more fruitful than not.

An absolute must is the American academic search directory at www.academicinfo.net. This holds thousands of links to academic sites and has an exhaustive list of digital libraries around the world. Like Britannia, Academic Info employs dozens of researchers and academics to trawl through the net. This means much of the dross that can clog up search engines has been filtered out. It is a bit like the Yahoo! of the academic world.

At the very least, these sites can speed up the organisation of study. Consider how easy it is to find text on the web, cut and paste it into a word processing document and then email it to either yourself or a friend. The alternative requires booking time on the library databases and catalogues, finding the book on the shelves (or not), queuing to borrow the book or reserving it and then laboriously photocopying or transcribing the required pages and typing the required quotes into an essay.

The web does not just beat many libraries on searchability and rare texts; it is excellent on contemporary debates too. The New York Review of Books is available at www.nybooks.com/nyrev and has a searchable archive going back to 1995. And the web boasts two great journals of its own in the form of www.salon.com and www.slate.com. Both contain a range of articles and essays on science, technology, politics and the arts.

Science is particularly well covered on the web. Details of the latest research and a set of reliable research tools are available. Sites such as Exoscience (http://exosci.com) publish regular bulletins on scientific issues and if you have access to email, Netsurfer Science (www.netsurf.com/nss), will deliver bulletins to your inbox.

The vast majority of content on the web is free, but a number of sites charge a pay-to-download fee or a subscription. If you cannot find what you need elsewhere, these sites could still save you time, and need not cost the earth if you club together with friends. Contentville.com launched in the US in June. It is full of magazine articles, transcripts, e-books and speeches. It claims to contain 'every dissertation written for a PhD degree in the US since 1861'. But it is not cheap. Magazine articles are sold for $2.95; a full dissertation (in electronic form) costs around $50. The similar Electronic Library (www.elibrary.com) offers a free 30-day trial.

But there is still more than enough for free on the web. The FT claims to offer more than 8.5 million articles from 3,000 publications, much of it free. And most newspaper websites now have fairly sophisticated search engines.

Other tools to save you time and improve your work include www.onelook.com, which searches more than 300 dictionaries at once. Roget's Thesaurus.com helps you find that very word.

The web is truly worldwide. If English is your only language, do not discount foreign language sites. Altavista's Babelfish software (http://babelfish.altavista.digital.com) will give a translation, albeit rudimentary, in six languages. So if you want to get ahead at university, avoid the scramble for library books and get to grips with the web.

fields.headline: 'Now I understand what Kierkegaard  was on about. The leap of faith is not towards God, but love and housing'
fields.standfirst: Jenny Diski, besotted at 53, is buying a house to be near her lover. In the second of a continuing series she discovers love is easy, property is a pain...
fields.trailText: Jenny Diski, besotted at 53, is buying a house to be near her lover. In the second of a continuing series she discovers love is easy, property is a pain...
fields.body:
In Cambridge, I've graduated from estate agents to solicitors and financial advisers. My flat, on the other hand, has not been sold. It's summer, I'm told. No one's buying, they're all away. Apparently it isn't summer in Cambridge, because I'm not away and I've bought. So a vast loan has been arranged and my cuddly little Cambridge terraced house is being conveyed to me. The only real fear I have in my life is of dispossession. Now I will have two houses from which I could be dispossessed.

I understand what Kierkegaard was on about at last. The leap of faith is not towards God, but love (for want of a better term) and housing. One leap of faith begets another, it seems. First, I throw myself on the mercy of love and risk betrayal, then on the mercy of the property market and risk penury. Never mind, I can be a mad, old, bag-lady instead of the mad, old hermit I had planned to be.

To distract myself, I build castles in Cambridge. Much of the talk between the poet and myself is about how to arrange our elderly idyll on opposite sides of the road. Will we have keys to each other's houses? Of course. But must we phone or knock before we enter? No, no, it is as if we live in one house, but separated by a road which is nothing more than a corridor between us.

I'm not sure about this: surely some system can be devised to indicate that we are working, sleeping, watching something moronic on the TV or sulking. Traffic lights on our front doors, perhaps, red and green, and amber for 'you decide'. A particular arrangement of the upstairs blinds. What about coded electric bells or a pair of whistles whose pitch only the poet and I can hear?

All this is a worry. If my house is his house, and his house is my house, where is the private space we both agreed was essential for mature love to mature further? It begins to look as if one big house with an east and west wing might be more suitable. Sadly, for a poetry-making don and a novel-writing granddaughter of immigrants, the aristocratic way is not an option.

I am inclined towards a covered walkway across the roofs, a kind of bridge of sighs, but the poet favours a tunnel, a netherworld connecting us like the linking of two unconsciousnesses. There you have the him and me of it. If planning permission is a problem we would both settle for a system of pneumatic tubes like they used to have in department stores in the old days. At a pinch, email would do.

Or there is the phone. Or we could send invitations through the post.

Still, this one house divided into two concepts has something to be said for it. It occurs to me that since the poet is a passionate cook and I am passionately not, I don't need a kitchen in my house at all. It could be entirely devoted to my pleasures and needs: a study, a reading room, a luxury bathroom, a dedicated bedroom (maybe two: one for private sleeping, one for sex).

But how will he let me know when supper is ready? He could bring it over. Do I want a lover or a waiter?

'Has it crossed your mind,' I say, 'that whenever we talk about this living almost together thing in Cambridge, we always imagine that you are in your house and I am in mine?'

He is unfazed, explaining that being apart is our difficulty, not being together.

Pshaw, I hiss, or something spelt very like that. I tell him once again that he is in the grip of middle-aged delusion, in love with being in love. And what about when he comes to his senses, and there we are staring angrily at each other from opposite windows?

'But what if I'm not deluded?' he says calmly.This is very aggravating, because I know he is and all he has to do is agree with me. In any case, as he knows perfectly well, 'what if he's not deluded' is quite as alarming as what if he is.

It's all very well countering my what if with his what if, but the fact that there's no certainty to be had this or that side of death, doesn't mean I don't want it. Cambridge has become the land of what if, and I, for reasons that I can't or won't quite put my finger on, am emigrating to it.

'What if,' I mutter, 'after I've moved across the road from you, one of us gets creamed by a lorry as we're crossing it?'

We're both quite overcome by the tragic irony I've just retrospected. We discuss who will play us when Stephen Frears makes the movie (the romantic drama having been transferred to New York and Harvard, naturally). I refuse to have Meryl Streep or Meg Ryan, but I know it's hopeless. The poet doesn't mind being played by Nick Nolte at all. (He would also like it to be known that he's beginning to develop great sympathy with Mrs Phil Hogan.)

But talking of crossing the road. Do we have to get dressed when we go back to our own house? Will a dressing gown do? Or a towel? Can we skitter across in the buff? It puts Neighbourhood Watch in quite a different light. I think we'd probably better call a street meeting to thrash out the problem.

webTitle: Profile of AEEU stalwart Sir Ken Jackson

fields.headline: 'Honest bastard' the brothers love to hate
fields.standfirst:
Oliver Morgan profiles AEEU stalwart Sir Ken Jackson
Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: Oliver Morgan profiles AEEU stalwart Sir Ken Jackson
fields.body:
Sir Ken Jackson has a favourite story that he likes to recount to friends. It concerns Les Cannon, the granite-jawed president of the electricians' trade union (EETPU) in the Seventies.

Jackson, now head of the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union (AEEU), which includes Cannon's former members, says: 'I remember just days before Les died the BBC did an interview with him. He sounded terribly weak. He was asked what he would like as his epitaph. He said: "I don't mind people remembering me as a bastard, as long as they say I was an honest bastard".'

Cannon and Jackson were both born in Wigan and many in the union movement would say they share more than a birthplace.

He has made many enemies during his career; from his resistance to communists in the electricians' unions in the Sixties to the back-room politics of the merger of the EETPU and the Amalgamated Engineering Union in 1992.

The merger caused bad blood between the two sides for years but Jackson is specifically blamed for seeking to maximise the interests of electricians over engineers. What he describes as a clear-out of part-time branch staff in order to create a more efficient organisation was seen as a grass-roots purge.

Jackson feels this is not entirely fair. 'I have had to take tough decisions,' he says. 'We needed to set the union on a secure financial footing, and this meant reorganising the branches.'

He maintains there is plenty of room for engineers, some of whom are regional secretaries.

He claims his position at the head of one of Britain's largest trade unions - the AEEU boasts 730,000 members - was the culmination of a life of service and luck.

He joined the Electrical Trade Union (ETU) in 1966, five years after leaving the RAF where he was an electrician. He became a local branch secretary in Wigan, before taking an area job in Preston and moving to take responsibility for Merseyside and the North West in the Eighties. The expanded EEPTU, then led by Frank Chapple, was the leading moderate union, fighting the Militant Tendency and arguing for what became the modernising Labour policies of the Nineties, such as one member, one vote in party leadership elections and abolition of the nationalising Clause 4.

The enmity of Derek Hatton, the Militant Liverpool council leader, and his supporters meant Jackson, as EEPTU political secretary, felt he had to go about his union business with a bodyguard.

But his high profile stood him in good stead. Jackson was elected general secretary of the merged AEEU in 1995. 'There were a series of bizarre events,' he recalls. 'People left for one reason or another - Paul Gallagher (previous head of the AEEU), Gavin Laird (former head of the AEU) and Bill Jordan (AEEU president). Suddenly I was the only one.'

It sounds too good to be true, and some, particularly those at the Manufacturing, Science and Finance Union, which is currently negotiating a merger with the AEEU, clearly think it is.

Jackson continues to fall foul of the Left - he writes regularly in the Sun attacking what he calls 'benefits cheats'. He is unrepentant, saying: 'We have to reflect the interests of the people who have elected us. Our members who pay taxes are concerned about the people who rip off the system.'

Neither is Jackson prepared to pipe down in the interests of union harmony. This week's Trade Union Congress in Glasgow promises a row between him and Bill Morris, head of the Transport and General Workers Union. Last week Morris launched a thinly veiled attack on Jackson - an active member of Britain in Europe - for speaking in favour of the euro, and potentially 'losing the referendum for the Government when the time comes'.

Jackson says Morris is 'aligning himself with the Tories', summoning memories of the unholy anti-European alliance between hard Left and hard Right in the 1975 referendum.

He says: 'I don't understand how any union which represents the manufacturing industry can be anything other than pro the single currency. We've seen what the exchange rate has done for jobs this year.'

He believes the UK is likely to reach convergence in the first half of next year, and that at a push an exchange rate of 3DM, which the markets think possible, would be acceptable.

He also says Blair will needs to sort the euro question quickly if he wins a second term. 'I certainly feel he will want to get this out of the way. It has been dragging on for too long.'

Jackson will not be confining himself to the single currency next week. On Tuesday he will speak in the manufacturing debate, and will not be shy of treading on Whitehall and Westminster toes. After a terrible year for the manufacturing industry and for jobs, he says: 'We have to avoid self-inflicted wounds. Can you imagine the French awarding a contract for four roll-on roll-off ferries [currently out for tender from the Government] to another country and watching jobs disappear? Or the French army being clothed in non French-made uniforms?'

While the target for these barbs is the Ministry of Defence, Jackson also wants more from the Department of Trade and Industry.

'I'll be saying in the speech that we ought to see a more pro-active DTI,' he says. 'Stephen Byers needs to keep his word in terms of helping some of the regions of Britain which are suffering because of the pressure on manufacturing.'

He says the Government needs to act to help employees understand what companies are planning through a package of information and consultation rights like those in the EuropeanUnion. At its summer policy forum in Exeter, Labour appears to have offered a compromise - its own version of EU regulations. Jackson thinks it must go further to put British workers on a par with their European counterparts.

Known for having friends in high places, he seems not to fear ruffling a few feathers. His union will remain the one that many - particularly those who believe his 'partnership' recognition deals with employers betray too cosy a relationship - love to hate. Jackson doesn't care. 'People may call them sweetheart deals. We see them as ways of employers and employees working together for each others' interests.'

Bastard? Maybe not. But more than a little stroppy.

Profile

Subject: Sir Ken Jackson

Age: 63

Job: General Secretary of the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union

Other Jobs: Director of Nirex; member of TUC executive; member of Government's skills taskforce

Hobbies: Rugby League (supports home team Wigan)

'People left for one reason or another - Paul Gallagher (previous head of the AEEU), Gavin Laird (former head of the AEU) and Bill Jordan (AEEU president). Suddenly I was the only one.' It sounds too good to be true, and some, particularly those at the Manufacturing, Science and Finance Union, which is currently negotiating a merger with the AEEU, clearly think it is. Jackson continues to fall foul of the Left - he writes regularly in the Sun attacking what he calls 'benefits cheats'. He is unrepentant, saying: 'We have to reflect the interests of the people who have elected us. Our members who pay taxes are concerned about the people who rip off the system.' Neither is Jackson prepared to pipe down in the interests of union harmony. This week's Trade Union Congress in Glasgow promises a row between him and Bill Morris, head of the Transport and General Workers Union. Last week Morris launched a thinly veiled attack on Jackson - an active member of Britain in Europe - for speaking in favour of the euro, and potentially 'losing the referendum for the Government when the time comes'. Jackson says Morris is 'aligning himself with the Tories', summoning memories of the unholy anti-European alliance between hard Left and hard Right in the 1975 referendum. He says: 'I don't understand how any union which represents the manufacturing industry can be anything other than pro the single currency. We've seen what the exchange rate has done for jobs this year.' He believes the UK is likely to reach convergence in the first half of next year, and that at a push an exchange rate of 3DM, which the markets think possible, would be acceptable. He also says Blair will needs to sort the euro question quickly if he wins a second term. 'I certainly feel he will want to get this out of the way. It has been dragging on for too long.' Jackson will not be confining himself to the single currency next week. On Tuesday he will speak in the manufacturing debate, and will not be shy of treading on Whitehall and Westminster toes. After a terrible year for the manufacturing industry and for jobs, he says: 'We have to avoid self-inflicted wounds. Can you imagine the French awarding a contract for four roll-on roll-off ferries [currently out for tender from the Government] to another country and watching jobs disappear? Or the French army being clothed in non French-made uniforms?' While the target for these barbs is the Ministry of Defence, Jackson also wants more from the Department of Trade and Industry. 'I'll be saying in the speech that we ought to see a more pro-active DTI,' he says. 'Stephen Byers needs to keep his word in terms of helping some of the regions of Britain which are suffering because of the pressure on manufacturing.' He says the Government needs to act to help employees understand what companies are planning through a package of information and consultation rights like those in the EuropeanUnion. At its summer policy forum in Exeter, Labour appears to have offered a compromise - its own version of EU regulations. Jackson thinks it must go further to put British workers on a par with their European counterparts. Known for having friends in high places, he seems not to fear ruffling a few feathers. His union will remain the one that many - particularly those who believe his 'partnership' recognition deals with employers betray too cosy a relationship - love to hate. Jackson doesn't care. 'People may call them sweetheart deals. We see them as ways of employers and employees working together for each others' interests.' Bastard? Maybe not. But more than a little stroppy. Profile Subject: Sir Ken Jackson Age: 63 Job: General Secretary of the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union Other Jobs: Director of Nirex; member of TUC executive; member of Government's skills taskforce Hobbies: Rugby League (supports home team Wigan)

fields.headline: TUC's euro feud boils over
fields.standfirst:
Bill Morris is gambling with jobs, says engineering workers boss
Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: The simmering feud among union leaders over the euro bursts into the open today as pro-euro unions accuse sceptic Bill Morris, leader of the Transport and General Workers, of 'gambling with his members' jobs'.
fields.body:
The simmering feud among union leaders over the euro bursts into the open today as pro-euro unions accuse sceptic Bill Morris, leader of the Transport and General Workers, of 'gambling with his members' jobs'.

In an interview with The Observer Sir Ken Jackson, head of the powerful Amalgamated Electrical and Engineering Union, accuses Morris of creating an 'unholy alliance' with the Conservatives against the euro and pillories his suggestion that the Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee should have a role in deciding when a referendum is called.

Jackson's remarks come as the Manufacturing Science and Finance Union publishes a survey of 100 chief executives of manufacturing firms, in which 94 per cent said their sector would benefit from membership, while 86 per cent said their individual companies would gain.

But concern about the weakness of the single currency intensified as it reached new depths against the dollar last week, hitting 86 cents.

The union row, which has been brewing for well over a year, is now set to dominate this week's TUC conference, which is likely to be the last before a general election. It will have political repercussions: Jackson is known to be very close to the Prime Minister; Morris is an ally of Chancellor Gordon Brown.

Other union leaders, including the GMB's John Edmonds, have joined the fray triggered when Morris said last week that pro-single currency leaders could lose the referendum for the Government by talking up the euro. They should stop doing so, the T&G leader urged.

Edmonds said he was 'surprised' by Morris's intervention, adding that he had hoped the lid could be kept on the issue before the election.

TUC officials have been working throughout the weekend to hammer out a deal on conflicting motions to the conference from pro-euro unions and the T&G, which has officially called for the MPC to have a role. But their efforts appear unsuccessful.

Jackson, who was livid when he read Morris's remarks, intends to lambast the T&G leader from the platform on Tuesday. He told The Observer : 'If Bill Morris wants to gamble with his members' jobs, let him do so. I am not prepared to do the same. A lot of our members work in manufacturing and I am putting their jobs first - not some ideological objection to going into the euro.

'As for Eddie George, anyone who says unemployment in the North-East is an acceptable price for calming inflation in the South-East has no business being involved.'

The AEEU leader rejected Morris's accusation that he advocated immediate entry at any price. Jackson said the UK economy had to converge with that of euroland. He believed the Government's five economic tests - including convergence - could be met early next year, and that Tony Blair wanted to clear away the issue within a year of winning a second term.

Edmonds thought Britain should aim to join the euro in 2003: interest rates should be cut by 1.5 per cent from the current 6 per cent to help with convergence.

'I am bemused by [Morris's] intervention,' he said. 'This has been the subject of much careful discussion within the TUC.'

fields.headline: Healthier than thou
fields.trailText: Few things give the slobbish, unmotivated majority more satisfaction than hearing that people who've made strenuous efforts to be healthy may have been completely wasting their time.
fields.body:
Few things give the slobbish, unmotivated majority more satisfaction than hearing that people who've made strenuous efforts to be healthy may have been completely wasting their time. So one could be forgiven for a touch of schadenfreude at the news that organic food might not be all it's cracked up to be.

According to Sir John Krebs, head of the Food Standards Agency, the bulk of organic produce isn't any safer or more nutritious than regular fare, mainly as 70 per cent is imported into Britain from countries where standards aren't so high. Supporters of organic farming have denounced this report, accusing Sir John of being out of touch with consumers and in thrall to the biotechnology industry.

Just because they're probably right, we shouldn't let it spoil the moment. It seems to me that ordinary Britons have been terrorised and demoralised too long by the healthy elite, who swan around, eating well, exercising, drinking lots of water, looking great, and generally being much better than us. Sometimes it seems as if Alpha Beings in unstructured layers are taking over the world, and we haven't got the time or the energy to stop them.

You're no one without a health regime these days. Just to complicate matters, modern keep fit seems to work on the microwave principle - from the inside out. This gives people the opportunity to say earnestly: 'It's not about vanity, it's about health, how I feel inside.'

To be fair, very few of them actually go around spouting pompous guff like that. They'd love to, but they haven't got the time. They're too busy 'stretching' down at the gym and having sacks of organic produce delivered to their door by environmentally friendly White Van Men. Or taking you into their kitchens to watch their juicers in action. As it turns out, these machines are so inefficient, it's astonishing - they process about one carrot an hour, throb and roar like a tube train is running through the kitchen, then finally splurt out a thimbleful of obnoxious slime. It's the culinary equivalent to journalism, but in this case it's not only media-studies students who want in.

To a certain extent, you feel like leaving them to it. On the other hand, why should we be left out like the fat kid in PE? We want some of that 'health and wellbeing' stuff, give it to us now! Sadly, it's not as simple as that. That's why Linda McCartney was such a boon to lazy vegetarians like myself - not only did she tell you about good food, she arranged for it to be cooked and transported to your local supermarket. It would have been even better if Linda had popped around personally to stick it in the oven for you, but she was a busy woman, with a large family, so we'll let it pass. Elsewhere, healthy living just seems such a drag - hunting down decent organic ranges, heaving Evian out of the fridge, trudging to yoga classes, knowing the difference between zinc and selenium. It never seems to end. In an age when most of us are already stressed to the max at work, being healthy is like signing up for an extra unpaid job. Voluntary work for the me-me-me generation. Which doubtless explains why only Alpha Beings can cope.

So it is, so it has always been. Everybody is entitled to put their own time, money and effort into achieving a healthier lifestyle and diet, if they want to. The problem is, there's probably an awful lot of people out there who'd love to get fitter, but they don't stand a chance. The really scary thing about modern 'good health' is how socially divisive, how class-based, it has become. People say it doesn't cost anything to be healthy, but you only have to look at the price of gyms, vitamin pills and organic produce to realise that's codswallop. In truth, when you're time-poor, money-poor, energy-poor and every other kind of poor, being healthy is hellishly difficult to pull off. One could even argue that good health is on the verge of becoming politically incorrect, because only the relatively better off have the resources to indulge themselves.

Bearing this in mind, instead of concentrating on who does buy organic produce, maybe we should start worrying about who doesn't, or, more specifically, who couldn't afford to. It would be interesting to find out how many stops at council estates Organic White Van Man makes on his rounds. Very few, if any, I'm sure. However, this doesn't mean that poorer citizens are choosing cheap, genetically modified varieties for the fun and thrill of ingesting dodgy pesticides and chemicals. While a lot of us are just too plain lazy to get it together, for many others, 'achieving a healthier lifestyle' could be quite literally beyond their means. As with education, a line has been drawn in 21st-century Britain, and once again, the poor are on the wrong side of it.
